description:
I'm in town for 9 days and have already eaten here 3 days in a row. The sandwiches are expensive, but delicious. The cheesesteak? Divine. The $$$ deliciously neat sweat inducing. The Fatty Matty? Not sure why there falafel on my tuna sandwich, but it's fine, just go with it because that tuna sandwich is amazing.

The bread is fresh, the meat is fresh, the flavors meld beautifully. There is spice, there is fat, there is salt, there is crunch. As far as I'm concerned, those are the elements of a good sandwich and Deli Board knocks it out of the park. I'll probably eat here for the next 6 days and think about it for the next 365.
author: Taylor M.

description:
I went to Deli Board with a friend because it had been recommended to us. It was a Saturday at lunchtime, and Deli Board was surprisingly busy which seemed like a good sign. I walked in and examined the menu. It certainly had plenty of options but it also seemed to be an accumulation of everything that I don't like. Certainly, this is partially because of my dietary restrictions (no beef, no pork) and pickiness, but I don't think I've ever struggled picking out a sandwich at any other restaurant before. 

Given my restrictions, I had 2 possible sandwiches to pick from: one turkey (all other turkeys have pork, too) and one vegetarian. The turkey one had swiss cheese, pepperoncini blend, cole slaw, Board sauce (AKA ranch), and mayo, which are all things I would never choose on a sandwich (except maybe the swiss but there are better cheeses). I was really feeling meat, so I decided to make my own sandwich. I chose turkey on dutch crunch with cheddar and lettuce (why are there no tomatoes on the menu? or regular onions?), and I paid almost $20 for it with tax - quite expensive for a sandwich. 

I walked home and opened up my sandwich to find that they had put jalapenos on it, and there was no cheddar to be seen, so I was quite disappointed. I didn't have enough time to go back, so I picked out the jalapenos and ate it. The sandwich itself was very large - the turkey was almost an inch thick the whole length. I had noticed double meat was an extra $10 and I can see why. I kind of wish they halved the amount of meat and lowered the cost of the sandwich by $5. 

I realized that I'm the minority in sandwich preferences, but my order was so simple and it still came out wrong. If I go back, I'll try a salad instead.
author: Kristin A.

description:
Now this place knows how to make a sandwich.

Bread is fresh Vegetables fresh and crisp , meat is good quality, very flavorful..
author: Head Chef F.

description:
Really unimpressed. Basically got a shit ton of dry meat, a little avocado and two jalapeños. Bread was great but otherwise this sandwich was really lame. I can't believe that I paid nearly $20 for it. Fool me once.....
I will not be back.
author: Shmev R.

description: Meaty sandwiches, mmm. I arrived right when they opened so I was lucky enough to grab a table after ordering at the counter. Within minutes the line was out the door. Lots of locals mixed with some visitors. It was hard to pick a sandwich especially when they all sounded and looked good. I liked that you can customize your sandwich too. The staff is very friendly and the food comes out quick. A must try when in San Francisco!
author: Pam A.

description:
I love Deli Board's sandwiches. They remind me of the original Ike's Place - fresh bread, heaps of meat, clever sauces... 

But the price here continues to rise, with most sandwiches starting at $18 - and that's before tax or tip. 

My favorite sandwich is the Ron, which is roast beef, cheddar cheese, jalapenos, avocado, cole slaw, and "Board sauce," but even it is $17 sans tip/tax. 

Logically complicated, too - no online or phone orders and very limited seating, with long lines at peak hours. But staff is friendly. A nice treat for locals, but not a regular lunch go to anymore.
author: Greg B.

description:
First I've heard of a sandwich being referred to as a sando. But hey, my sando was bomb af so I'll go with calling it a sando.

Yes, the name of the sando I ordered is $$$. Definitely not for anyone vegan or vegetarian. Brisket, corned beef, salami, and cheese and on a toasted roll. This sando really is money. Hella damn good. My only regret was that I didn't grab a bag of chips.

This place wins at life.
author: Xerxes N.

description:
When I come across a sandwich that's comprised of Romanian pastrami, turkey, Kosher salami, American and muenster cheeses, pepperoncini blend, pickles, house "Board sauce"--all on and Dutch crunch bread--I'm going to effing order it. The sandwich I'm referring to is the Leroy Brown at Deli Board and honestly I was sold at pastrami.

A visit here with coworkers was casual and cool and we even got to chat it up with the owner for a bit. A couple cops even showed up to chomp down some sandwiches. Good call. There's a grittiness to Deli Board that makes this place special. Like a little piece of when SF wasn't full of tech a-holes still exists. Like Clint Eastwood would've eaten here when filming Dirty Harry.

Get here for the sandwiches. Stay for the sandwiches. Come back for the more sandwiches.
author: Will S.

description:
Delicious sandwich, no doubt. It's perfect in each bite and not overwhelmingly large. My sandwich was perfectly toasted, and I was extremely satisfied with my selection - hot thin pastrami with cheese sandwiched between two slices of dutch crunch perfection.

BUT HOLY SH*T THE PRICES ARE THROUGH THE ROOF.
$17 for a delicious sandwich?! This is what I hate about SF. All of the sandwiches are amazingly expensive. Tasty... yes... but expensive AF ($15-$18 range!!!). Be aware of what you're walking into. It's almost egregious to price it like this.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Never had I ever paid $18 for a deli sandwich. Now I have and it's not worth it. With sandwich prices ranging from $16-20, you expect it to be heavenly. Unfortunately it tastes more like a $10 sandwich. The pickle was good, though.

Vegetarians be warned: there is only one sans meat option on the menu.
author: Nick K.

description:
Well the sandwiches are spectacular. No doubt about that. Excellent local spot to come in and grab a sandwich. 

That being said, I have 2 negatives which impact the rating. 

The first one is that my sandwich was $16. A sandwich? For $16? And that's it? Don't get me wrong, it was delicious but DANG!!! $16!?!? That's a little much for just a sandwich. Pretty much all of them are on the pricey side. 

The second one is that there aren't a lot of seats. It's a smaller spot and it's a popular spot so it can get crowded. 

If you're getting a sandwich to go then no worries. If you want to eat here, you may want to come earlier because once it's 11:30 or on, it's pretty full.
author: Matt M.

description:
Meh.  

No f'in way this place is better than Ike's or Lou's and no way it's remotely close to justifying an $18 sandwich. 

I'm not hating on the price point, but you better bring it if it's basically more expensive than the burger at Marlowe. It doesn't even come close. 

What this place really feels like is SOMA trying to establish some street cred but falling short.  Just making it a hipster sandwich spot and charging Mission+ prices doesn't get you there, the sandwiches need to be epic and they are just so-so.  

I had the Carzle and the French bread was good, cherry peppers were also good, but the 'strami/provolone/sauce heart of the sandwich was just lacking; tasted more greasy than actually standing out in terms of flavor.

I'd pass unless you were starving, right there, and had $20 you didn't need.
author: Saminda W.

description:
I am freakishly obsessed with the Deli Board. The owner Adam is very cool and super hospitable. A guys guy. 
He's even got a new bagel spot called Board. It's on my list now! 
I love the Bradley, but you can't go wrong with anything the new. Give the specials a try, I've been disappointed.
author: Kristina C.

description: Great overstuffed sandwiches. A little pricey but size and quality matches up to the price. If you are staying in the Union Square area or near Moscone,  it is definitely worth the walk. Be sure to also check out their specials on the door when you walk in.
author: Nathan R.

description: Yummy!!! This place was fantastic. Stupid me went during the busiest time though. There was quite a big line. But I wanted to see why!! The "Board" had too many wonderful sandwiches. I really couldn't decide. Eventually, I got the Ruby Claire. it was to die for. Definitely recommend.
author: Olive R.

description:
Have been meaning to try out this place for some time and have tried several of their sandwiches recently.  Cleveland style/inspired sandwiches at this spot which ironically enough when I went to Cleveland a couple years back I went to a notable sandwich place with a line out the door. I had an underwhelming experience as well so maybe Cleveland- stye isn't for me??? 

Let's start out by just pointing out that there are a lot of great sandwich places in the city.  I'd list some of them here but Yelp frowns upon this , as they sometimes consider this promotional.

I've tried more than a few (sandwich places) and why did I give this place a 3 star rating ?  It's not the price which I know a lot of people take issue with but it's simply because the taste wasn't enough for me to crave another one when there are other viable options.  Yelp shows "I'm a fan" when you hover over the four star rating and I just didn't think this place was deserving of 4 stars for me let alone 5. 

The Leroy Brown however surprisingly was my favorite of the 3 sandwiches I've tasted to this point. I'm not a pastrami fan but as others have pointed out the quality of meat here seems to be above average. I like how the balance of the meat and the "others" (stuff in the sandwich) is just right in the Leroy Brown.  

The service was friendly and the sandwiches came out relatively quick as well. 

I tried the (in order of what I liked the most) :
Leroy Brown-$17-  romanian pastrami, turkey, koshe salami yellow american cheese, muenster cheese, pepporcini blend, pickles, board sauce on dutch crunch

Tina- $16- turkey avocado, muenster & chedder cheese, cherry peppers , cole slaw , board sauce, brown mustard, garlic french roll

Zeke - $16-  turkey , avocado , bacon ,cream cheese, pickled onion, sprouts , mayo , french roll
author: Rod M.

description:
This is THE BEST sandwich in the Bay Area. If not the world. Anything on the menu is great and is well thought out.

Service is great

The only thing you have to know is this is not a Jewish deli, the pastrami is AMAZING but if you want a mound of it on rye with mustard you are in the wrong place.

Come early as the line can get crazy
author: Chris G.

description:
I made a visit to Deli Board for lunch one day.  There was a lot of options to choose from, but I ultimately went with the Carlze based on a recommendation from the staff at the counter.  The Carzle was really tasty.  The Romanian pastrami had a really nice flavor and got a good kick from the board sauce and cherry peppers.  The cherry on top was the juicy pickle that came with the sandwich.  

Other than the food, this place was decently packed and it took a few minutes to find a table.  I would definitely come back to grab a sandwich but need to plan ahead to fight the crowds coming from the surrounding offices.
author: Mitch T.

description:
Deli Board never disappoints. I only work one lunch shift a week at my job and it's the bane of my existence. Deli Board is the one reason I get excited to get up and be excited about my shift. The menu is always changing and so unique. The sandwiches are incredible and the staff is always super friendly. Thank you for making my work week less stressful and filling my belly. 

 best sandwich shop in San Francisco
author: Megan K.

description:
At first, I was thinking this would be another version of Ike's, a popular Bay Area sandwich shop. However, after ordering from Deli Board, this place has proven itself to be far superior to any other sandwich shop in the area.  I ordered the $$$$ sandwich. The bread was crispy, buttery, and soft to your bite.  The meat and mayo spreads were the highlights to this sandwich.  The meat was extremely tender and soft, full of flavor, and will leave you full.  However, it's so good that you'll want to order another. Be sure to ask for the complimentary bottled water that comes with your sandwich.

The only drawback is that the sandwiches are rather pricey. But is it worth it for the best sandwich around town? You be it is.
author: Nick A.

description:
The Best. East Coast deli sandwiches are second to none, but the Deli Board is on par with any of them.  Sandwiches are expensive, but you get  a real sandwich with a lot of meat.  Its a must try if you are near SOMA.
was losing faith in SF sandwiches, but no more.
author: Braden E.

description:
If you're looking to drop a pretty penny (or 1,700 pretty pennies) on a sandwich packed with a mountain of meat, look no further.

Rotating menu featuring new flavor combinations, typically packed with 2-3 types of meat. I'm particular to the Bradley which was packed with corned beef, pastrami, AND brisket. Deli Board absolutely kills the pastrami game. That being said, seems you can't really go wrong with the plethora of options on their ever-changing menu.

Quite a long wait (20min to order and another 10min before the sandwiches come out) and not much seating available due to the hoards of people, but that's to be expected at a sandwich shop only open for lunch hrs. If you're in SOMA at the appropriate time and you know what you're getting yourself into, it's hard to think of a reason not to spoil your carnivorous stomach.



Oh ps. They give free bottled water for dine-ins because they don't have tap water. And there's a restroom in the back.
author: Deanna C.

description: This place just has it, plain and simple. We opted for the Mr. Adams, not spicy, which is the main man in the kitchen's own creation at the time of. This guy whipped up a 4-meat bomber that makes it into my top 3 sandwiches ever eaten. That's a serious statement coming from a guy from Brooklyn. Everything was perfect and the meats tasted like they just came out of the roaster. 10/10 for this place. Keep on doing you!
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Was turned on to Deli Board by a friend who said this was the best sandwich spot in the city. Boy was he right. 

I had the $$$ (brisket and corned beef, amongst lots of other things on a French roll) and damn if that wasn't the best sandwich I've ever had I don't know what is. The bread was crunchy and the meat was thinly sliced. The entire sandwich was very well-composed and held together extremely well. 

The waffle fries were perfectly crispy without having to order them extra crispy like I normally have to anywhere else. And mad sauce that they came with was SO GOOD. It was like In n Out sauce but less mayo and more mustard so it tastes slightly more acidic. 

Unfortunately, they're only open at lunch time, which is why it took me so long to try it. I'll have to make sure I keep this place in mind for Sunday brunch. It's fast and simple. 

It's a little pricey but I've spent slightly less for a far inferior sandwich in the past! Can't wait to come back.
author: Nick D.

description:
The Deli Board has been on my list for some time and I was finally able to make a visit after my appointment at a nearby business.

It was just after 12 noon on a weekday and I expected the line to be long.  However, I expected it to move and it did, but slowly.  After placing my order I went back outside to wait for my name to be called.  

At first glance I didn't like any of their sandwiches as almost all contained pastrami (I have NOTHING against pastrami but don't like it combined with other meats) and I didn't want a basic sandwich either as I knew that would not be a good test of how good the establishment could be.  I decided on the 555, which consisted of pastrami, turkey, cheddar and american cheese, pepperoncini, coleslaw, pickles and Board sauce on a garlic dutch crunch roll.  The sandwich is heated, which allowed the cheese to be oozy and stringy when the two halves were pulled apart.  The flavors of the sandwich produced a wonderful taste and taste sensation with each bite but the flavors became a bit muddled over time.  Overall, this was a pretty good sandwich.

Yes, the sandwiches are a bit on the pricey side but I assume that is because they are making so many of the sandwich components themselves.  It's worth trying at least once as I have not seen any other sandwich around town that is quite like the one I tried here.

The total wait was around 25 minutes to place my order and around 15 minutes for my food.  If you park on Folsom there were plenty of free 1 hour parking spots to be found.  Some side streets have parking meters.  Most of the crowd was there to order their food to go.  Tables opened up and the line became significantly shorter just after 1 pm.
author: Melissa L.

description:
If you can afford to spend $17 on a sandwich, you still shouldn't spend $17 on a sandwich. I however, can't afford to spend $17 on a sandwich yet here I am, so who am I to judge? Anyway, it's just this one time (she said, while in her heart of hearts, she knew it was not just this, air quotes, one time.)

If you're here and you a.) already own property, or b.) are setting back property ownership/retirement by 10 years (let's face it, it wasn't going to happen anyway, you might as well get that avocado toast) you would not go wrong in getting a hot sandwich and a side of crispy waffle fries. 
 
My Mezman --Romanian pastrami, deviled egg salad spread, fiery sweet cherry peppers, muenster cheese, Board sauce, garlic Dutch crunch-- was a rib-hugging combination of ooze, crunch, heat, salt, fat, umami and acid. 

So pleased was I that for a moment, I (drenched in rainwater, mouth full of Dutch crunch) forgot the perennially cruel April Fool's joke San Francisco plays, of pretending to be Los Angeles for one balmy week before yanking away the sunshine and dumping buckets of water on you.
author: Tianyi S.

description:
How do I eat this everyday? It took 30 min to get our sandwich during lunch and the place was PACKED. And sandwiches aren't cheap either, mine was $18. But it was damn good. Tender pastrami and brisket, cheesy and excellent pickles. I wish I lived on top of this place or next door but it's located in the cuts. 

It can be more efficient if they could call out names more effectively versus having the staff shout it out and walk around. So great place to try. The sandwiches are pretty unique. Almost like a hoagie but not as oily. Great for a team adventure lunch!
author: Young Y.

description:
Wow!!! The price for a sandwich and a club soda (can) is outrageously high! The sandwich is nothing special at all! 

I mean I don't even know what I paid for?!? 

Never again
author: Jaime C.

description:
Cleveland-born sandwich savant, Adam Mesnick, bringing his sandwiching talents to San Francisco is the biggest Bay Area free agency acquisition in recent memory. 

The Romanian pastrami is without a shadow of a doubt the best is the city and the other monster sandwiches pile the entire butcher shop window between slices of various delicious breads-- of course made fresh daily.

Get the "$$$" and the "Leroy Brown"... and don't sleep on the "bk" breakfast sandwich, which is one of the fattest fat boy sausage + BEC's you will find anywhere. 

Heads up, they're a little more expensive than your average sando. But if you can't spend a few extra bucks on greatness, then maybe take the extra money you're saving and spend it on finding yourself because I can't help you.

Go Browns!
author: Trevor W.

description:
Man oh man was my experience at Deli Board one to remember. To start off this place truly cracks me up. A Cleveland guy repping Cleveland in the bay with all sorts of Cavaliers items as well as pictures of Mr Lebron James. That's not what caught my attention though.

When you look at the menu.. expect to take a minute to figure out which sandwich you are going to want as it took me a bit as well as some help from the nice woman at the register.

Ended up going with the Carzle and my goodness was my taste buds taken away. The sandwich is stacked and expect be full of you can finish it which I barely did because it was too darn good. 

My only issue with this place is the fact that it's not in LA because that's where I'm from but other than that this Cleveland guy definitely knows how to make one delicious sandwich in the Bay
author: Payam Ali K.

description:
I went here for the first time today and they make a perfect sandwich. There's a lot of meat, without being too much to get your mouth around it, or so much that it falls out. 

I got the $$$ sandwich, which was delicious and had a great balance of flavors. It is a bit spicy, but not overwhelming.

Also, the waffle fries are $8 but it's a huge serving. I wish the owners would start selling half portions.
The sauce they serve with them is like a more mustard-y in-n-out sauce. And it's delicious.

Cost is about $16-17 a sandwich, but if you take a friend and split a sandwich and fries it's perfect.
author: Elena K.

description: Got the Ilyaboss today! Definitely need to share with someone, the sandwich is gigantic and was stuffed with chicken and pastrami. It came with swiss cheese and some jalapeno bits.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
This is THE premium sandwich spot in SF. It's expensive, there's usually a line but when you wake up on a Saturday morning and are craving tasty meat on bread, this place is worth it. 

I've tried almost the whole menu in the last few months and my favs are the Leroy brown, Bradley, boca, $$$, carzle. They're the ones with a combo of different meats like pastrami, roast beef, corned beef, brisket.. Oh man the words alone.. 

They have two hot sauces, one super hot one and one semi hot, the super hot is legit, few drops at a time only. The pickles are massive and juicy a good acidic cleanser between bites.

$20 for a sandwich is a lot but these babies are worth every penny.
author: Pat K.

description: First time trying Deli Board! The sandwich was amazing, but kind of pricey. I ordered the Carzle but with cheddar cheese on Dutch crunch. The real reason why this place deserves 5 stars is because of Claire! She was amazing. She made our experience great.
author: Galia A.

description:
Woah woah woah. A friend of mine mentioned that this place was pretty good and had large portions, so we went there for lunch today, even though it was quite far from my office (30 min walk).

I got the 555, which was composed of Romanian pastrami, turkey breast, cheddar and white American cheese, pepperoncini blend, coleslaw, pickles, Board sauce, and garlic Dutch crunch. First off, the meat portion; the meat portion wasn't too little, but it wasn't a lot either. Before receiving the sandwich, I was worried about there being too much turkey meat and thus creating too dry of a texture; however, this was not the case, so all was good. Probably the first thing you notice when you pull apart the sandwich would be the cheese, as it stretches and pulls apart into the respective sandwich halves. This would only be possible because of how warm they toast their sandwiches, which was something I really appreciated on a cold day like today. The Dutch crunch provided a really nice crunchy texture that housed all of the middle layer ingredients, though I didn't really taste much garlic.

I honestly don't know what the Board sauce tasted like because I ate it all too quickly (I must have been pretty hungry), but I remember overall being very satisfied with the flavor profile of the sandwich. With every sandwich order, it also comes with a bag of some sliced pickles, which I ate to top off the sandwich.

All in all, I ate the sandwich way too quickly, but it tasted delicious. I would give it a 11/10, would come here again to try other sandwiches (and probably eat slower to be able to discern the flavors a little more).
author: Ed W.

description: I had the Zoe sandwich with the waffles fries and mick sauce. It had falafel, hummus, muenster cheese, red and green bell peppers, pickles, pickled red onions, sprouts, & Board sauce (mayonnaise & ranch) on a french roll. I got jalapeños instead of pickles so it had a nice kick. The waffle fries had a nice crisp on the outside and were soft on the inside. The mick sauce is their take on a thousand island sauce (like McDonald's Big Mac sauce or In n Out's spread sauce), really good!
author: Sheila P.

description: Ordered turkey sandwich with sprouts & pepperchini blend. Such a great lunch spot & a go to when your at work!
author: Gabriel T.

description: I am a sandwich snob and this is one of the best sandwich spots I've ever been too!! The quality of the bread, meats and cheese is superb. I've had a variety of the sandwiches on the menu. They are all so good I prefer the warm sandwiches. Great soda and chip choices too. Get here early!! The line gets out the door. I don't go to the city often anymore well... because it sucks now BUT I will make my way there for one of these sandwiches!!!!!!!
author: Natasha E.

description:
Love their salad and sandwiches. Price wise, Deli Board's items are not that cheap but it's definitely worth the price. 

They change their menu often and every sandwich I have tried so far has been amazing. I like when they mix several types of meat into one sandwich. My favorite meat from them is probably the Romanian pastrami. It's super juicy and flavorful. Also, whatever sandwich I order, I like to use the Dutch Crunch as my bread option. It's crunchiness forms a texture contrast with the tender juicy ingredients sandwiched in between.

Sometime I also order their salad. Everything is really fresh and I really like their mustard balsamic. It's those kinda dressing that goes with almost every type of salad you order.
author: Clare L.

description:
Wait - Long lines around lunch time.

Value - $17 / dish. Great value.

Dish Size: Large. 

Boca - This is an amazing sandwich. The flavors of all the meat are distinct and flavorful. What I enjoyed most is the way the meat was sliced. It's sliced paper thin that the meat fold on itself to create a wavy texture which adds another sensation when eating. 

Leroy Brown - This sandwich has it all - salty, sweet, tangy, and spicy. As mentioned previously, the meat is sliced in similar manner which adds another dimension. On top of that, the Dutch Crunch roll adds the crunchy texture which is perfect complement to the tender meat. 

Pickles - Each of the sandwiches are served with a side of deli style pickles. They are a perfect palate cleanser when all that meat from the sandwich becomes a bit overwhelming. 


Deli Board is like the Rolls Royce of sandwiches. Everything from the meat, bread, cheese, and vegetables taste of luxury. You would think with such great tasting ingredients the portions would be small, but, Deli Board packs a mountain of food in-between two slices of bread. I would even say half of the sandwich would be enough for lunch. 

If you plan on arriving around lunch time, be aware that Deli Board's line is consistently out the door. Don't be surprised waiting in line 10-20 minutes before placing your order. Upon arriving, the most noticeable thing will be, the ever changing menu hanging on the wall. The menu is extensive, however, the wait in line will give you plenty of time to read it over. 

The space is small and sparse. There's not much seating inside and there's only a couple tables right outside on the sidewalk. If you plan on eating in, be prepared to wait again for seats to open up. I can't wait for Deli Board to move to a larger space and revamp their interior to be equal to the quality of their sandwiches.
author: Julian L.

description:
3.5 stars for the sandwich, rounded down to 3 for the absurd price.

We had one of the specials (perhaps the Alice?) - pastrami, roast beef, 1000 island, peppers, meunster. While it was a good sandwich, I can't even say it was a GREAT sandwich. I got this specifically because I wanted the cherry peppers, and that flavor didn't really come through. I also think it's says a lot when myself and another in our party kept going back to the hot sauce. I don't need hot sauce on everything, but it's one of those things where I slap it onto something okay just to amp up my palate a bit.

Perhaps I'd have a different opinion if this sandwich cost $14, $12 instead of $17. That is absolutely ridiculous for one sandwich, and it's not humongous either - sure, enough for a meal for your average male, but as a small female I could totally eat one (and be very full). The pickles - though large and juicy - were also just mediocre, not particularly crunchy and a little on the mushy end.

I'm not sure why this place gets all the hype. I think some people respond to a high price point and shift their perception of the meal more favorably. I'll admit I fall in the opposite camp. If you're going to rip me off you've REALLY got to impress me, and Deli Board just underwhelmed.
author: Clarice W.

description:
Arrived sometime around 12:20 and there was a line that went out the door (granted the shop isn't that big). The first thing that stuck out to me is the prices of the sandwiches (average $16-17). The inside is pretty lively so be prepared to speak up. There are a great variety of choices to go with and there is also a make your own option. 

I chose the 555 and after about ~10 minute wait the sandwich came out HOT. I mean steam was coming off of it. The sandwich itself was pretty tasty and sizeable. Good mix of meat and assorted ingredients and not too overpowered in one flavor direction (ie. that meat sub that is salty AF). 

I probably wouldn't come here on a super regular basis just because of the price, but there is definitely nothing to complain about with the sandwiches.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I completely agree with Nick K. 

This was his review:

"Never had I ever paid $18 for a deli sandwich. Now I have and it's not worth it. With sandwich prices ranging from $16-20, you expect it to be heavenly. Unfortunately it tastes more like a $10 sandwich. The pickle was good, though.

Vegetarians be warned: there is only one sans meat option on the menu."

I'd add that it's in a very off the beaten path location.  And the staff is very friendly.
author: Jane D.

description:
So the hype is real and the sandwich is 5-stars easy. But (and this is a big one) I am adamantly opposed to spending $17 on a sandwich. I had no clue the price when I told my coworker to pick me up a sandwich. In fact I did not believe him so I looked at the menu and guess what a regular turkey sandwich is $15+ with any additions. 

I get it, this is San Francisco and everywhere is crazy expensive and it's crazy expensive to live here ( I hope they are paying a living wage). This does seem a little bit crazy though and I just can't bring myself to pull that trigger again.

tl/dr: Amazing sandwich w/ stupid expensive prices, I don't think it's even close to being worth it.
author: Chris R.

description: The best place on earth! Not only is the food amazing but the service is awesome! Its defiantly my go to place for lunch or dinner. you have to at least try it and then you will be hooked.
author: Mace M.

description:
Delicious & Indulgent is how to describe these sandwiches!  
There are lots of rich combinations for sandwiches and you can get a free pickle on the side. It takes a while to make, about 5/10 minutes. The price is a little steep (around $12 to $17) but the sandwiches are huge! The flavors are unbelievable too. The food is defiantly very meat-heavy so if that's not your thing, this might not be the best place for you.
The location of the shop isn't the nicest though and doesn't look like much on the outside. However the workers and shop are nice and very laid back.
author: Ece K.

description:
Wow! Heard this was the best sandwich place in SF, they weren't lying!
Had the JJ, looked at the menu ahead of time, the main selling point was it was on a garlic bun. The sandwich was piping hot, meats and cheeses were very fresh and the garlic roll was crisp and tasty.
Deli Board was started by a Cleveland native (that's why it is so good) and features Cleveland's famous Stadium Mustard.
Kudos to the staff who offered me some clean towels to dry off with after I got caught in a downpour on the way there, they were great!
author: Drew F.

description: Best sandwiches ever! Well at least one of the best sandwich places in SF. Honestly you can't go wrong, the sandwiches are so delicious and so filling you keep coming back for more. Definitely a top list place to visit if you want great sandwiches.
author: Roman L.

description: Good sandwiches. Got the carzle with Dutch crunch instead of French roll and added lettuce to give it a different texture. Love the pastrami and brisket. It's a bit pricey for a sandwich, about 19 after taxes, but it was good!  Lines might seem long, but they're pretty smooth with ordering and serving.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Yum! The sandwiches are really good here. I got the TINA sandwich and it was great. A lot of shredded, soft, moist turkey, coleslaw, board sauce (??), peppers, and some other things. Comes with some pickles. And came out warm. It was $16.

Yes, $16 is a lot for a sandwich but you get a ton of food. None of us were able to finish our entire sandwich. Subway is down the street if you're looking for a cheap lunch.

The waffle fries are delicious and the mayo / relish sauce was so good.
author: T L.

description:
Sweet mother of mary, what a sandwich! For those of you who haven't experienced a Deli Board sandwich, it's time to make the trek. Just an FYI, you have to go to the location to order as they aren't on any delivery services or not do they take phone orders. 

Normally I'd order any of the sandwiches that are on the menu but, was feeling like a healthier sandwich when I went earlier this week. I opted to build my own sandwich and boy did I nail it. Disclaimer: any sandwich you build here will be delicious. Anyway, my sandwich consisted of turkey, all the veggies, cheddar and the house made bomb balsamic dressing. The result, a massively delicious sandwich that hit the spot! Everything about the quality of ingredients is top notch and it shows. 

That being said, it's expensive. How expensive you ask? Well, just shy of $20 bucks for the sandwich. Worth it, yep. 

Moral of the story. If you're down to throw some coin at one of the best Santos in town, this is a can't miss.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Wow. Just wow.

Ok, I admit it's pricey. But on food quality alone, this is worth it. Perhaps its because its pricey yet served with no frills that people complain? But there's plenty of restaurants that charge more with far lesser fare just because they offer an "experience".

Came here on a weekday for lunch with co-workers. I'm from out of town, so usually I trust the judgement of the locals. Lots of times it bites me because they aren't foodies. Luckily, this time it didn't, as they suggested Deli Board. Description: "the best sandwich. a heart attack sandwich. a super expensive sandwich". This description is 100% accurate.

Walking up at around 12:45 pm, there was a fairly short line (read: it didn't extend outside the door). We were not only able to order, but we were also able to snag a 4 person table! Apparently, for one of my co-workers, it was the first time in his 2 years visiting this location that he was able to sit inside. What can I say, I'm a good luck charm :)

For food, I got the Carzle based off recommendation. It was. So. Good. The brisket was perfectly tender and just melted in my mouth (I never thought I'd describe meat this way, but I am). Would recommend, although I'm sure all the other options are just as delicious as well. To drink, I got a bottled water, which was free as they don't offer tap.

Right after we sat down, the line got super long and extended past the entrance. As soon as we stood up to leave, our table was instantly snagged. Needless to say, people know good food when they see it. Even at ~$16 a sandwich, you feel like you're getting a deal... The quality is that good.
author: Angela C.

description:
My favorite sandwich shop in SF - So much meat, cripsy yet soft bread, and the best pickles! Service is always great, and I appreciate their hot sauce selection.

Warning: Food is heavy and you may need a nap after eating.
author: Michelle B.

description: Do you know who is in the back of this location making your sandwiches?????? God. God is in the back making your sandwiches. These sandwiches blew my mind through a black hole and into another galaxy. These sandwiches deserve to be framed and put in a museum. They are legendary. Eat at Deli Board. Shut up and take my bitcoin.
author: Neema F.

description: BEST SANDWICH SHOP EVER. Eating the food here is a heavenly experience that everyone should have when they are in the San Francisco.
author: Davis T.

description: Sigh... Deli Board has become one of those places that used to be great but is becoming sloppy while raising prices.  Recently I had a $17 sandwich that was way too salty.  I could have probably forgiven the overwhelming saltiness if the sandwich was $13-14.  Or I could've forgiven the price tag if the sandwich was large enough for two meals.  But neither was true and moreover they ran out of the habanero hot sauce.  Unfortunately I just don't see myself returning!
author: Beatrice W.

description:
The only complaint is the price point. $17 for a sandwich is a lot (but I would pay it in a traditional restaurant I suppose).

But clearly the ingredients and care to make the perfect sandwich here is a priority.  I needed to go for jury duty and thought this would be a great way to break up the day. I thought for the price point it would be huge and I would need to take 1/2 home (so I brought a baggie, and asked then to wrap both halves separately).  

Well what do ya know? - I easily polished off the Bradley (subbed cherry peppers for jalapenos).

SO SO SO good, and Adam is right there making sure everything is perfect - even changing out the records on the record player. So funny I was not sure it was him because I remember him heavier, so I looked him up on the web and sure enough - he has lost a tons of weight  not quite sure how he does it being around all the deliciousness. Counter gals also super sweet.

Oh - and they sell branded SOCKS - super funny - I got a pair for my nephew.

He is opening up a new place in 2018 closer to the Fidi (1077 Mission), WHOOPEE Article here:
https://sf.eater.com/2017/10/23/16512232/deli-board-expansion-soma-mid-market-sandwiches
author: Amy W.

description:
tldr; Food was solid, service was solid, and restaurant was solid. If you don't mind a long wait and have some of that good SF tech money in your pocket, ignore my two cents and go for it! :)

I'll start with what's most important--the sandwich! It was pretty good. I got the Gold-n-Berg-n-Stein (corned beef, pastrami, salami, cole slaw, muenster cheese, 1000 island, french roll). You can tell all of the ingredients were good quality. 

The workers were really nice and I thought the restaurant (which is on the very small side) had a great vibe. Everyone looked happy to be there. 

With those positives aside, two negatives really left a strong impression on me. 

The first being time: 40min wait for a sandwich is nuts--the line was out the door leading to the sidewalk. By the time I got my food, my lunch break was over and I had to save it until after work. It's probably 1/2 my fault for coming in at noon on a workday, but when else should I go?

The second being price: My sandwich was $17. With chips and tax, it was about $22. Now, I saw the prices before I went, but I thought, "Hey, maybe the sandwiches are huge." (The pictures certainly make it seem that way) But in reality, the sandwich was a normal size, similar to a 6" sub at Subway (comparable only in size, not quality!) 

I cannot see myself ever coming back because of price alone, but that, combined with long wait time, kind of seals it for me: I'm not seriously considering Deli Board an lunch option again.
author: Josh M.

description: This place was defining disappointing for having 4.5 stars. I simply expected more for the price. Sandwich was $20 and just didn't seem worth it. Overall good atmosphere and great costumer service.
author: Tina R.

description: Darn you Deli Board - can't stop thinking about the breakfast sandwich I ate here a few weeks ago. I would happily take muni with a transfer for you. And that is saying somethin'
author: Robin P.

description: Best sandwich spot in SF! Portions are huge, their soup is amazing and the fatty matty is fire
author: Rachel U.

description: Hands down the best sandwich I've ever had. Perfectly toasted with tender corned beef, brisket and Romanian pastrami. Pretty sure their pickles are made in-house as well. Delicious!
author: Thomas N.

description:
OK, so these sandwiches are NOT cheap ($14 - $16 on average), but they are SO darn good, who cares  about money!  

I ordered the 'A. Stud' to try the famed Romanian pastrami.  I should state upfront that I'm not a huge pastrami fan - I usually find it to be overly fatty, too salty, and I hate when it gets stuck in my teeth.  Deli Board's pastrami is nothing like that.  It's flavorful without being overly seasoned, relatively lean, and easy to eat - where has this pastrami been all my life?  The balance of the sando includes jalapenos (don't worry, they're not that spicy), cheddar cheese, and coleslaw.  Somehow this sandwich melted in my mouth, and in turn caused me to melt with each bite.  In fact, it was so good, I craved this sandwich for an entire week after my visit.  My only gripe is that the sole Deli Board location is way out in SoMa, in the middle of nowhere (well, it's technically in the middle of SF, but that's a formality).  Hey, at least parking is easy.  

In summary, if you have the means, and you're in the 'hood, I highly recommend picking one up!
author: Tom G.

description:
Stopped at the Deli Board today with my friend after a morning of heavy drinking and, based on the reviews, got lucky - only one person in line when we got there around 1:30pm (it blew up while we were eating). 

I ordered the Bradley and added white American cheese (which give them props right there for serving whitey. I don't like yellow American). I really enjoyed the sandwich but can't believe they charge $17.00 for it. I could easily have eaten two of them. 

To be fair, it was a business expense which is why I stayed, but if it was my dime I would have easily walked out. $17.00? It felt like going into an Italian Restaurant and seeing a sign that reads "Homemade Meatballs - $10 each." The ladies who were there today were very sweet (I tipped them) but two sandwiches, tip, a Mexican Coke and a bottle of water topped out at $47 and change. And that's waaaaaaay too much. 

If you go, you will enjoy it - if you can swallow what you paid for the sandwich as it's on its way down.
author: Jackson Z.

description: This truly is a good sandwich. The quality and flavors are definitely there. I got the boca which had the corned beef, pastrami, and brisket. I really love how they thinly shaved all the meats because it added really good texture to the sandwich. Their hot sauce is great too. It's kind of like a crystal or rooster sauce the vinegar based sauce which I love. The pickles that come with it are crunchy. The only reason I'm not giving this place a 5 star is because of the price. I'm sorry, but $16 for a sandwich is just way too much. If I am paying this much for a sandwich it better be a sandwich big enough for 2 people to split which was not really the case with these. However, almost all SF restaurants are pricey so I guess this isn't anything new. I would recommend this place if you don't mind spending a little extra for a good quality sandwich.
author: Steven K.

description:
phenomenal sandwich.  I had the carzle.  meat is legit and not too much bread.  I'm salavating now writing this.  Thanks guys.  This is awkward. 
 Where's my drool cup when I need it!
author: Brian N.

description:
This sandwich and fries needed to send me on a Segway to heaven if it was running me $28. 

It did

Almost fell asleep at my table eating the pastrami because it was that good. Never have had meat this good on a sandwich. The avocado on it was a bit underripe, but I just scooped some of it on some fries and returned to focusing on how good the sandwich was. I'm getting drowsy thinking about it again. 

Oh, speaking of fries. Deli board's waffle fries are the best I've ever had. They came with a big cup of Mac sauce like what's from McDonald's and it was the perfect combo. 

Holy cow I'm starting to budget my weekly spending on food so I can justify paying $30 every weekend on deli board. I ran after the meal to justify its cost on my gut. Would do much more if it means I can keep eating here.
author: Jon N.

description:
Been coming here once in a while for a couple years now since we live close by and it's a mistake almost every time. 
Today I spent $28 on the Julie ( do not recommend), waffle fries (good), and a root beer 

Ordered at 2:30 and didn't open it at home until 2:50 to realize they added even more sprouts after asking them to remove them completely. They close at 3. 

They've been making one vegetarian sandwich ( j ocean) which is the exact same as the Julie... so now it's called the Julie and I asked them to take off the heated sprouts (ew???) and she goes to the back and comes back to say that it's not even made with sprouts and that it has lettuce. Ok cool. Then she comes back and says they're making it with light lettuce... ok.. not what I asked for but whatever. Get home and open it and the hot sprouts smell so bad neither of us could eat it. 

Get back after paying $30 and only ate fries and a soda. 
I have never been able to get a vegetarian sandwich here WITHOUT SPROUTS NO MATTER WHO, WHEN, OR HOW YOU ASK.
author: Emma G.

description:
This is the best sandwich spot/deli in the city. Big portions. Good vibes. People mention that it's pricey but there's nowhere else in the city where you can get pastrami of this quality. Melts in your mouth. Sandwiches come out fresh, hot and stuffed to the brim. YOU CANT GO WRONG HERE but definitely go for a sandwich that has pastrami (we like the 555 which is pastrami and turkey). I'm dreaming of their sandwiches as I type this. A little tight on seating on the weekend but people seem to rotate in and out fast enough. As others have noted, it can take awhile to get your food so don't come if you're in a rush or just order ahead over the phone!

House made hot sauce is hot. But very tasty!!

Not every deli in town plays things like "cats under the stars" in the background.
author: Mai N.

description:
Oh deliboard how I love your wacky combos and fun sandwich names.. I can't say its the best sandwich ive ever had but it sure is the most expensivist!  I've eaten here a few times and tried the soups in as many times as I've been there and they've generally been.. bad.. most recently it was the tomato polenta.. great on the surface and conjuring images of a steaming bowl brimming with bisque and hearty chunks of polenta.. what I got was a thin fairly basic tomato broth in a clear platic tub with no polenta in sight.  Apparently it's in there, but that's def not a take on polenta i'd ever want. Tossed it out after a few sips. Don't get me wrong the deli meat is amazing. Fresh pastrami etc like you don't get no where else...at that price.. anywho..




This
author: Raphael P.

description:
The best sandwich I had all year!! I got the KUIP. Highly recommended!! Romanian pastrami, corned beef, kosher salami, white and yellow american cheese, cherry peppers, cole slaw, mayo,1000 island. I got it with dutch instead of the french roll. Every bite till the very last one was amazing. Sandwiches comes with a side of pickles. 

The staff was friendly and the store was roomy. I do think the sandwiches are expensive therefore it would not be a everyday meal. But so good that I wouldn't mind spoiling myself once in awhile.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Great lunch spot & the price-quality-quantity ratio is amazing! You get a super large sandwich for less than $20. You can also make your own sandwich if you don't like any of their combos.

Made fresh so it takes a while, probably the only downside to this place. We came at around 12:15pm and it took ~15min to get our food.
author: Rohenne L.

description:
Largest, girthiest, tastiest sandwiches I've ever had.  Every sando on the menu sounds sexy af. Brisket, pastrami, bacon, corned beef, chicken salad- there's something here for everyone. 

I had the Tenenbaum because it reminded me of The Royal Tenenbaums, one of my fave movies, and also because it had turkey, avocado, pepperoncini, and coleslaw. I subbed the French roll for Dutch crunch (Dutch crunch is just the GOAT).

While I could only finish half of my sando, my friends (whom I've lovingly dubbed as the couple who eats the MOST) shared 3 sandos, which is an impressive feat, given the size. I mean, they're so jam-packed with goodies that my jaw almost came unhinged when I first tried to fit it in my mouth. Then I tried compressing it with my hands and it bounced right back. Eventually, I resorted to taking alternating bites of the top half and bottom half of my sandwich. 

You get pickles on the side served in ziplocs which is not very environmentally friendly, and so surprising to see in SF when there hasn't been plastic bags at grocery stores in years. Anyway, the pickles were delicious and crunchy, but watch out for the dripping pickle juice. I accidentally got some on my jeans.

Honestly, I never thought I'd pay $16 for a sandwich, but these are worth it.
author: Karen S.

description:
I think I may be addicted to this place. I'm very particular about sandwiches, specially the ones that have a lot of meat. But this place gives you plenty of meat with tons of awesome flavors without all the unnecessary condiments that other places add. 
It is obvious that the meet is of good quality since I can eat it and not feel sluggish after.
author: Elmer I.

description: It was just ok to me. Eh.. Definitely overpriced - $18 for a sandwich? I rather go to Ike's. The one plus is probably the "free" water bottle.
author: Sandy G.

description:
Yeah, dozens and dozens of sandwiches later and this place is still the ultimate sandwich. Prices go up with inflation and are kind of crazy, but so is the sandwich.

I've eaten all around the country and nothing compares. Deliboard for life.
author: Josh S.

description: Sandwiches just aren't the same after eating here.   Only issue is the hours here aren't great.   Won't find a better sandwich though.
author: Justin S.

description:
Got the Zeke.  Turkey, avocado, bacon, sprouts, and cream cheese. Large amount of meat.  $17 is pretty steep for a sandwich though, I guess because we are in San Fran they can charge that... but I would be broke if I lived here eating this weekly.

Arrived at 1:45pm and there wasn't a line.
author: Courtney E.

description: Um yes!!!! The Ron...omg! Get here early and come hungry. A bit expensive but worth it.
author: Wendy B.

description:
I never get the chance to come here anymore. I just work a little to far away, when I do go it's more of a pilgrimage. The prices have increased since they first opened in the first location. Price and menu aside this place hasn't lost the one main thing I love, the most important thing of all. Heart and soul. This place has so much love for the sandwich game it's on a level most sandwich shops can't even understand. 

Take for instance the fatty Matty, a falafel and tuna sandwich with fresh produce. It's so solid that when you finish eating it you've discovered a new meaning to life. How about the Mikey Likes it (not on the menu anymore). This sandwich is amazing, it's a pastrami cheesesteak but I like to call it a pastrami cheesecake. It's just that good. I'm fairly sure if I was able to eat here more often it might shorten my life some, everything in moderation right. Except for the homemade pickles, those are sick!
author: Ben M.

description:
It's a tad pricey with an appetizer, sandwich and soda running you $26.  However, the deli meat is really good!  So worth the occasional indulgence.

Roll Dogs: A hot dog wrapped in an egg roll wrapper completely then deep fried with house mustard on the side for dipping sauce.  It's lighter than a corn dog and crispier than pigs in a blanket.  It's definitely novel.  I feel like for an appetizer, it should be cut into smaller pieces (before being wrapped in egg roll wrapper) to promote sharing.

Bradley: Got this one because it had the trifecta of corned beef, brisket and pastrami.  The meat is shaved super thin, like a good cheesesteak.  Though I enjoyed the texture, the 3 distinct meat types kind of merged together because of their thinness.  Probably better just to enjoy them individually.  Loved the soft and chewy roll, however it didn't taste particularly garlicky for being garlic bread (nor was it that crunchy on the garlic butter side).

Pickles: Two big chunks of pickle.  Sour, but not too sour.  Was decent.
author: Adam B.

description:
I never thought I'd enjoy a $16 sandwich but here I am. These sandwiches are loaded with meat and it's hard to choose a sandwich from their menu because their all so damn loaded and sounds delicious. I had the Boca:brisket, romanian pastrami, corned beef, muenster cheese, pickles, Board sauce, brown mustard, french roll purely because it's the first item on the list and my rule is the first item means the store's signature! 

Anyway the sandwich is delicious of course for $16 + tax, I mean it pretty much has to be to justify the price. If you don't care too much about cost then come by for sure to try. I would love to now try Katz in NY and see if there can be a comparison.

Tips: Go earlier during weekdays to beat the lunch crowd, not that much seating available inside
author: Daniel C.

description: Ridiculously good sandwiches--expensive but it's because they are packed with meat. And crazy good matzo ball soup here, which is perfect for chilly SF days. Best music played from vinyls. Peeps are from Cleveland and proud of it!
author: Alias A.

description:
I've had Deli Board bookmarked for a long time, but I finally made it out there today. 

I arrived shortly after they opened so there wasn't a line and I ordered the Carzle (pastrami, brisket, provolone, coleslaw, cherry peppers, and board sauce on a garlic french roll) to go. The sandwich was really tasty and I liked the spice of the cherry peppers with the salty, fatty meat and the bread stood up even with a commute back home. 

I knew going in that the sandwiches are on the pricier side so I was prepared, but from the pictures I thought they would be bigger. Overall, I'd love to come back because it was delicious, but I don't think I can justify a $17 sandwich. I definitely think it is overpriced even for San Francisco. I'd give them a 5 for taste, but I have to dock a couple stars for price.
author: Annaliese D.

description:
I'm seriously wondering.... did I eat at the same place as all of these other reviewers?? I really wanted to like this place but was disappointed. 

I stopped by Deli Board after a long morning of jury duty and was expecting to be wowed. Turns out I have never been so unsatisfied with a sandwich ever. My bf ordered the one w/ pastrami/brisket (maybe the Hermine or Carzle idk) and I had the one with turkey and avocado. I can't even remember the names because that's how unmemorable they were. They're pretty much stuffed with meat and have almost no veggies which makes for a very bland and underwhelming sandwich IMO. Not to mention, these sandwiches are TINY little things for over $40 for two! 

I seriously don't see what all the hype is about. Ike's, Lou's Cafe, Little Lucca's, and even Mr. Pickle's is far better in terms of quality/portion/pricing. Meh.
author: Marny N.

description:
I dropped by the Deli Board based solely on its proximity to my hotel, and a need for a quick and efficient lunch.  I wasn't expecting to be blown away.  But I was.

The "Fay" sandwich (turkey, avocado, Swiss cheese, cherry peppers, cole slaw, mayo, and some kind of secret sauce, all on a Dutch Crunch roll) was one of the best sandwiches I've ever had.  Warm, rich, filling, delicious -- and not greasy at all.  I also loved the fresh, house-made pickles on the side.

The Deli Board provides bottled water *for free*.  I can't think of a single deli anywhere that provides that kind of white-glove service.  

Also: The folks who run the Deli Board are among the nicest people in SF.  They're all smiles, making sure I was perfectly taken care of even though I was just some rando in town on business.

Bravo, Deli Board.... I heart you.  I heart you very much.
author: David G.

description:
I travel a lot and my brother and I are sandwich aficionados. This place is right at the top of the list. Everything I have had here is amazing they have the exact mix of thinly sliced meat and soft melt in your mouth bread. 
I am seeing more than a few reviews from people saying its too expensive. I wonder if these are the same SF hipsters that also pay 8 times more than what they should for an undersized apartment. This product is amazing and totally worth the cost.
author: Jared H.

description:
I had been dying to try this place for the longest time, just waiting for the chance to be in the area, so I had already set my expectations very high. A small, clean joint that where you order at the front, find a seat yourself, and they bring the goods to you.

FOOD:
I shared the Carzle and the Ruby Claire. The Ruby Claire: pastrami, thinly sliced to be fluffy that fell apart easily. Good flavor on its own. Corned beef, pretty much the same idea. All really good meat. A classic Reuben-ish sandwich with the sauerkraut giving it that extra kick. Bread nice and making this one of the easiest sandwiches to actually eat. I do wish it had more thousand island dressing, but can't complain too much.

I honestly preferred the Carzle. Brisket and pastrami has the same meat deal. Thinly sliced and delicious. I love me some provolone on a sandwich and their board sauce added well to these flavors. Despite this, it was the cherry peppers that really made this sandwich for me. A bit of spiciness with the pickled flavor really went a long way into elevating this sandwich, which makes me think that I should've gotten the KUIP. Next time.

They also serve some full pickles with each sandwich that comes in a ziplock bag. A welcome addition to any sandwich. Well done. I'll be back.
author: Bryant C.

description:
Read lots about Ike's before we visited but the pictures of these sandwiches were not to be ignored. Stopped in after a morning at the beach. Friendly cashier and available seating. Talked a bit with someone who may have been the owner or manager who sitting with customers. Very friendly. He said the sandwiches would blow our minds and he was not joking. 
Just AMAZING sandwiches!! A must try.
author: Emily P.

description: Wow. Just wow. I know it's not cheap, but it's worth it. From the breakfast sandwiches on Saturdays to EVERY sandwich I've had for lunch, it's just the best. The staff is nice, funny, and personable. Sandwiches are great. Pickles are very tasty. You can't go wrong at Deli Board.
author: Sean T.

description:
Deli Board doesn't skimp when it comes to portions for any of their dishes. 

Their Samurai salad was huge. I loved the heart of palm intermingled with romaine lettuce, cubed chicken, carrots, red and green peppers, tomatoes, and cucumber. It was a simple and basic looking salad - but also one of the most satisfying that I've had in awhile. The ginger dressing was perfectly tangy and I finished the large salad in one sitting - savoring each bite.

Sometimes straightforward food can be the most memorable.

For outstanding take-away sandwiches and salads made with love and wholesome ingredients check out Deli Board.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: The sandwiches are good, but $20 good? No I'm sorry. I gave it three stars because the sandwich tasted good. I just can't get over the price. Overrated.
author: Denise R.

description:
Welp, nearly $19 for a sandwich after tax and tip. No chips, no drink.

At that price it better be one of the best damn sandwiches I've ever eaten. Was it? 

Yep. 

Still can only stomach 4 stars though, since I now need to take out a second mortgage on my condo.
author: Rocco B.

description:
Gah... Deli Board may be one of my favorite sandwich spots in SF! I've been meaning to try this place for awhile now, especially since I'm walking distance from this place. 

What I love about Deli Board is the sandwiches are flavorful and they're generous with the ingredients! I dislike places where half or the majority of the sandwich is just bread and saucy... 

I highly recommend the Mezman! It has a nice spicy kick from the peppers and I especially love the garlic dutch crunch roll. In fact, it has pieces of garlic on the bread! It was yummy on its own. 

It was so hard not to eat the whole sandwich so I wouldn't fall into a deep food coma, but I managed to save a quarter of it for a snack later on. The sandwich is super filling and I almost could have gone without dinner that day.

Seating is a bit limited, so you have to be a hawk and wait for one as they open up!
author: Janet H.

description:
If I was to ever jump on a plane to grab a sandwich half way across the country, this place would be it.  
If this place is ever franchised, I'm in, I'll buy five.  Yep, I love these very tasty creative sandwiches that much.  Try them all, I haven't yet, but I'm working on it.
author: Rob M.

description: Deli Board was good. I got the Carzle. The sandwich had great meat and some of my favorite type of bread. My only criticism is that the sandwich was missing a good fresh crunch to counteract the meat overload. The coleslaw was a good crunch but I needed a larger ratio. Ok - one other criticism was price. I could see paying $11-12 for this sandwich but $17 was steep when it doesn't come with chips or drink at that price.
author: Been B.

description: I had high expectations for this place. The sandwiches are OKAY!!! I probably would not come back. There's better sandwich spots in the Bay Area and cost half the price. 40 dollars for 2 sandwiches?!?! That's outrageous. I don't think sandwiches should be priced that much; unless it comes with an alcoholic beverage. Additionally, the owner was there and didn't even seem welcoming or social. You can at least say "Welcome". He stood there and stared blankly at the customers. You may not need our money, but having a good reputation with your customers is a MUST!!! Especially if you want people to RECOMMEND your establishment. FRANKLY, I don't think this place is worth the drive and the time. There are other places that have better tasting sandwiches that are half the price. $40 dollars NOT well spent.
author: rae m.

description:
I see a lot of reviews that this is the best sandwich place, as though no other combination of meat/veggies/cheese between two pieces of bread can top this. 

I beg to differ. This sandwich place is OK. If delivering a warm sandwich, as promised, makes this a 5-star place, then standards must be low. 

The place itself is nice and very hipster. The service is polite, expedient, and friendly (despite a long line). The hours are a little weird, making this really a lunch place more so than anything else. 

Now onto the food. The sandwich is indeed good, and the portion size of the sandwich delivers. The Turkey sandwich (The Fey) was tasty, meaty, and will make a person full. The meat itself was good, but did not have any particular flavor notes, taste or texture, that would otherwise indicate that this is more than just an average turkey sandwich. The veggie sandwich was also good, but didn't quite hit the spot. 

The place is very meat-focused, and offers a lot of beef options (for those who don't eat beef, you aren't left with a ton of pre-designed items). That said, you can always make your own custom sandwich.

We spent about $16/sandwich (and the veggie one is $14!!!) these prices are absurd, even for SF. In fact, my friend who ordered the veggie sandwich said she felt like she had to split the sandwich into 4 portions, to eat throughout the day, so that she could justify the $14 spend on veggies.

Given the price, I'd expect complete and utter satisfaction between two pieces of bread. Sadly, the sandwich was just average. Nothing special, and I've had better (and cheaper) sandwiches elsewhere. Hell, even Ike's (a to-go sandwich place) gives you a better price to taste ratio (in my opinion). People may say "the taste of the sandwich is different than the price", and they may be right. However, a Yelp-rating, to me, is far more comprehensive. 

If people are in this part of town, looking for something good to eat, that is filling and won't bust your wallet. I highly recommend Frena/Taboon a block-ish up from Deli Board. 

Overall, I'd say this is a good once and done type sandwich place. Fun to try, but nowhere near the value it should be.
author: Aditya Y.

description:
I don't always go to SOMA on Sunday's, but when I do it's for a Deli Board sando. Best enjoyed at the seedy park across the street.

I've never ordered anything off the menu that I haven't liked here. Sometimes with food looks can be deceiving, but that certainly isn't the case here.

Dinging this place one star for value (sandwiches are $$$ but I'm willing to pay for something that delicious) and the fact that they only let you order so many sandwiches at a time. I tried to order for a group at work once and we had to have two people call in separately to order the number we needed.
author: Christine M.

description:
If you want pastrami and all the rest DB is great.
I visited and was recommended to me and worth the wait. Try with cheese and slaw, you won't be disappointed. A sandwich can really hit the spot and you need a place in every town. great to meet and great to sit and wait. You won't go wrong here, haven't been for a while but timeless.
author: Ryan S.

description:
#37/2016

They lose a star because they're really expensive. $16 (including tip) for a Cobb salad -no avocado by the way- is too much. 

Overall the salad was good: the ingredients were fresh and I enjoyed the few honeydew melon slices in my Cobb salad; it was a refreshing note.

The chicken was cubed, not in slices, so they're really cleaning up on a salad that's a little bit of chicken, a rasher of chopped bacon, a small amount of halved, tiny grape tomatoes, a few Bleu cheese crumbles, some melon - and lots of romaine.

I'd walked in because I'd only had a green drink that morning and the staff at SFIEC Paul Mitchell sent me there when I said I wanted a salad rather than a slice of Extreme Pizza (located next door). 

They warned me it was expensive. It is.

They had no soup and when I asked why she said "it was too hot" (it was about 68 degrees yesterday, hardly a scorcher.)

Trying to be simpatico, I suggested "maybe gazpacho or vichyssoise?" I got scoffed at. She explained "soup wasn't a big seller especially when there's a line out the door."

[I'm sensing the staff doesn't want to be "put out" ladling soup into a container because it's so "time consuming", whatever.]

Her attitude made me sorry I suggested so I added provocatively,

"Well, MY soups would sell. Maybe I should give you a couple recipes?"

[silence]

Yeah, I thought so. Well now I'd never give them to you anyway- "no soup FOR YOU!"

Cool space, a few tables to chill and with a paucity of lunch spots in the area, these folks have a captive audience.

Their slightly snotty attitude (1/2 star demerit) and high prices show they're capitalizing on that.

Decent food, sandwiches looked good, they might skip making soup for the day if it's too warm (68 degrees for Pete's sake) and it'll be expensive.

Manage yer expectations.
author: Jennifer O.

description: I had the Carzle which is the best pastrami sandwich I have eaten till date. It's super delicious and will make you guilty for the whole day. I would say, skip the breakfast and have this sandwich for lunch!
author: Ash M.

description: The carlze is truly incredible, which is probably the case for every sandwich they serve. Great breads, high quality meats, friendly staff.
author: S K F.

description:
killer sammich. grab the A Stud if you love pastrami. the most delicious pastrami. price upwards of $15+.
(review's been sitting in my Review Draft for a few years now )
author: Sha A.

description: This place is by far my absolute favorite sandwich spot ever! Whenever someone asks about a lunch spot I recommend this place. The only reason I give it a 4/5 is over the last year or so I've seen a dwindle in the quantity of sandwich here. Or maybe it was just a miss while Adam was out one weekend but if I'm paying close to 20$ a sandwich I want to feel like I never need another meal after eating of these amazing sandos.
author: Kimberly J.

description: Definitely an elevated sandwich experience. Anything with pastrami is a win. This is my go to, when I want to treat myself.
author: Nate T.

description:
Five stars for five reasons:
* Huge amount of meat in the sandwich
* Every ingredient was perfect unto itself - the meat (corned beef and pastrami), the additions (cole slaw, sauerkraut), the sauces (Board sauce and the perfectly spiced brown mustard) and the bread (soft on inside, crunchy on outside)
* Flavors blended perfectly together
* Warm and welcoming staff
* Free bottled water
*Bonus: snagged 1 of 2 outdoor tables on a gorgeous SF Saturday
author: Francesca A.

description: Downgrading this 1-star as their prices have increased pretty drastically since I first started going to Deli Board.   Now you can expect $25-$30 a person for sandwich, chips and drink.  It's still delicious, however pricing has made me go less often these days.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
My girlfriend and I were in the city after her hair appt; we checked around and this place had good ratings.

The lineup was backed up outside on the sidewalk (always a good indicator). Not a very large place - but it was packed.
And lots of local atmosphere inside, which we loved. Props to the turntable setup with a nice collection of vinyl. Johnny Cash ... oh yeah.

We shared a turkey sandwich together outside on one of the patio tables, along with an old-school bottle of Coke. The sandwich was delicious. Made just right, and we left not feeling stuffed and ready for a nap in the car before we headed back to San Jose.

Highly recommended.
author: Dave A.

description:
For any fellow Chicagoans, or others who have experienced the tastebud heaven that is Potbelly, this place will make you very, very happy.

My friend and I did two "make it basic" sandwiches, which is the build-your-own option, one with turkey and the other a turkey/bacon/avocado. Both were on wheat with a crazy amount of toppings.

What brought me home (to Potbelly) was the pepperoncini blend. My favorite sandwich there is very similar - from the turkey down to the brown mustard - and this was the first sandwich I've ever had that tasted just like it. (Can you tell I'm obsessed with Potbelly?)

Super pricey, but the sandwich can last you two meals. I will absolutely, definitely, positively be back. Phenomenal! Thanks for giving me a slice of home.
author: Nic Z.

description: Amazing quality sandwiches. I didn't try the pastrami but can attest to the turkey being delicious. The location was a little bit crowded and we had to wait for our sandwiches for a bit but absolutely worth the wait.
author: Grace A.

description: Oh my!!  The Sandwiches are scrumptious!!  John was wonderful and talked with us while he made our sandwiches special to order! He gave us a history lesson about the area and was so nice & pleasant!  We will definitely be back when we vusit SF and already told some people to go there!!
author: Denice B.

description:
For about $14-$16 a pop for a pretty normal-sized sandwich on a long roll, I was pretty underwhelmed with the portion size. However, my eyes just lit up when I looked at the masterpiece of fillings on the inside when I took the sandwiches out of the bag and unwrapped them.

Both of the sandwiches were phenomenal as I split the two with a friend so we each had a half of the $$ and Carzle. I preferred the $$ as I'm not the hugest fan of the Carzle, which contains some slaw, along with pastrami, brisket, provolone cheese, cherry peppers, and board sauce on a garlic french roll. 

The sandwiches can take a while to come out, especially if you go during prime lunch hours, and there was a bit of a line at this time as well (about 15 people deep). But once they come out and oyu take a bite into it, it is definitely well worth it! I wouldn't go out of my way to try Deli Board out, but you really can't go wrong with the quality of ingredients that go into the sandwiches here. Essentially a higher-quality deli sandwich, which is A-OK with me every once in a while.
author: Matthew L.

description: I wish I lived or worked closer to here because the sandwich was great! I had the Leroy Brown which was 3 different kinds of meat, 2 different kinds of cheese, some veggies, and dressing all stacked high on a Dutch crunch roll and toasted. The meat was piping hot, the cheese was gooey, and the sandwich was filled with toppings. Definitely a lot of food! The chunks of pickles that came on the side were also great and classic, semi-sour deli pickles. The prices are a bit higher than your typical hole-in-the-wall sandwich joint, but the quality of the ingredients and the size of the sandwich definitely made it worth the price! The menu has a pretty big variety of sandwiches on it so I'll definitely have to come back and try more of them.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
I got the Cobb salad and it was excellent. The food was great for all in my party. Would definitely come back. A few things that could have been improved upon: 

1) If I'm dining in (which I was) give me a real bowl and a real fork. At a bare minimum a real fork. Eating a salad with a plastic fork is infuriating. This tells me you don't eat your own dog food. Buying and washing 50 forks a day is easy, cheap and less waste.

2) Don't bury your dressings in the bottom of my salad bowl. Mix that shit in. I'm eating in, for $20 present this shit to me. 

All in all very good, aside from these 2 things.

May also be a good idea to stain/seal your tables as they seem hard to wipe/clean currently.
author: Lance E.

description: $18 for a decent sandwich. Nothing mind blowing. This is a $10 sandwich at best. Tried the Leroy Brown (too salty) and the $$$ (great flavor)
author: Ben S.

description:
Our team went here for lunch last Friday. There was a line out the door but it was worth the wait. The sandwiches are packed with fillings and my Jezerski was served warm. Everyone in the group raved about how tasty their order was and most could not finish the 2nd half. The service is fast once you order. 
The only draw back it the price. $17 is a lot for a sandwich. That said, it was so good I will return again soon.
author: Denise M.

description:
Really, really good sandwich shop.

I came here for lunch during the afternoon and was surprised by how many people were there for lunch hour. Luckily, the wait in line wasn't that bad and neither was the wait for my food. 

I ordered the Fay and it was delicious and very filling. I ate half and gave the other half to my boyfriend. We were happy and satisfied.

Not a lot of seating inside but I was able to get a table. 

Friendly service and would recommend!
author: Cindy B.

description: I loved it great food excellent service. The dill pickles are wonderful and the Pastrami was perfect. Get there before12pm if you want avoid a line out the door. But to be clear the food is worth the wait.
author: E.C. B.

description: This place is perfect for a quick bite! Everything was really fresh. Staff was friendly. A little on the expensive side and a limited seating space.
author: Steven J.

description: A little pricey but damn worth it. Best sandwich I ever had. Definitely a must try. The $$$ and the Carzle are orgasmic.
author: Hui L.

description: The hype is real! Waited in line for a Boca last week and was not disappointed. The meats are sliced paper thin and layered onto the sandwich for an amazing meat-packed but not chewy, melt-in-your-mouth bite. The only down side is the price - it's expensive even for SF, and a little more than I feel comfortable paying for bread and sliced meat (even meat THIS good). Definitely worth the occasional splurge!
author: Nerri Y.

description:
I love Deli Board. I shamelessly leave work early to grab Deli Board for dinner before it closes (shh)... I sing songs about Deli Board... I annoy my friends by recommending too often to eat at Deli Board.

It's whatever, I'll get new friends.

**They have daily specials, so check the board! Expect long lines, but expect it to be worth the bomb-ass sandwich you'll soon be oh-my-gaww-ing over. 

**If you're looking for turkey and avocado... the ZEKE (+ bacon, cream cheese, pickled onions, sprouts, mayo, on a French roll) or the FAY (+ Swiss cheese, cherry peppers, coleslaw, board sauce, mayo, on a garlic Dutch crunch) Can't go wrong with either. 

**(Board sauce is kinda like a spicy Russian dressing)

**Try the MEZMAN if you're looking for something different! Juicy Romanian pastrami, deviled egg salad, muenster cheese, cherry peppers, pickles, Board sauce, on a garlic dutch crunch! I thought it would be way too heavy, but it wasn't! Though it is very filling, it didn't leave me feeling incapacitated... Super nommy!

**THE THICK, JUICY BOARD PICKLES ARE AMAZING. They're always happy to give you extra :) 

**Also awesome is the Stadium Mustard that they carry, their hot sauces, and that they have Dirty Chips! Yay! They also have some bombbbb daily soups as well.
author: Ashley S.

description: Its not cheap, nor convenient for me to visit (as I'm rarely downtown), and its certainly not healthy. That's everything I could say about this place that isn't phenomenal. The service is a very friendly. And the food: wow. I got a sandwich with pastrami and corned beef on it and it was incredible. Incredible. The pastrami was both crispy and juicy. I'll repeat that again: crispy and juicy pastrami. Most places you get pastrami its not made in house and its neither. Not here. The sandwich also had coleslaw on it. I've gotten sandwiches with coleslaw before, where it just didn't go right, but you can tell this coleslaw was made to perfectly pair in the sandwich. You can tell a lot of care goes into this food. If you've never been here before, you need to go. Your life is incomplete.
author: Michael K.

description: Delicious sandwich . Ordered the cheesesteak special. Flavors were great, size was average-to-small. -1 star for the price...even for SF ($15-$20).
author: Clay S.

description:
