Five of us came here for lunch recently.  The sandwiches were all tremendous.  Why only 3 stars?  The prices were high even by SF standards ... and not because the sandwiches were huge, either.  Average price in our group was about 16 bucks for a sandwich.

But it doesn't seem to be impeding their business,  Plenty of people before and after us at lunch time.  If you don't mind the prices, then it's definitely worth a try.  Lots of great meat choices, like pastrami and corned beef and brisket, in addition to turkey and tuna etc.  They even have egg salad.
author: Lewis C.

description:
ANNOYED. Made my own sandwich to take to go. (turkey, cheese, lettuce, avo, board sauce).  By the time I got to my destination ( Twin Peaks) , realized my sandwich had Bacon on it. What? I didnt even say Bacon so why is it on there? The Cashier was stoned out of his mind as I saw him and a co worker eat an edible candy while taking my order. WHAT HELL? PAY ATTENTION !!!!!! My friend prevented me from calling them and bitching them out but I will definitely be contacting them directly. At $16 a sandwich, it better be right.

UPDATE: Got a full refund, so +1 Star. Thank you :)
author: Sarra E.

description:
Hands down my favorite sandwich place in all of the west coast. I do love my Jewish deli Sauls in Berkeley but nothing beats this Cleveland natives sandwiches. 

My personal favorite is the Zeke. French roll stuffed with turkey, cream cheese, avocado,  and sprouts. Mother of Satan. It's amazing. 

Great location, always busy, and the staff is wonderful. Go here. Eat here. I shouldn't have to tell you this. You won't be disappointed!
author: Colleen S.

description: There was one of the best falafel sandwiches I have eaten. Just a little on the pricey side and has limited seating.
author: Gael L.

description: Well I was extremely unimpressed by what some call "the best sandwich spot in SF". Came here before a Giants game for a little lunch and I was eager to give this a try. We decided to order the "Zeke" sandwich. This had turkey, sprouts, cream cheese, avocado, bacon, and pickled onion on a French roll. It sounds delicious right? Well it was 80% meat, 5% veggie, and 15% bread. I felt like I could have easily made a better sandwich at home that didn't cost THIRTEEN dollars from a glorified supermarket deli. I'm truly sorry I don't have better things to say, maybe if someone I knows ever goes and gets a good sandwich I would try them out again.. until then byeeeeeee Deli Board you will not be missed.
author: Emily B.

description:
This is some straight san francisco shiz right here. $16 for a sandwich?! Only in San Francisco would that price fly. Was it delicious? Hell yes! Would i pay it again? Maybe...if I was feelin' like a baller.
We got the Boca and the combo of meats came together perfectly. It was a meat-centric sandwich with no produce, but oddly not too heavy. I'm glad the folks recommended it as I would not have chosen it. My go to is sandwiches, and I have an appreciation for all types, and this one is up there, but I just can't get past the price.
If price is not a consideration for you, I cannot recommend this place enough!
author: Rachael R.

description: Finally checked this place out!! The employees were super nice and sandwiches were awesome. Wish they were a tad cheaper, but they're still great.
author: Brielle W.

description: I've always loved sandwich places that set themselves apart from the rest. Deli board does just that! They're a little pricey, but you get what you pay for. You can taste the quality in every bite (literally). I've tried the Zeke and the Carzle, both were amazing!
author: Caiti V.

description:
If you ask a bunch of SF residents where to get the best sandwiches, the plurality will say Ike's. 

Don't listen to them. 

Head to Deli Board to get the best sandwiches in the City. Get the Stone.R: turkey, pastrami, provolone, cole slaw, cherry peppers, pickles, 1000 island, french roll. 

The owner of this place knows sandwiches, having grown up out East where there is a strong sandwich culture thanks to a stronger history of Jewish delis and the like. But he adds characteristic West Coast creativity in his flavors and ingredient combinations. 

Along with Rhea's in the Mission, there is no other place I'd rather get a sandwich than Deli Board.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Goodness me - what a sandwich. I'll come straight out with it: my experience at Deli Board brought about what is without a doubt the second best sandwich I've ever had (if you're curious, it's behind only the Porchetta sandwich at Italia Deli and Bakery in Agoura Hills, California: http://www.yelp.com/biz/italia-deli-and-bakery-agoura-hills), and if the price point were just a smidgen lower this would be one of the easier five-star reviews I've ever written. Come here. Now. 

Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?

I've only been to San Francisco maybe four or five times over the past couple of years, so you might chuckle when I say that I was initially a bit concerned walking through a rougher part of town on my way to the gentrified oasis that houses Deli Board. Surrounding area aside, the service and atmosphere at Deli Board are both excellent, and while each sandwich is indeed a masterpiece, they come out quickly. Star Granted. 

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

As I touched on, my experience at Deli Board was sensational, and the one and only drawback was the price. Have a look at the picture of my 'Mina' sandwich at the bottom of this review. Looks delicious yeah? It was, as you'll read, and it was pretty big, but the price tag prior to tax/tip was fifteen bones. $15? That's like, two guac-less Chipotle burritos just about. I don't think I've ever had a sandwich that expensive, and while this was a decent amount of food and some seriously fresh and flavorful ingredients, I simply can't dish out the value star here. $12? Even $13? Now we're talking, but half way to $20? I can't do it even though there are some cheaper sandwiches on the menu. No Star Granted. 

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

Again, this was absolutely brilliant. Fresh pastrami that was flavorful without being too fatty, lettuce, peppers, cheese, sauces, and some of the freshest bread in town. Above all else, while I can't say how they do it, the sandwiches at Deli Board are either toasted or packaged in a way that melds all of the ingredients together into a single cohesive dish as opposed to the piecework stuff you find elsewhere that ends up being nothing even resembling a sum of it's parts. The sandwiches at Deli Board are something special, and you won't go wrong regardless of what you order. Dual Stars Granted. 

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

Without a doubt I could eat this every single day of my life if my organs (and wallet) would allow it. Wonderful. Star Granted.
author: Paul V.

description: Friendly and prompt service. Delicious food (I've only had the Jack). Good tunes. Would be a go-to if I lived/worked nearby
author: Clinton L.

description:
Fast paced. Always Crowded. Constantly yummy and creative with the menu items. Perfect (once a week) cheat-on-your-diet spot! Try my personal favorite: "Zeke" turkey breast, pickled onion, sprouts, mayo, avocado, bacon, cream cheese, french roll. 

Once I described the owner (Adam) as a maestro - a modern day Mozart of sandwiches.  He and his team are leading an extremely talented orchestra of menu items.  Following this analogy, IMHO - Zeke is his "Requiem."
author: Nick S.

description: BEST dang sandwich! I'm drooling thinking of them, if I could afford to go here daily this would be my lunch diet. but dropping about $18 bucks a day just ain't in the cards... BUT a dang good treat on occasion.
author: SMarie V.

description: Deli Board makes amazing sandwiches. I've had a few of their creations and recently made my own vegan sandwich. The dutch crunch bread came out warm and everything is top quality! My only complaint is the price for the size of the sandwich. I could seriously eat two or three of them. Gold star for the pickle.
author: David M.

description: Walked all the way up here from Mission Bay to find out their sandwiched are $15-20 each?! I'm going to grab something affordable like a banh mi
author: Jose U.

description:
My favorite sandwich spot in the world.

I go to SF every 3 weeks or so, and every time I end up coming here for lunch, because it is literally my favorite sandwich.  I look forward to it & dream about said delicious sandwiches...

The CARZLE is #1 top sandwich.  They tried to take it off the regular menu, temporarily, but were met with such customer disappointment on the removal that they were essentially forced to bring it back as a permanent sandwich.  Yes.  YES. YES!!!!  So glad.  75% of my sandwich orders are the CARZLE, add Bacon+ ftw

A.STUD is my #2 favorite sandwich.  Freaking awesome...  And yes, I still add Bacon.

ZEKE is #3 when I'm feeling a little healthier than usual (LOL).  I tend to add either Cherry Peppers or Jalapenos to that one to give it that extra spice.  

Yes its a $16 sandwich or w/e, and yes after I add Bacon to the already-huge mass-meat sandwich it ends up being like $18.  After I add the chips, soda, and a tip for the nice folks who work there its a $25 lunch.  BUT ITS WORTH EVERY PENNY.  Don't listen to the clowns who are complaining about the price - you get what you pay for; and these sandwiches are freaking amazing.  Enjoy!!!!
author: D W.

description:
WHAT A WAY TO MAKE MEAT SHINE.

The way it's constructed with a minimal amount of sauce, the right amount of pickle, and warmly toasted medium-thickness bread makes the meat taste even more yummy.  I almost prefer the meat chopped up like this vs. the old-school NY-style meats in chunks/slices.

The Hermine consists of pastrami, corned beef, and beef brisket, and is sort of a replacement for The Boca which many Yelpers talk about.  It's all chopped up so I can't really tell the difference between the meats as I'm eating it.  All I know is that I love it.  This thing costs $15 and comes with a side of pickles which is one pickle with the ends chopped off.  It tastes strong on its own but I barely notice the one in the sandwich.

If you're looking at the specials online, know that there are more options when you get there including some for vegetarians (mostly containing falafels) and nothing really for vegans unless you abstain from the mayo-based board sauce.
author: Shannon L.

description: I'm a pretty picky eater, don't like most condiments or vegetables so to earn points with me a place needs great ingredients. My first sandwich anywhere is a turkey and cheddar with lettuce on Dutch crunch. That's it, four ingredients. Nowhere to hide bad produce, meats, cheeses or bread. This was the best I've had in SF. A stack of warm delicious turkey, strong melted cheddar, crisp fresh shredded lettuce, and a soft crunch roll. It's closer to my $$$ level but I'll be back to explore next time I get jury duty. Well done!
author: Mark M.

description:
The Carzle and Hermine were both great - served hot with notable freshness in the ingredients and bread.  That said, the sammies themselves were surprisingly small for the steep price.  Overall, a notch below Ike's given the comparable quality yet lesser value.

Some seating is available if you come during off peak hours, so don't expect to find any during the lunch rush.
author: Eric F.

description: Keep in mind that you'll pay at least $15 for a sandwich....but a very delicious one. They're huge and come with some bomb pickles. The amount of filling each sandwich receives makes it worth the price. Check out their website for their board specials which change regularly.
author: Daniel P.

description:
Amazing sandwiches! Pastrami is supposed to be their thing, so I tried the carzle last time I was here. It lived up to its reputation. The carzle has both brisket and pastrami (along with cheese and other toppings) on a garlic french roll. The brisket and pastrami were both sliced so thin, and the entire sandwich was really flavorful with their special sauce. I especially approve of the choice of garlic french roll - the bread is soft and just slightly garlicky. Their sandwiches have a great stuffing to bread ratio (aka LOTS of stuffing but still holds together and fits in your mouth) but are not quite as huge as a sub. 

They have limited seating, so I would definitely suggest taking your sandwiches to go and eating somewhere else. The only annoying thing is that, for some reason, they won't take orders of 6 or more sandwiches during lunchtime. The cashier was really rude to us when we tried to place an order of 6... so... we split our order into two orders of 3 and paid separately. I couldn't really figure out how that limit makes a difference for them.

Deli Board and Ike's actually have different styles, but I would almost dare to call this the Ike's of Soma. Would love to try some of their other sandwiches next time!
author: Tiffany P.

description:
I went here with a friend. The bill came out to be 50 bucks. Granted we did order 2 sandwiches + extra meat + bag of chips + a drink. Regardless, I did not think that a sammich should cost $15-20 a pop. 

The sammich that was supposed to have the extra meat didn't look like it had extra so my friend asked the cashier. She insisted that it did. 

Probably won't be going back. Not worth the price for what you are getting.
author: Elim K.

description: Amazing amazing amazing. Love the Leroy Brown and the Allison. Huge portions! A must stop in San Fran!
author: Emily G.

description: I really want to love this place. I even went here a few times before reviewing, but it's just not hitting the spot likes Ike's does. I tried the Fatty Matty and there other tuna sandwich, both times I was disappointed. The sprouts in both sandwiches were not a good addition they overwhelmed the tuna. If you are going to get a tuna sandwich skip the sprouts. The tuna also could have been better. I know I am not their targeted demographic.  I'm a Pescatarian meaning I only eat fish for meat of choice. But if you're going to charge 15 and up for a sandwich I still want to be really impressed by the taste. Maybe I would have better luck with a make my own tuna or veggie?
author: Cynthia G.

description:
There is no consistency with the sandwich names since they are changed every now and then. There is no menu online.

They are only open for a few hours.

They do not take phone orders.

A sandwich costs close to $20.

Lines can get long.


All negative comments. Why the 5 star review?
Cause the sandwiches are so freakin good! It's totally worth it!
author: Agent K.

description:
A picture is worth 1,000 words, the picture I posted is the Carzle.

Regarding sandwiches in San Francisco:
1. Deliboard
2. Roxie Market on San Bruno
3. Mayo Mustard food truck 
4. Potrero Hill Whole Foods deli
author: Matthew S.

description: Absolutely phenomenal. Had the Carzle and wow, just wow. The bread was cooked to perfection, not too crunchy or too soft. The meat was delicious and juicy. The owner was present and was super friendly and helpful. Love this place!!
author: Nicole K.

description:
4.5 stars for a sandwich place? I mean... how good can one sandwich really be compared to the others?
You don't know until you try it! I went to have a little taste of these infamous sandwiches and I put it away to the face. Cya, Gone. SO GOOD.
The staff is friendly, the ingredients are delicious, all the right ratios, mmmmM!
All my love deli board. See you soon xoxo
author: Marie M.

description:
Let's start with the facts: Any Grateful Dead restaurant is immediately five stars. What do I mean by that? Well... all of their employees were wearing black t-shirts with the iconic Steal Your Face on the front and on the back?! It said: Grateful Bread. I mean, come on. I'm going back there just to get these shirts. Beautiful.

But what a great neighborhood deli! There will likely be a line when you go, but don't worry, it moves fast. We scored a table outside in the sun on such a beautiful day. I got a salad. It was delicious, and it was MASSIVE. Massive people!! Come hungry.

Moral of the story: love the restaurant, love the vibes. Good things all around.
author: Brooke S.

description:
OMFG- yes the sandwiches are expensive (~$15 on average) but these things are worth it- they're also massive so if you're not looking for a food coma/aren't massively hungry you could split with someone. All of the sandwiches come with a big pickle, too!

They've got their standard sandwiches but also have a board that changes daily with any specials on offer. There is usually a line, which is a great thing- it'll take you awhile to figure out which one of these beauts you want to have.

I went with a friend and we opted to go halfsies with our sandwiches so that we could have more than one - we got the Kuip and the Fay, both of which were amazing.

The Kuip is a meat monster with pastrami, corned beef AND salami. It's a bit spicy due to some cherry peppers and also has some melted American cheesy goodness on it. It's a pretty heavy sandwich but delicious.

The Fay is a mix of turkey avocado cole slaw (sounds weird but is great on the sandwich!) swiss cheese and some cherry peppers as well. The Fay would definitely be a better choice if you're trying to avoid that food coma feeling- it's not too spicy as the mayo and coleslaw cut down on the cherry pepper flavors, but it still has a slight punch to it every couple of bites.

This place should definitely be on your lunch rotation!
author: Elliott W.

description: It's expensive and there is a line. It's worth it. The Leroy is the best sandwich I've ever had. Kind staff. Try it out! You're worth it!
author: Shane J.

description:
This place has become one of my favorite places to get sandwiches! Oh my yum! I think of this place all the time when I'm craving sandwiches, but the downside is that they close at 4pm and I don't get off work until after! 

My husband and I shared the Ron. It had a lot of things in the sandwich, but that's what made it delicious! A Rob had roast beef, cheddar cheese, jalapeños, avocado, slaw, board sauce on a garlic French roll. We never eat jalapeños because I can't take spicy food, but I decided to give it a try. The flavors of the ingredients put together was so good! The jalapeños wasn't too spicy and the bread was perfect! They put a generous amount of roast beef. They weren't stingy at all!

The next time come here, I'm excited to try the D. Rubin! It's a pastrami and corned beef sandwich with sauerkraut, Swiss cheese and 1000 island dressing on a Dutch crunch. Or a Boca which had brisket, pastrami, corned beef, muenster cheese board sauce, brown mustard on a French roll. Omg! Those sound amazing!
author: Darlene M.

description:
These are some serious sandwiches.  The bread is amazing and they don't skimp on the meat.  I've gotten sandwiches with sprouts before and the sprouts were a little old and wilted, I'd probably opt for no sprouts on future sandwiches.  Aside from that I have been really pleased with my experiences here.  I love the fresh pickles, too.

There are a couple of drawbacks: if you go here during prime lunch hours, you are going to wait a looooong time in line and wait a looooong time for your sandwich to be made.  I'm not sure if you can call in your order ahead of time, but if they let you, definitely do it.  Second drawback - it's like 20 bucks for a sandwich.  Normally I'd say that's not worth it unless it's a lobster roll, but with how often I crave deli board sandwiches, I think this place is worth the price.
author: Robyn H.

description: Haven't been here in 3 or 4 years. This place is still rock solid. Didn't recognize the owner since he lost a bunch of weight. I was disappointed they didn't have their orange habanero sauce but it didn't ruin the experience, saved my mouth from burning so that's a plus. Will definitely be coming back.
author: Dominic T.

description: These sandwiches are good but not worth $15-17 in my opinion. They are delicious though. Don't build your own--their creations will be better
author: Molly O.

description: Extremely expensive but extremely delicious sandwich place. I tried and give top marks to the BOCA sandwich. Definitely a must try if you in the neighborhood and craving a good sandwich. Me will b a regular whenever I can afford 16$ for a 6 inch deli sandwich
author: Vikas J.

description:
Good sandwich, but just can't get over the price.  Some are mostly meat and sauce.

I remember when the sandwiches were expensive (around $11-$12) but not outrageous.  Came here and most were in the $15-$17 range.  Wow.

I expected to eat half for lunch and save the rest but it wasn't that big.

I guess my wallet isn't as deep as all these SOMA tech workers...
author: Crandon J.

description:
The sandwiches are outstanding, and the line moves quicker than its length would seem (although be prepared for a little post order wait, because the sandwiches are outstanding and people know it).

There's not a distinct lull time, so just come and take your chances.

Be aware that there is a vegetarian option, as well as a vegan salad, but the sandwiches are primarily for meat eaters
author: Matthew D.

description: Deli Board has the best garlic french roll I've ever had. I ordered the Porky and the sandwich was perfection. The bread was lightly toasted and everything within the sandwich was meant to be together within a magical garlic french roll. I definitely can't wait to go back.
author: Radhika G.

description: Pricy, but very good. The sandwiches are huge! They are definitely good for sharing.  The location is a bit out of the way, and the walk from the Moscone center was a tad on the sketchy side, but we would go there again. Yummy!
author: April V.

description:
Me and my bud came for the first time today, all the way from Davis, CA (we had a conference to attend in SF...we're not crazy).  After devouring the Leroy Brown and the Grog (the Grog was better in my opinion), we would be crazy enough to come back just for those sandwiches!  We arrived at 11:40 and zipped through the line.  By 12:10, the line was out the door.  Damn, those sandwiches were good and worth every penny!  I'm salivating as I type this review.  They may not look like they're that filling, but our walk to the Transbay afterwards for our train trip home was not enough.  We should have walked to Davis...no...pushed the AMTRAK back to Davis.

Holy moly, that was an amazing lunch!!
author: G G.

description: Very pricy but one of the best sandwiches ive ever had. Meat is so tasty and nice pickle and hot sauce. Highly recommended.
author: Hyun Goo K.

description:
OMG so delicious. Adam/Owner (The owner) is very friendly. The lunch rush is big sometimes, but it's so worth it.

The sandwiches are worth their price in gold (in fact, I think that's a payment option).
author: Eric S.

description: The best Veggie sandwich I've ever had - the Rivkah. You have to try it to know how amazing it is. The lines are a bit long, and the price is higher than a normal sandwich, but you won't regret paying for what you get in return.
author: Prateek K.

description: Yes, the sandwiches are expensive, but they are stuffing them to the brim with super tasty high quality meat and other fantastic ingredients. I forget which one I got but it's the one with pastrami and egg salad. The Garlic Dutch crunch really was the icing on the cake for this sandwich and the sandwich was the perfect temperature in terms of warmth. I pretty much died and went to heaven, and that wasn't my tired body from partying from the previous night talking. Make sure to use the hot sauce on your Sando! It takes it to a new level, and don't worry too much about ghost peppers being in it, it's not too spicy and here's a lot of flavor to it. Honestly it looks like every sandwich here tastes great so I need to come back again to try some of the others, especially the turkey based ones.
author: Carly H.

description: This was probably one of the best sandwich I ate. My stomach hurts, ham was a little too salty.
author: Mr J.

description: Not for me.  I don't understand who would want minced meats on a sandwich??? I'm baffled by it all and I tried hard... the only good thing I can say is that it was hot and looked good....
author: Kathy W.

description:
Go for the sandwich. Stay for the pickles.
I had delicious and well-crafted pastrami sandwich.
author: Steve P.

description: A must have in SF! This place is amazing Definitely 5 stars. Their sandwiches are made to perfection and make sure you get the waffle fries.
author: Anthony W.

description: There's no denying that the sandwiches at Deli Board are delicious...but if I'm going to pay $16+ for a sandwich, it better look better than this! They definitely skimped on the meat and it was a poorly made sandwich.
author: Kelsey F.

description:
This place is kind of hard to find. There's no visible sign out front, or I'm just unaware, LOL. This place has been in my bookmark section for about a year now, and I finally got the chance to try it. They close at 3 on most days so it is ideal for lunch. 

Got to try the Carzle and Hermine, and they are hot sandwiches! The meat here is very soft. There was nothing I particularly love about this sandwich, and to be honest, it didn't leave an impression on me. It was neither good or bad, and it is definitely missing a wow factor to it.  

However just like everyone else, I was taken back by how small the sandwiches actually are. I was thinking they might be at least a little bit bigger than the actual size of it. I am also disappointed by the price. You are paying more than what you are getting. $16 for an 8 inch sandwich that just tastes mediocre. I do love the pickles that come with the sandwich. So crunchy and juicy.

On top of that, I did get a stomach ache after eating here...
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I came here with high expectations from the reviews and was largely not disappointed. I bought the Carzle which had a delicious blend of pastrami and brisket. Absolutely 5 stars for taste.

What took it down a notch is after tax and a coke, the bill was $20. I don't mind paying that much, but I expected a MASSIVE sandwich - I did not get one honestly.

Comparatively, Little Lucca's in SSF and Burlingame has MASSIVE sandwiches for half the price. I would even say old Mr. Pickles in Millbrae has a bigger sandwich.

Don't get me wrong - amazing and delicious sandwiches. 5 stars for taste. I just can't give this place that rating because you're really not getting the right amount of value for the dollar spent.

In a way, this place is a metaphor for San Francisco as a whole - you pay far too much to get a lot less than your dollar would virtually anywhere else.

Probably not coming back anytime soon, but clearly they don't need me. It's 11:50 and there are 10 people sitting and a line 20 deep out the deli. I guess clearly, I just have different standards than the rest of the gentrification crew of SoMa...
author: Doug R.

description:
YUMMMM DELI BOARD! 

I met a friend for lunch here today. We wanted to meet somewhere in-between both of our work places an didn't know where to choose! Deli Board was recommended by one of her friends who lives in this area and her recommendation did not disappoint!

Deli Board sure knows how to make some tasty sandos. We decided to order two sandwiches and split them, thus the Caralze and Fay were chosen, ordered, and eaten.

LE MENU
-Caralze: SO GOOD. pastrami, cherry peppers, pickles, cole slaw, on a garlic french roll. All of the flavors together were amazing. The garlic french bread wasn't too garlicky if you're concerned about garlic breath afterwards.
-Fay: turkey, avocado, swis cheese, cherry peppers, on a garlic dutch crunch roll. I ordered this one because I love turkey + avocado. This one was also yummy but not as amazing. Maybe because the turkey was not as tasty as the pastrami? Or maybe because I was already getting stuffed from the Caralze. 

PROS:
-PICKLES!!! fat, thick, juicy pieces of pickles to compliment the sandwiches. Also  chips. 

CONS:
-Gets kinda crowded around lunch + limited seating

Ahh such a good place for lunch. I was stuffed afterwards and I had about 1/4 of my Fay sandwich left. I wish this place was a bit closer to me so I could come by more often! Definitely recommend the Caralze :)
author: Grace J.

description:
pros:
Quick to get our orders to go on lunch hour with a busy line. 

cons: 
`At $13 for a ZEKE sandwich and their ingredients aren't even organic/non-gmo!
`Sandwich is not large enough (compared to San Bruno's Little Luccas)
`Emailed them to see if they make their meats, pickles, and breads but... no definite answer.
`Their website has no info on their ingredients statements and weather they make their own meats, pickles, bread etc...
author: Organic T.

description: This is probably the best sandwich I've had in San Francisco. I had the zeke sandwich with bacon on top and then one with pastrami and corn beef bacon and all the veggies. I will be coming back before leaving San Fran. And next time you're in the area you should stop by and try it out it's worth it.
author: Hunter W.

description: The most unique pastrami sandwich I've ever had! The person at the sales counter was very nice, water bottle was free. Thank goodness because my sandwich was $18!!! That's the only down since. But this is Sf! So, yea. It was more than enough food for 2 meals if shared or saved for later.
author: Gayle W.

description:
Why oh why wasn't this here when I worked down the street?!

It's really good. If you like sandwiches you can't go wrong. It's better than Lou's and Ike's. Really.
author: El B.

description:
It feels wrong writing a review when I don't recall the exact sandwich I got here! You'd think that I could maybe narrow it down by saying "It had a LOT OF MEAT!", but nope, turns out all their sandwiches are LOADED! 

I had some assortment of pastrami or roast beef on dutch crunch, and boy was it grand. HOWEVER, it wasn't grander than the other amazing sandwich shops I've been to, just 1000x grander than the likes of a smashed flat thing from the likes of your corner sandwich shop that may sell some $5 12-inchers. 

Things I really enjoyed: the cute set up, the GIANT PICKLE CHUNKS, and splitting two sandwiches with a fellow hungry soul. 

Things I didn't quite enjoy: the difficulty of finding parking and seating, and the impossibility to narrow down what I want from their yummy looking choices (but then again, that's me everywhere!)

If you're feelin' hungry, this is the place to go for a meaty sandwich!
author: Christine L.

description: When people say the best sandwiches in SF they really aren't kidding. I got the Ron and it was fantastic- the cheese and avocado were very fresh. Pro tip: they can make any sandwich vegetarian with egg salad or falafels! Anyways, highly recommend this place. Long lines and they do not accept orders of 6 sandwiches or more. And you are definitely paying for quality (~$15 a sandwich), but well worth it.
author: Vineet J.

description: Do you want the best sando you've ever had in your life? Then you need to come here. These sandwiches are fantastic. We got corned beef sandwiches and they were heavenly. Ours were on a heavenly crispy French bread. Not traditional but a wonderful twist on traditional corned beef sandos. A really fun casual place that spins vinyl albums and the staff is super friendly and helpful. The owner is a great friendly guy that sent us home with a gift of Cleveland's own Stadium Mustard. Treat yourself and get one of these gorgeous sandwiches, you're gonna get addicted!
author: Missy D.

description: Amazing. They have achieved sandwich perfection. What you get is mostly meat, and the bread is warm, crispy, yet soft and doesn't cut the roof of your mouth. Price is a bit high, but, you are paying for perfection in sandwich form, after all.
author: Eugene A.

description:
I reallllly tried to like Deli Board, I mean c'mon, it's 2pm on a casual Thursday afternoon and the line is still out the door, that a good sign, right? Deli Board is a small hole in the wall, fast paced shop with a tiny kitchen that dishes out soups, salads, sauces and most importantly: hand crafted, loaded, mouthwatering looking sandwiches! Their menu is jam packed with tons of pre made selections of sandwiches that come loaded with various meats: briskets, pastrami, corned beef, roast beef, salami...etc as well as a plethora of toppings to go along on their freshly baked breads. It's also bit overwhelming to decide what you want to order with all these options and if that is the case, you can always customize one too!

So I ordered the $$$ sandwich (pronounced as the "money" sandwich) which came with brisket, corned beef, kosher salami, muenster cheese, cheddar cheese, cherry peppers, cole slaw, board sauce, all inside their french roll. It was the first item on their menu and I heard good things about it. When my order came out, it looked massive, eye appealing, and my mouth was ready to tackle every bite of it. The sandwich was filling and hit the spot but something about just seemed missing, there was not "it" factor to it to distinguish it from other sandwiches I've had in my life. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing, but for $15 dollars (the standard price for most sandwiches there) I guess I expected just a little more. I left feeling full but unfulfilled after the hype I had in my mind. 

Nonetheless Deli Board seemed like a great spot the locals frequented and I'd be happy to come back and try some other menu items!
author: JP G.

description: I'm not sure why this has such a high rating. It was a good sandwich, but not as good as Bite, Little Luccas, Genes, or Two Sons and twice the cost. For $17 I expected something that was either huge or spectacular and it was neither. The portion size was very small for a sandwich and there wasn't anything special about it. The fries were completely flavorless but nice and crispy. If the sandwich had been between 8 and 10 bucks I'd probably give a higher rating.
author: Madeline S.

description:
Oh Deli Board what would I do without you. When I am craving a sandwich there is no place that satisfies that urge more than Deli Board up on Folsom. In my opinion these are the best sandwiches I've had or know about. 

The menu seems to change periodically but the ideas and ingredients are generally the same. Everything here is high quality, especially the meats that they include. On the subject of meats, they absolutely stuff an unbelievable amount of meat into each sandwich. I very much like the breads here as well and I generally try to substitute in the garlic dutch crunch which comes out nicely toasted. Lastly, the sauces are all good but the board sauce is so delicious that I always get an extra side to dip my sandwich in.

Overall, while the prices are on the higher side (~$14) it is definitely worth it as these are the best sandwiches around. When it comes to custom sandwiches, this is "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
Best Dutch Crunch! It's perfectly toasted where the bread is flaky , not too doughy, super soft and crispy. It's got the real crunch without the palate cutting. And since its freshly toasted, it comes out nice and warm. 

Their combinations are delicious with thinly sliced meats. Everything from toppings, meats, cheese and sauces were perfectly proportioned so that not one component was overwhelming. We got the boca and the $$$. I liked the boca more but the bf preferred the $$$. I did expect more of a wow factor from all the great reviews. But that Dutch crunch bread left a lasting impression which is why I'm giving it a solid 4 stars instead of 3/3.5. 

The downside is that prices are expensive. $12-15 for a sandwich the size of earls in LV. I expected a larger sandwich for that amount I paid. It's definitely not as large as an Ike's or little Luccas sandwich but tastewise I think deli board beats them. They also beat Ike's and little Luccas on meat quality and bread quality.

They're homemade pickles are delish too.

They accept card and cash.

They also cater. Definitely wouldn't complain if I had a catered lunch with deli board sammies.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Excellent Cleveland-style sandwiches with corned beef, pastrami, and Cleveland Stadium mustard the stars of the show. Really good stuff. $14-$16 for sandwiches are not much of a bargain for lunch, but enjoyable for the occasional splurge.
author: Robert B.

description:
If you are a vegetarian, you should keep reading. 

There is one option and its the falafel sandwich. The falafel itself is chewy and kinda mushy. There is a TON of cream cheese in the sandwich, which is delicious for the first 5 mins and then it hits you. The rest of the sandwich is pretty sub-par and a salad may be a better option for vegetarians.
author: Akshaya V.

description: Whenever a sandwich costs $16, it had better be one helluva sandwich! That's exactly what the Leroy Brown -- pastrami, turkey, salami, American and Muenster cheese, pepperoncini and pickles on Dutch crunch -- is. Can't wait to try their other delicious offerings!
author: Brett W.

description:
The wettest and juiciest sandwich I have had. If you're not feeling very heavy meat I would suggest the Zeke (Turkey-oriented) and great combination with the sprouts, guacamole, and some sort of house sauce.

A must try place in SF for lunch.
author: Kunal T.

description: I really wanted to like this place.  I really did.  I've spent a few months reading these reviews and how great these sandwiches are.  So I finally decided to check it out. The first thing I noticed was that cool little, farm to table type vibe.  The second thing I noticed were the prices that I actually had to double check that I was in a sandwich shop.   I ended up ordering the Boca.   Don't let my 3 stars fool you.  It was a very good sandwich.  Was it the best I've had? Certainly not nor was it the cheapest since it was $16. All the sandwiches are $15-$17.  It wasn't epic or transcendent which I would expect for a $16 sandwich.   It pales in comparison to Little Lucca, who has a near life altering pastrami sandwich for $9.
author: Milton W.

description: Amazing sandwiches by far my favorite in the city. The only downfall is they close on sundays!
author: Edgar C.

description:
These sandwiches are so overrated: lots of meat, little veggies, too expensive for a sandwich.

Yes, they put lots of meat in their sandwiches, which makes it huge and heavy. My roast beef was moist and delicious, it was ok. Next time I'd plan a nap after such weighty meal.

No, Deli Board doesn't bother with vegetables, or as they call it 'fixes.' No cucumbers or tomatoes in the veggie menu, so I had salad, sprouts, and pickles. Can you imagine my surprise when I got my order with pickles in a ziplock bag outside of my sandwich? 

For some odd reason I used to think that sandwich is a combination of products put together outside of one's stomach for a taste and convenience sake. And there is a ziplock bag with moist pickles I have to touch. It is a questionable joy/sanitary situation for a lunch on the go.

Deli Board environment is nice, clean, clear signs, friendly people and expensive sandwiches. I think there are better food options in a walking distance, but I might give a try for their salad next time.
author: Julia G.

description:
This place is expensive. But I don't care, quality has it's price. 

This place lost a star because it doesn't have yellow mustard. 

It lost another star because of the crowd it attracts: a bunch of hipster douchebags. 

If u can get over the bias against yellow mustard & the scumbag crowd, the sandwiches themselves are well worth the price and even when busy the service is fast.

The reality is, this is a 5-star establishment that is disguised as a hangout for losers. But don't let that detract u from eating here. It's worth having to stand in line for.
author: Luther M.

description: I had one of the special turkey sandwiches about a week ago. It was good. It was $18. But it definitely wasn't the best I've had. I even prefer Lou's turkey Roma sandwich, which is just as big for $9. I would have paid $9-12 for this Sammy and would have walked away content. But $18 leaves me a little underwhelmed. Good sandwich, though.
author: mel l.

description:
SO GOOD! had the Jezerksi and was completely blown away by how amazing it was! It's $15 but I would definitely go back for it again! They also give you pickles on the side that were great as well. Great place, just wish it was open later.

Went back a few days later and tried the Porky! STILL AMAZING!
author: Stephan G.

description:
I got the Ricowitz (sp?) and it blew my mind. holy cow HELL yes.

gotta say through the Sum 41 Warped Tour music put a weird taste in my mouth, no bueno dude. its a Jewish deli for christ sake. (if it isnt it should be)
author: Ellie B.

description:
Look if  you want delicious & fresh sandwich, you gotta come here! A lot to choose from, I decided on the "Mina" sandwich with pickles of course! 

The sandwich was absolutely amazing. Decent portion and lots of meats inside.The pickles come in a plastic bag, and they're the best pickles you're gonna ever have! And please don't you dare to not drawn your sandwich with their amazing homemade hot sauces! 

Just go there!
author: Tamara S.

description: I can't believe I hadn't left a review sooner. Simply put, this is my ABSOLUTE FAVORITE sando spot in all of SF! The bread is ridiculous and the meat is out of this world! I love the Carzle- wow!!! And the staff is always super friendly & chill. I love these guys!
author: JonJon W.

description: Yummy!!! This might be one of the best sandwiches I've ever had. I got the tenenbuam and broccoli cheddar soup. Pricey but def delicious if you're willing to splurge a little
author: Samantha G.

description: Deli Board is one if the best sandwich place in SF. When I am stuck not knowing what to eat, I find myself walking over to Deli Board simply because I could blindly pick a random sandwich and be happy with it. Sandwiches are often juicy, delicious, mouth watering, and JUICY! Do beware of long lines if you're in a pinch. Though the wait time isn't always very long.
author: JJ T.

description: This is definitely a 5-star deli spot! Me and hubby ended up splitting an Annabelle - it was turkey, pastrami (or was it corned beef?), coleslaw and cherry peppers in dutch crunch. The sandwich took sometime to be brought over to us but as soon as I opened the wrapper I can see why. The sandwich was piping hot! They took the time to properly assemble your sammich - it wasn't haphazardly just put together. The bread was crunchy but not hard and provided a good vessel for all the goodness that was inside. The sandwich had a good bread to meat ratio and I always appreciate that. The sandwich was so big, that it was the perfect amount for me and hubby to split. Although he did admit to me that he could have finished the whole thing by himself. LOL. An order of sandwich also comes with a small bag of pickles. I don't usually like pickles but this one wasn't as briney and sour like others that come in a jar. The place is only open certain hours during the day - I suggest that you plan ahead if you're heading out here. Menu rotates every now and then but I think you'll be fine with any sandwich you pick. It's for sure going to be a winner!
author: Patricia A.

description: We walked in at 2:57 pm and they close at 3pm on a Monday. Staff was awesome enough to still help us choose great options and helped with great customer service. I got the Jezerski with sauce on the side!!! This place is a must 10x's over and over
author: Joseph G.

description:
I have been hunting for the perfect sandwich for quite some time. And, thanks to my favorite brewery, Cellarmaker, the hunt is now over.

I can't even describe the amazingness that is the carzle. The pastrami and brisket were out of this world.

I saw a review saying that Ike's is better. What a joke, Ike's is more comparable to Subway than to Deli Board, I don't care how expensive the sandwiches are, but then again, I would not be going here every day for lunch.
author: Bryan B.

description: These sandwiches are like crack!!  Bought 4 different sandwiches and they were all good.  It can get a bit crowded there and a bit far for me to be a regular here which probably a good thing or else I would gain about 10 lbs from eating here on the regular lol.
author: Leon L.

description: You can't really go wrong here! The sandwiches may seem a bit small in size at first, but they are chock-full of juicy meat (or whatever protein you decide to go with) and they will fill you up in a hurry! Perhaps my favorite part about the whole experience was the ziploc baggies of homemade crunchy pickles that they give you - so tasty and a nice, local touch! The only reason for the four stars instead of five is the price - at $16+ for a medium-sized sandwich, you could go broke in a hurry! But a great little taste of Cleveland nonetheless. Enjoy it at the park across the street!
author: Andy L.

description:
Deli Board has a good product but their terrible service and horrendous attitude does not justify supporting the establishment. They have a policy of 6 sandwiches max per order because they can only support 150 sandwiches a day according to the clown that was there today.

If you are 3 individuals who show up with different credit cards but they think you are associated or in the same group, they will turn you away. That's what happened to us. Because they don't answer their phone (call them just to hear the VM and how pretentious these guys are), we didn't know that they are not OK with three individuals ordering 6 sandwiches each so we trekked all the way over there only to be treated terribly.

They said they could refuse our service and that's what they did. 

Fortunately, SF has plenty of good sandwich spots so I would encourage you to GO TO MERIGANS on 2nd Street. They take orders over the internet or phone. We ordered 13 subs today and it was ready in under 40 minutes and they have great service. Support a place that cares about good quality AND the patrons that support them.
author: Jackie M.

description: I'm a professional cook and have higher salt tolerance than most people. However, I got the Gold-n-Berg-n-Stein today and it was really salty...It was alright the first bite, but after eating 1/4 of it, I started to taste nothing but salt. For $20/sandwich (including tax + tip) I expected better.
author: Jin Z.

description: Pretty good sandwiches but idk what it was but the sandwiches were SALTY. Luckily I made it just before it got super packed so I didn't have to wait that long
author: Navdeep D.

description:
The sandwiches are great, and the owner's dedication to his sandwich craft is sincere and dedicated. He once chased me and my friend outside because he saw us putting the bunch of sandwiches we'd ordered for our friends in a backpack, and he explained to us that the sandwiches couldn't breathe in a backpack, and they needed to be in the paper bag to maintain peak sandwich deliciousness. Overwhelmed by his poignant and sincere message, we carried the sandwiches back in the paper bag as requested. 

I also recently tried a salad here, and it was delicious! I may just order salads going forward, I liked it so much.
author: Tasha D.

description: Amazing sandwich. Super fresh and tasty.  The Dutch crunch roll was excellent.  This was the best sandwich I've had in years.  Go early for lunch as it gets busy.
author: Tom G.

description:
Finally had the chance to check this place out after seeing photos of the sandwiches (in between rants about SoMa's homeless) by its owner on Twitter. I have to say the sandwiches are smaller and less hefty than they appear in the dude's photos, and the pricing is suspect even by SF standards ($16 for the main ones).

However, this may all be because the deli meats and bread are of a high quality. I don't know the narrative regarding the ingredients if there is one, but everything seemed fresh and "artisanal". I had the Boca sandwich, and it was pleasantly salty - juicy pastrami and brisket with a nice cut of brown mustard and house pickles. The French roll was soft and likely baked morning-of.

Overall I think I'll come back here, as the vibe was nice (records playing, industrial chic, startup lunch crowd) and the sandwich was really tasty. Just wish he'd either beef up the size or reduce the price.
author: Narek A.

description: This small sandwich shop was a weird find when we were just walking around the area and got hungry. The sandwiches all seemed interesting and tasty but we could only select 2 choices. Would come back and try the rest of them.
author: Raymond W.

description: Best sandwiches in the city, hands down. A bit pricey, but you won't regret it.
author: Greg P.

description:
Awesome sandos! Don't be afraid by the pricing...these things are works of art! The meats are like butter, and and they're exceptionally gratifying! 

The Carzle has to be the best of the bunch! Try it and you'll be craving it for days like i was.
author: Aaron S.

description: Gold-n-Berg-n-Stein (corned beef, romanian pastrami, kosher salami, cole slaw, muenster cheese, 1000 island, french roll) was, without exaggeration, the best sandwich I've ever tasted.
author: Stefan W.

description: Open atmosphere, friendly staff, delicious food. Had a delicious deli sandwich with sweet peppers, amazing flavor and a lot of food for the cost. Mexican soda is a nice touch. Vinyls playing in the background provide excellent ambiance. Pickles added to the meal were an excellent final touch.
author: Matthew E.

description: $17 for a sandwich... Damn that's expensive. Automatic minus one star. I came here with my coworkers for lunch and got the Carzle (romanian pastrami, brisket, provolone, cherry peppers, pickles, cole slaw, "Board sauce", garlic french roll). Definitely a tasty sandwich! Arby's roast beef on crack is how my friend has described the Carzle, and that would be a very accurate description. I'm would definitely recommend trying out the sandwiches at Deli Board at least once if you're in the area. There's going to be a long line at lunch, so do come a bit early if you don't want to wait. Would I come here over Ike's? Absolutely.
author: Austin W.

description:
Deli Board is hipster heaven. The Forrest Gump soundtrack was spinning on a record player, and the girl who took my order was hipster cool and flashed a peace sign at a regular customer entering the room.

I had a simple kosher salami sandwich, which was delicious and hot and great, but I'll be back to try every other sandwich on the menu. And it's true, these sandwiches are jammed packed full of meat. They're great and delicious and not stingy at all with the toppings.

Deli Board, you've got a new regular.
author: Christina S.

description:
Expensive sandwich that's packed full of flavor.
Quality and expect to pay average of $15 plus drinks.

Typical soma hipness, people and cost.
author: David H.

description:
Delicious
Dense, Hot, Savory
Just go.  

The best sandwich I ever had.
author: Peter H.

description:
$$$ (name of sandwich) 

Sandwiches made by angels! Enough said!

Meat was super tender, moist and flavorful...would gladly pay $3 for extra meat (most photos are with 2x meat) 

Overall Thoughts

Good god the sandwiches here are amazing
author: Eddie W.

description:
I can't stop eating these sandwiches. They are all so damn good.

If you come here on a weekend at noon then expect a long line, but it moves pretty fast.

Love the free pickles.
author: Captain B.

description: Seriously incredible sandwiches! We got the Zeke and the Boca and both were perfect. The meat is so tender and all of the ingredients are high quality. Well worth the above average price.
author: Pam N.

description:
Excellent experience 

You get what you pay for - not cheap but the quality is there

Friendly staff and fast service 

Will now be part of the rotation on visits to San Fran
author: Joe A.

description: Fatty Matty & Grog were both UNREAL. Go with a friend just so you can split sandwiches. This place is INSANELY DELICIOUS. Best $15 I've ever spent...
author: Emily L.

description:
I ordered the Mezman and it was one if the best sandwiches I've ever had. The pastrami was warm, cheese perfectly melted and the bread was not soggy or too rough on my mouth (how dutch crunch can sometimes be). The sliced pickles on the side were a nice touch too. The menu is unique and everything sounds delicious. I can't wait to go back and try more.
While the sandwich was amazing the price was a little higher than I usually spend on a deli sandwich and the sandwich itself was smaller than average. That's the only thing stopping me from giving this place the 5 star rating.
author: Jenna A.

description: What was GREAT about the Hermine is the layers of deliciously fantastic pastrami, corned beef, and brisket (yes, all three!) muester cheese and mustard. One of the best sandwiches I've had in a while. What's not so great? The $17.60 price tag for a sandwich and a quarter pickle. Delicious yes but that's an outrageous price even for Sam Francisco.
author: Will H.

description: Never mind their amazing sandwiches. They have THE BEST buffalo wings in the city hands down. So delicious!!
author: Yan H.

description:
I went there on a Saturday afternoon and ordered the The Boca. SO DELICIOUS! Prices are pretty ridiculous so I decided to split the sandwich with my boyfriend. I regretted it after the first bite. I wanted to order a whole other sandwich just for myself after! This is by far the best pastrami I have ever tasted. 

It wasn't TOO packed and took about 10-15 minutes for the sandwich to be made. 

My new favorite sandwich spot in SF (although I have yet to try Ikes) :)
author: Vanessa P.

description: Holy smokes, this is the best sandwich place I have ever, ever been to!!! I wish they could open up somewhere in the financial district!!!! love this place and the flavor of the lunch meats. Even the bread served totally by itself would be awesome...
author: Jim B.

description:
While expensive, these sandwiches pack a ton of flavor into each bite. I didn't think it would be overly filling but I was dead wrong. I almost didn't finish my Carzle sandwich. It was packed full of great meat and the bread was fantastic. 

Get here early though or you'll be in a line of 20-30 people waiting for a great sandwich.
author: Mike W.

description:
I've heard how good the Deli Board sandwiches were in terms of their city wide reputation.  My coworkers and I came here to try it on a weekday and the line wasn't that long.  Of course, then I see all the Cleveland connection and the Cavaliers logo on the background...it probably didn't help that I was wearing my Warriors shirt.  

The sandwich list is pretty large...I was tempted to get the corn beef, pastrami, or brisket items.  I was actually tempted by the sandwich that offered a combo of chicken salad and kosher salami.  After waiting and getting my sandwich, I was immediately enlightened with my eyes opened to the chicken salad/salami combo.  That plus the bread and the condiments, wow!!!  The chicken salad itself wasn't a mayo-based creamy mess, it was actually more chicken which was a great change of pace.

Yes the sandwich was $15 but a big sandwich that can at least two meals for any person who is not crazy to eat the whole sandwich in one meal.  And yes the owner is a Cavaliers fan but I can love any place that can deliver such unique creations that I have not seen before.
author: Ben H L.

description:
First bite of my Boca Sandwich screamed, "OMG THIS MEATY SANDWICH IS SO BOMB!"  Packed thick with juicy corned beef, pastrami, brisket, warm melted cheese, a light hint of mustard and all on a crisp, French bread, every bite fulfilled the senses of my taste buds in my mouth!  Eat it with the succulent, half-sized pickle that they provide and it is BEYOND spot on!

Picture of my Boca - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/deli-board-san-francisco?filter_by_userid=True&select=ieYTLrAFTr-ruVr6Nxnc2w&userid=I-FmdvI28N7OIIt4JZOgIg#ieYTLrAFTr-ruVr6Nxnc2w

They also offer other sandwich fillings on their simple menu, but their Boca, which was the first one on the board, caught my eye right away!  On average, it's about 12 bucks for a sandwich, but believe me, it is worth it!  I devoured it like no tomorrow! 

I like how there is a good seating area to enjoy my sandwich experience and the wait time to get your sandwich is on point!

Great deli shop with bomb diggity, mighty meaty and veggie sandwiches!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I work around the block from this place but have literally refused to go out of principle. $17 after tax for a sandwich is just absurd. Ludicrous. Offensive actually.

HOWEVER

This sandwich was amazing.

I got the Crezle. Pastrami and Brisket.  The sandwich basically melted in my mouth while biting into it.  The garlic french roll tasted like it was doused in butter.  Amazing.  Surprisingly, exceeded my expectations.

Now I cant say much to their other meats, but if im paying this much, im getting the pastrami and you should too. It doesnt disappoint.
author: Nick E.

description: Deli board is a restaurant that is as San Francisco as it gets. You walk in after waiting in a long line to a very trendy looking place that sells sandwiches. When you look at the menu you can't help but think how much meat will be packed into a $16 sandwich but all the signs so far point to that this is going to be a great lunch spot. And it was, the sandwich was pretty good, but I would never be able to charge someone $16 for it and feel good with myself for it. There wasn't an absurd amount of meat like I would have liked but it was very good. I think my favorite part of the whole experience was the habanero sauce they had which made the sandwich taste even better.
author: Itzak H.

description:
Go here. Eat a sandwich. Be happy. Repeat. 

Here's the deal: this is San Francisco, which means there are a lot of people here to get a sandwich (see above). Because of this, you will have to wait in line. You will have to wait for your sandwich to be prepared. To ensure decent service, they will not do more than six sandwiches per person. So don't be an idiot and expect them to Know Who You Are and break the rules for you. 

The sandwiches are absolutely delicious, worth the price, and worth the wait.
author: Jeremy B.

description: Expensive sandwiches and worth every penny.. Seriously - just take all my money and make me a sandwich.  We grabbed two sandwiches and head over to Cellarmaker Brewing for a perfect lunch.
author: Sarah W.

description:
These sandwiches are outrageous- comparable to the size of a super burrito.  Living near and having a husband who is a deli board addict, I have tried them all. These combinations are just too good to not attempt stealing a 2nd bite of his and devour my own. 

I personally cannot get enough of the BK. A BK on a sat am can only set your weekend up for success. This beauty has 2 or 3 fried eggs, multiple strips of bacon, 2 sausage patties, melted cheese on a dutch crunch roll. I inhale this sandwich and a very sick part of me still wants more. 

The porky is also a dream come true. Ham, bacon, melted american cheese and board sauce

Again, you really cant go wrong here. Read the menu, follow your heart, and you will leave a very happy soul.
author: Denniz S.

description: Been meaning to try his place for a long time now. Since it's open only during the day i never get to it. Was in the area for a meeting so i hit it up before heading there. The Hermine is a loaded sandwich. Brisket, corned beef, muenster, pastrami, sauce, good bread. Good pickle on the side and a Doc Browns. With tip that got to be basically $20 for lunch. Now if the sandwich were twice e size id probably be more comfortable with the price. Its no less tasty just a tad on the expensive side. Still worth trying though if youve never been
author: Kim N.

description:
PROS: Warm. Soft. Flavor explosion. Not soggy. Aromatic. Cool atmosphere.

CONS: Small sandwich. Small location, easily crowded.

ATE...
*Fay: I had the Fay sandwich which consists of turkey, avocado, Swiss cheese, cherry peppers, cole slaw, board sauce, mayo, and garlic dutch crunch.

*Boca: The wife had this one. French roll stuffed with brisket, pastrami brisket, corned beef, muenster cheese, board sauce, brown mustard, and pickles.

THOUGHTS
I gotta say that the Fay is a pretty damn good sandwich. I'm pretty picky with my sandwich and they totally met most of my expectations. The only problem I had with it is that it seemed a tad small. The wife got filled up with hers and even had to save some for later but I could've used more. Her Boca was delicious! Made me a little sad that I didn't select hers but I normally am not a fan of pastrami. Next time for sure!

This spot is pretty chill. The seats are part wood boards and industrial red chairs with urban stickers on the backside. Music taste is pretty wild since they have a big box of old school records. If they got more seating or moved to a slightly bigger spot, it'd be the perfect sit down spot but after today's crowded experience, it's take out for the foreseeable future.

TL;DR: Awesome sandwiches at small location with slightly small sandwiches.
author: Martin U.

description:
Came here for lunch with the boyfriend and it totally lived up to the hype. 

What we ordered:

The Fay 
The Carzle 

Both were amazing. Freshly toasted bread and the meat melted in your mouth. Highly recommend if you're willing to wait in line!
author: Stephanie R.

description: I've been to a lot of Deli style places. Some have let me down. Some I can't wait to get back to. This one was pretty legit. They have a set menu, then a rotating one. I ordered an Allison. Perfect size. Packed with ingredients. And a great taste with a hint of slaw at the end. Smaller spot so seating is limited. But cool people so I just shared a table with strangers.
author: O M.

description:
Prices have climbed significantly in the past year and the sandwiches have gotten significantly smaller.

It used to be that eating a whole sandwich put you in a meat induced coma for the rest of the afternoon, but now, it's like a snack.

Prices went up by over 25% and the sandwiches are probably 40% smaller.

Increase prices or make them smaller, not both.

Sad, because this place was so good.
author: Tu T.

description: SO GOOD!! anyone who's complaining about the cost doesn't understand business there's so much meat on these sandwiches!! Worth every penny. I ordered the brisket, the bread was so warm and fresh. The meat was sliced so thin it almost melted in my mouth, I actually had a dream about one of those sandwiches! I'm lucky to be working back in that area and it's just a walk from work! Typical lunch time is busy but they're pretty quick for the amount of traffic in there. I can't wait to go back, it made me miss Katz deli in NYC mile high meat and food coma after.
author: Nena L.

description:
No, they don't JUST serve sandwiches.  

During the past few visits, the variety of their daily soups convinced me that there is more than meets the eye here.  
Gazpacho, mushroom bisque, hot baked potato soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=e1Niicp8QJmuKo1PFNRZ2Q&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), and most recently their Cinnci Chili (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=jaxeZoViGe7F3B-Ire1x7g&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), comprised of cheddar cheese, macaroni, and red onions are the REAL DEAL.  

On another adventurous stop, I ordered the Its salad to go (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  Talk about a meat lover's dream, this salad has romaine, capicola, pepperoni, provolone, black olives, 1/2 dry cherry tomatoes, pepperoncini with creamy Italian dressing.  This was a meal in itself, though definitely not for vegetarians.

If none of their sandwiches tickle your fancy (finding that hard to believe), try their soups or salads!

Note - Their specials are listed daily just before 11 am (http://www.deliboardsf.com/the-board/).
author: Mike C.

description:
These sandwiches are wonderful. That's obvious by the line out the door. Cool names and all with a great taste.  While waiting in line ask others what their favorites are.  It's a good thing to do while waiting in line.  

Order ahead. They're not fast. Good food isnt always fast. Just be prepared for it to be much slower than other sandwich shops.
author: Sam A.

description:
Neat little sandwich joint.

Portions are big, staff is really friendly, and service is speedy.

Prices are a little steep but definitely not excessive. Good spot for quick bite.
author: Teiki K.

description: Went around 2 pm on a Thursday . No line. Really quick service . Place was crowded. Sandwich was delicious.
author: Niosha E.

description: I love that there's a great deli around the corner from my office. There's definitely a hipster vibe with young people lined out the door and music playing from vinyls, but the sandwiches back it up. The menus are printed on pitcher paper, with specialty sandos and an option to build your own. Admittedly i have only gone here when I get my egg salad sandwich craving, and this place hits the spot. I'll have to venture out of my box soon, but until then, the egg salad with muenster and peppers on Asiago roll is my jam. Only drawback-- why can't we have tomatoes as a sandwich topping?
author: Anita H.

description: The best sandwich in San Francisco. Hands down. Salads are off the charts as well. Only negative is the owner is a Cleveland sports fan, but we won't hold that against him.
author: D R.

description:
Very tasty sandwiches - perfect temperature, good mix of ingredients, great bread. 

They lose two stars for:

*calling their sandwiches sandos (ugh), though at least they don't call them sammies, which is worse IMO.

* charging $15 for a sandwich. 

* only offering water in the form of bottled water. And Arrowhead brand, owned by Nestle and bottled in drought stricken california, to boot. And $1.50 for a small bottle. Lame.

* and giving customers their (super tasty) pickles in disposable ziplock baggies. Double lame.
author: Mary Z.

description: Walowitz! Oh how I wish you were on the regular menu. Hotdogs and pastrami and muenster oh my! Get this and shove it in your face!!! Kthxbai
author: J S.

description: I thought it was quite an amazing sandwich but ultimately it was a little too dry for me. I hoped it would have been a little more juicy like the one with the coleslaw. I liked the kuip too!
author: Sian C.

description:
Great sandwiches. Raunchy Customer service. 
Everyone needs to just start BEING NICE!!!!!

Geez.
author: taylor w.

description:
A damn fine sandwich. Great bread, well assembled, quality ingredients, the whole package satisfied.

Really really expensive tho. Almost $20 for a sandwich. Seriously?

Roxie's is still the best.
author: Mason C.

description:
$15 sandwiches! Oh but it's delicious. I had the Jackson. Melted cheese and jalapeños are like magic together. Heated just right, good toppings, and they're spinning vinyls on a record player.

Way better than Ike's which has no seating and a wait both before ordering and after that's insane and unjustified. I used to work at a deli so I think I'm not being unfair. They make them pretty fast here. 



7 tables inside, 2 out. Only one table is a four top. Stand up counter along windows. 

Here for jury duty at the hall of justice on Bryant. Easy walk and you have enough time to eat and enjoy your break.
author: Tracy Y.

description: Probably the best sandwich I've ever had. The price is a little bit high which is why I only give it 4 stars. I would definitely go here again, but not on a regular basis. Overall it is very good but a little overpriced.
author: Wguild G.

description:
The VHAT. Yes.

But, really...no drink, nothing extra, and not a big sandwich...and I spent over $15.
author: Amy O.

description:
Best sandwiches in the city. Everything is the best version of that food you can imagine, if it is pastrami, chicken salad or just the rye bread. The sandwiches aren't overly sauced, but actually well balanced between all of their ingredients so that in each bite, you can clearly taste the rye bread, the sauce, the veggies and the meat. They also have some really good veggie sandwiches, which I would normally not go for as a carnivore, but the Rivkah is a great sandwich. 

They also occasionally serve dinner as well, and if they have the brisket, I can easily say that it's the best brisket I've ever had. Don't tell my grandmother I said that, but it's true. I can't go enough. It is usually a time they are trying new things, but all the plates from the burritos to the gyros have been excellent.
author: Michael J.

description:
Seems like this is where hipsters go to grab some good pastrami. It's a cute little place that offers a variety of hot sandwiches and fresh salads. I had the pastrami sandwich and I have to say, I think I prefer thick cut pastrami better, so the sandwich was okay. The meat was good but too thin for my liking. The bread tasted similar to potbelly sandwich bread so a bit on the chewier side. I really liked the bubbies salad which was egg salad, tuna salad, and chicken salad on a bed of field greens. You could tell they made the salads from scratch so I felt really good after eating the whole thing. 

Kind of in a dead neighborhood so there's not much to see of you are waiting for it to open. There's a park across the street if you are into people watching.
author: Vy B.

description:
It was good, ok? It was not, however, $20 good. 

I had their version of a Reuben, which is to say, not. I missed the rye bread a great deal, and while I did *see* the sauce and "sauerkraut," their taste did not make an appearance. The menu said there was cheese on there, but it too was very well hidden. They should have called it "meat and bread." Funnily enough, at first blush, the sandwich evoked Arby's for me. 

As far as I'm concerned, the homemade pickles are made in the home of one Mr. Vlasic. 

Funny things overheard included a conversation between the cook and a couple of customers I assumed to be friends of his. Cook asks friend what he thinks. Friend says, get this, "It tastes kind of like Arby's." The cook seemed to take some measure of pride in this and replied, "Yeah, it's a special thing I do." For all I know, they actually go to Arby's after you order and grab some meat for your sandwich from there. I don't hate Arby's, so that's ok, but the markup is ridiculous. 

AND! During the course of their conversation, the cook mentioned he was thinking about opening a $20 sandwich shop in the Tenderloin. "It just seems like a really interesting concept," he says. This bodes well for neither his sandwich shop nor the Tenderloin. 

This is probably a three-star joint, but I knocked it down one because of their unconscionable pricing.
author: Jarrod S.

description: The $$$ sandwich was definitely tasty, no complaints there. But $15?! For a sandwich?? I saw an outdated photo of the menu on yelp which had the sandwich going for $11, still pricey for a sandwich with no sit down service, but I was willing to try it out for something that got such great reviews and looked like a large, solid sandwich. When we got there we were astounded at the prices so my boyfriend and I ended up splitting. Adding insult to injury, the sandwich was much smaller and had much less meat than those pictured on yelp. Overall, disappointed and NOT worth the money.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Hands down THE BEST sandwich place in town.

The FATTY MATTY was AMAZING- fresh albacore tuna, sprouts, pickled onion & FALAFEL?!? SO DELICIOUS. 

I always come here for my sandwich craving and it's so worth it x1038372661839489283810!!!! Lunch lines get very long, but its not too bad of a wait. It's worth it. 

I'm pretty sure they make their own bread. I mean...it can't get any better than that extra soft Dutch crunch roll...or that French roll..they have to make that stuff fresh...it can't be from a bag...it's just too good to be true. I can keep going, but you get the picture.. It's amazing. I don't know what else to say.
author: Sophie P.

description:
I got the Chloe and it arrived wrapped as a stolid grenade that when split open, rushed forth like an oven door in a steamy burst of soft French bread, juicy stacks of meat (turkey, Romanian pastrami, and salami), coleslaw and spicy cherry peppers.

Astonishingly pricey, at $16 after tax and tip, but that sandwich was packing heat.
author: Letitia L.

description:
I had to unfollow these guys on Instagram because It would make me want to go so often. 

My friend ordered a Ham and cheese (even though he's an adult) and even that was amazing! 

I suggest getting two sandwiches and having a friend get two and splitting.
author: King R.

description:
Dang man. I rode the bus and had a very interesting trek from work to get here. 
I studied photos before coming and these sandwiches looked monstrously huge.
They're not actually that big in length but they've got GIRTH  puahahhaha. They are PACKED with meat
You know what else? It's the motion of the ocean and these sandwiches have got it going on!

I know $11 seems pricey for a sandwich (I had the Boca) but damn. What you're really paying for is the meat. Each piece of meat, each bite... so juicy, succulent, and flavorful! 

In the family of sandwiches, Deli Board would Ike's' guido juicehead cousin and I am all good with that. 

They have Dutch Crunch bread which is definitely works in their favor. The crunch of the bread is like... DAMN with that amazing meat.
author: Susy C.

description:
Pretty good sandwiches. 
Split the Hermine & Zeke and they were both pretty good.

Hermine $13 
romanian pastrami, brisket, corned beef, muenster cheese, 
pickles, Board sauce, brown mustard, french roll
It sounds like it would be super salty but it was actually not salty at all.  It was good but I think all I could taste was the meat. Everything else was subtle
The toasted french roll is nice.

Zeke $12 
turkey breast, avocado, bacon, cream cheese, 
pickled onion, sprouts, mayo, french roll

The turkey breast was yummy. It didn't taste like those cheap deli meats at the market which was a relief.  Mostly you can taste the turkey and the avocado.  I love turkey, avocado, and sprout combo so this was definitely good for me.

Both sandwiches came out warm. Hot and fresh! 
The side of pickles are good.
The buffalo sauce, thai sauce, mustard are self serve.

Service was nice and friendly.
limited seating.
author: Heejin L.

description:
*** After just one visit, me likes. Original. ***

I stumbled upon this little neighborhood deli
purely by accident.  It is a serendipitous find.

Cashier was pulling out an EW&F vinyl album
when I arrived. Wah, they gotta record player?
(+1 star for creative style.)

Even though the meaty sandwich selection
is great, I opted to get chicken tortilla soup
and a falafel sandwich for my Caltrain ride.
Both were filled w/ fresh healthy ingredients.
I was pleased but I prefer tastier seasonings.
Both were rather bland.  I'd do meat next time.
(+3 stars for veggie selections.)

*** I would def frequent here if I lived nearby. ***
author: Barry W.

description: Delicious sandwich place we found while looking for lunch in SOMA. Went with a falafel sandwich topped with tomato, lettuce and pickles. Some of the best falafel I've had and probably the closest I've had to tasting like the falafel in Jerusalem.
author: Andrew V.

description: Friendly staff really good sandwiches! A very good portion of meat for each sandwich even the kids ham had a good amount of meat. I have 5 kids and no one complained everyone ate all their food! That is great! I can tell they use good ingredients I am super sensitive to food and felt good after I ate it!! Well be back
author: Nick N Parker S.

description: I live a couple blocks away from Deli Board and I used to come here all the time. I haven't been here for maybe +6 months and came back here yesterday and I forgot how expensive their sandwiches are (~$14-16)! Don't get me wrong, this is still one of my favorite sandwich joints in the city, but I'm knocking down a star for the price. The sandwiches have the right balance of sauce, meat, and bread; you'll never get a soggy sandwich. Everything here is amazing, I just wish it was at a lower price point so I could get it more often.
author: Cindy A.

description: I've experienced a few food comas in my life time but WOW this place is the definition of a food coma. I've been here now two times and have had amazing meaty sandwiches: the Fay and the Ilyaboss. Both were of high quality and came packed with tons of meat, veggies, and sauces. Plus you get a huge delicious pickle that will give you pickle breath for hours. The line gets pretty long during the lunch hour so I would advise to get there a bit early. It is a bit on the pricier side for a sandwich but its definitely worth it. Beware of going back or attempting to go work after eating one of these sandwiches, I straight up had a food coma!
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Best sandwich I've had! A little $$ but worth it. Try the crazle. 

They also play albums - nice touch.
author: Nick S.

description:
The sandwiches here were amazing. I can't remember the exact name of my sandwich but it had jalapeno and roast beef on it. The sandwich was served hot and toasty, they also add in a pickle as an option. Staff here were friendly and even though there's a line here (it's not too bad because the order line moves fast, the wait is a little longer), there's still manage to have places to sit. I guess it's because everyone is taking their order back to their office for lunch. What was a little disappointing was that their price is on the higher end, it came close to $15 for a 6" sandwich. Hardcore sandwich lovers wouldn't care too much about the numbers if their ingredients are hitting the right notes which they do. So it's up to you if you're into $5 footlongs at subway or piping hot delicious sandwiches for $15.

I'll leave that choice up to you while I munch down on my sandwich.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Stars off because it's pretty pricey for a sandwhich. Pretty good though. The sandwiches are huge. Didnt get to finish mine so I saved it for later. Im not a crazy die fan of deli meat, but this is the place to go if you are. Would I come back again? Probably not. I wouldn't go out of the way for it, but its a place to try if you haven't yet and you're in the area.
author: Hayle C.

description: Uhhhh, no.  I walked in and was immediately accosted by Guns N' Roses blasting from the record player behind the counter.  Don't get me wrong.  I love old school Guns N' Roses, but it was too loud.  I perused the menu desperately trying to concentrate over the vocals of Axl Rose and decided on a salad.  "Ok," I thought, "This is cool.  The salad is expensive, the music is too loud, but I'll have a glass of wine or a beer and chill."  I was informed by the friendly cashier that they don't serve wine, but that I could go down the street (a block away per her instruction) and get wine.  I was confused.
