First of all, was she suggesting I vacate the premises and find another place to eat?  Was she suggesting that I make my purchase, tote my little salad over to the wine oasis a block away and sit on the corner, bottle of wine in one hand, salad fork in the other?  Or perhaps, turn around, walk to wine shack in the nether regions of Folsom, then mosey on back to super expensive sandwich shop with booze in hand from a different locale?  I pondered for a second and said, "I'll just have water, thanks."  As I sat waiting for my uber expensive salad sans wine or beer, I heard my name bellowed, "Niki!  Niki!"  I waved to the person holding my salad and smiled politely and said thank you.  No smile back.  No, you're welcome.  No, enjoy.  Nothing.  Just a deadpan glare.  I wasn't looking for a friend, just a level of courteous societal niceties for a brief second in time.  Anyway, I digress, I looked down at my salad expecting to find it displayed on fine china with stainless steel Oneida flatware and a crisp, linen napkin.  Instead my salad was served in a clear, plastic box, with a single, rough, brown paper napkin and a plastic fork.  I opened the plastic salad box top and began eating.  It was good, but tasted like a salad from a plastic box.  It was clearly not fresh, but tasted as if had been in the plastic for a while atop other lonely shelved salads in the dark recesses of their industrial sized refrigerator.  We were now onto Mr. Brownstone bellowing from the archaic music chambers of the sandwich counter.  I rubbed my head detecting an inevitable headache approaching.  Halfway through my salad I asked wannabe hipster sandwich guy if they served bread with their salads and he said, "Well, we caaaaan, but it's gonna to take a few minutes."  Damn.  Well that sure sounds like it's going to be super inconvenient for you.  "That's ok." I said.  Seconds later, "Are you sure?"  Me, "Yes, I'm good thanks."  Sandwich guy, "I've got pita bread right here...you want that?" Me, "No.  Thanks."  Him, "Are you sure?"  Ok, at this point I'm thinking, what the fuck.  Do I not look sure?  What is it about me that is forcing you to continue asking me if I'm sure.  And then it continued, "It's really good pita bread.  It's from the bakery down the street."  Me, clearly annoyed, "I'm fine."  Him, "Are you sure because I'm just going to throw it away."  Well damn!  Give it here then!  Let me shove that pita bread into my face so as not to waste it!  Listen folks, I'm a native San Franciscan and a grown woman and this is what I'm sure of:  don't deter your guests by telling them to go down the street to buy wine, don't blast the music so loud that people can't have a conversation at noon and/or blast away, but offer wine and beer so people can tolerate your establishment and when a guest asks for bread the correct response is, "Yes, I'll be right back."  Not, you can have the shitty pita bread I was about to throw away.  For the price of that salad, I'd rather go where I can have a glass of bubbly and gracious service.
author: Niki Y.

description: Everything about this place is absolutely amazing except for the prices.  $20 for a sandwich! Are you kidding me? However after you get over the sticker price shock and take a bite of ANY of their amazing sandwiches you will quickly forget about how much you paid.  Great friendly owner, nice staff, quick service considering the lines.  Go get one!!!
author: G B.

description:
WHY, oh WHY have I not reviewed this place for Club de Sandwich yet?! I fail at life.

The first time I came here was with...Club de Sandwich. Clearly, it needed to be done. We were looking for a spot accessible for people coming from the North/East side of SF, South West side of SF, and from South SF. Deli Board had opened recently, and we opted to go here. OMG. SOOO GOOD!

My first sandwich here was the mish. Corned Beef. Bacon. Jalapenos. Yummy! My partner in crime had the Zeke, which was also delicious. I've been back a few times, and am trying not to get the same thing twice. So I've had the bocca, and the illyabos on two other occasions, and they did not disappoint either!

I WILL say this - if you're a lover of sandwiches and flavors, come with another person. It's a great thing to share 2 sandwiches between 2 people, and since the sammies are sliced in half, it's pre-made for sharing! With one person. Only one other. Find your favorite friend...

It also comes with a side of pickles in a little plastic bag. LOVE going with people who dislike pickles. I'm in pickle heaven...
author: Lily W.

description: I moved to SF from the east coast and have only been sad for the most part with the sandwiches.  Sandwiches at Deli Board are next level shit - hug worthy even. Will be back!
author: Aaron P.

description:
This place doesn't need my review but I'll do one anyway because it was so damn good. I was bright three by a work colleague yesterday. Never heard of it before. I had the Carze great sandwich on awesome bread. Put together really well. It reminded of to-gos but 10 times better.

I like the no nonsense taking orders by one person and orders going to the back of house and not having my sandwich made in front of me. Not sure why I liked it but I did. 

I come from NY where we have the best delis in the world. This was a modern take on a great deli sandwich and everything about it was awesome.
author: Seth W.

description: I spent $18 on a sandwich that was so salty I could barely eat it. Unfortunately, there are few food choices near the hall of justice so when a Google search came up with a sandwich shop, my fellow jurors and I were all over it. We all walked out wishing we could convict them of price gouging. Seriously? My sandwich was $16, add tip and I spent $18. For a freaking sandwich people. For $16 I wanted this sandwich to be amazeballs. Instead, I felt dick to my stomach the rest of the day. It was so salty I couldn't even finish it. Don't get the pastrami and roast beef.
author: Thompson M.

description: Here me out. I normally wouldn't recommend someone order the one thing the place isn't known for, in this case, the token veggie sandwich. Just like how I wouldn't recommend ordering chicken at a steakhouse. However, I'm making a definite exception here with their J-Ocean falafel sandwich is amazing! The falafels are so crunchy and flavorful, complemented beautifully by the avocado, muenster cheese, and jalapenos. It comes out piping hot and o so satisfying! You'd hardly notice the meatlessness.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
This is, by far, the most expensive sandwich I've bought. By the same token, it's the yummiest. 

Purchased the $$$ + it was DA BOMB. Tender, juicy meat coupled w/ freshly toasted bread makes for a great bite. LOVE

$$$ x2 = $32.45
author: Julie L.

description: To be fair they do stuff the sandwiches so full of meat it's hard to take a bite. But for $17, I'll definitely not be returning. I got the Zeke and it was bland to me. Ike's is wayyyyyyyyyyyy better and less money too.
author: Amber C.

description:
The first thing I did after I arrived in San Francisco was look on Yelp for a place to eat. Naturally, I was starving after a 6 hr flight. Saw that Deli Board was close to my hotel and had awesome reviews, so decided to give it a try. 

Wow was my sandwich good. Nothing fancy or crazy, just a great sandwich. I had the Fay, which was a great take on a Turkey/Swiss. Fresh Avocado's, Coleslaw and Cherry Peppers take this sandwich to another level. The bread was soft, yet crunchy. Over ally the food was really fantastic for a quick bite. Service was quick and friendly. Place is simple and clean. Highly recommend.
author: Ryan C.

description: This place is expensive for a deli but it's really good and worth it.  The two sandwiches I've tried were great, especially the Kuip.  The sandwiches are pretty big but perfectly built so they don't fall apart and they're served piping hot.  It can get busy but they make the food fast.  The staff is nice and you can usually find a place to sit.  Minus one star because they should have better and bigger drinks.
author: george c.

description:
Let me start right out and say that the sandwiches are delicious! The bread doesn't get soggy and keeps its crunch. We ordered two sandwiches-- the $$$ and the Carzle  for $34+ excluding drinks! The sandwiches are small and the place is not even in the better neighborhood that's why
I opted for 3 stars! $15 for a 6" Sandwich is just too much! It's smaller than it looks in pic too!
author: PixieD D.

description: Best sandwiches in SF! I've tried to order different menu items each time I go, and each time I leave full, happy, and with a new favorite menu item. Slightly pricier than your average sandwich but worth every penny b/c these are not your average sandwiches. Go NOW!
author: Dylan H.

description: Best sandwiches and salads, even for a pescatarian. Gotta love this place & the pickles
author: Andreea C.

description:
We were looking for a lunch spot within walking distance of the conference center and found this place on Yelp. We were encouraged when the place was filled with people that worked in the vicinity. Or not, the guy in the line behind us drove 10 minutes to there. 

The seating is cosy and so be prepared to be close to your neighbors, but the food was simply awesome. We had something different and everyone was thoroughly enjoying their food. 

I will be back.
author: Gavin M.

description: Great sandwiches! I ordered the zeke without pickles and it was absolutely amazing, only thing is there wasn't really much space to sit to eat.
author: Bree M.

description:
My coworker was going to get a sandwich from here and asked if I wanted to tag along.  How can I say no to a sandwich? (Cue in appropriate Joey Tribbiani GIF).

They have a lot of sandwiches to choose from, or you can customize your own.  I wasn't feeling particularly creative, so I went for the Fatty Matty because tuna salad, falafel, and hummus sounded good.

It was love at first bite!  I would never thought that tuna salad, falafel, and hummus would be good together.  Oh, but they do!  And I added some of their stadium mustard for a little kick.  And the French roll was the perfect type of bread for the soft texture of this sandwich.

I really like the vibe of the restaurant, especially the music they play on vinyl.  And the employees are enthusiastic and really friendly.  When my coworker and I came in, she was surprised there was no line.  But after we ordered, a huge line formed behind us.  I like to think we brought them in ;)

But I'm pretty sure their delicious sandwiches is what really drew them in.  I'm definitely coming back to try more off their sandwich board.
author: Vira P.

description: Solid, solid sandwich. My Jewish friend from Cleveland took us here and it didn't disappoint. Definitely a sandwich for sandwich lovers, but has a price to match it. You're looking at about $17 for a pretty small deli sandwich. Is it worth the price? Ehh, probably not to be honest, but that doesn't mean it isn't good. I had the A Stud last time I went which had pastrami, jalapenos, cheddar, and avacado on a garlic bun. The meat is stacked thick and makes for a great ratio with tasty bread. My biggest gripe is while the ratio is great, the sandwich itself just isn't that big. I was still hungry enough to have a second. For $17 I was hoping to be nice and full. Also make sure you come early, the line gets backed up around lunch and it can take up to half an hour to get your order made.
author: Patrick S.

description:
This is about as close as your going to get to a Jewish Deli without going to Manhattan.  I had the Ruprecht which is full of corn beef, pastrami, swiss cheese and thousand island dressing.  It comes on a perfect Dutch Crunch roll.  

The only thing stopping me from coming here more frequent is the lack of parking and the douche bag who tried to steal my sandwich.  That's how good they are that people can't wait.   So when they call your name, make sure you claim your sandwich.
author: James H.

description:
You will not be bored with lunch from Deli Board. 

Located on a busy block of mid-Folsom, Deli Board puts out some serious sandwiches. 
Inside, the space is clean and modern with polished concrete floors and walls adorned with giants pictures of (what else?) sandwiches. 

The extensive menu is a sandwich lover's heaven; there is something for everyone.  With heaps of corned beef, Romanian pastrami, Swiss cheese, cole slaw, pickled onion, and thousand island dressing on a perfectly toasted Dutch crunch roll, the Ruprecht ($12) will make you never be satisfied with a simple Reuben again.  Served on a toasty garlic roll, the porky ($11), featuring Black Forest ham, bacon, American cheese, and pickles, will please lovers of tasty salted pig parts. All sandwiches are accompanied by crispy, house-made dill pickles that have just the right balance of spices and acidity. Those choosing to avoid meat will love the huge "phat" Greek salad ($10) with fresh, crispy romaine, imported feta, calamari olives, cucumber, pepperoncini, and cherry tomatoes. 

Service is friendly and fast. The waitstaff seems to genuinely enjoy helping diners choose the right sandwich from the extensive menu.  Despite the rapid service, the lines do get long at lunchtime, so either come early (before 11:30) or late (after 1:15) or just chill out and be prepared to wait.

While a little pricey, Deli Board has some of the best sandwiches in The City.
author: CJ G.

description: WARNING: the sandwiches are a lot smaller than they look in these pictures! I paid $16 for a sandwich that had maybe 3-4 slices of meat. Ridiculous , will not return
author: Tammy P.

description: A $20 sandwich better be the best damn sandwich I've ever had. Sadly, this was not. The spicy peppers were delicious but the price tag is just to high to justify going back.
author: amy W.

description:
No joke, best sandwich in the city. I've tried too many to list and each one has been fabulous. Definitely check out the board for their specials. I've never been disappointed, even when venturing out of my comfort zone to try something new. You can't go wrong here, they should just hand people darts and a blindfold to choose sandwiches. 

Love this place any day of the week (except Sunday, they close). 

Do your self a favor and eat here, you won't regret it.
author: Jesse P.

description:
Update:
This popular Howard street sandwich shop/ catering kitchen is moving to 1058 Folsom, just 2 doors down from Extreme Pizza. And they'll be expanding their hours to include breakfast, plus new menu items and plenty of seating space (no more waiting on the sidewalk). To open beginning of September.
author: Luis C.

description:
I was excited to finally try a sandwich from Deli Board after hearing a friend rave about it.  Unfortunately, I didn't completely agree with her.  Although the sandwich I had (munsoned) was good, it wasn't that great.  The sandwich was a tad bit dry.  My husband said his sandwich was dry as well (he had the mish).

Too bad...I was really excited about this place...
author: Rose A.

description: Very good sandwiches! Possibly the best I've had in SoMa!! Good tip, get there early to beat the crowd, because the lunch line can get long! Only negative is the fact that they have odd hours but if you're that good, you can get away with that! Haha! This is a must-try!
author: Pablito R.

description:
I love good sandwich and Deli Board definitely delivers!

Where Ike's is all about the sauce, deli board is all about the meat, and man do they give you a lot of meat!

I've tried a few different sandwiches here recently. The Ron is pretty good, it's essentially a good cheese steak with TONs of meat plus some avocado. 

The real winner here though (of the ones I've tried so far) is the "$$$" - pronounced "money" by the lady who handed me the sandwich. Really delicious warm and gooey with TONS of flavor and meaty goodness! It contains brisket, corned beef, kosher salami, muenster cheese, cheddar cheese, cherry peppers, cole slaw, Board sauce all on a warm french roll. A delicious combination!

Be warned that you may have to wait, especially on a weekday lunch, but Deli Board is definitely worth the wait.
author: Ely L.

description:
Baravelli: "You can't come in unless you give the password." 
Professor Wagstaff: "Well, what is the password?" 
Baravelli: "Aw, no. You gotta tell me. Hey, I tell ya what I do. I give you three guesses. It's the name of a fish." 
Professor Wagstaff: "Is it Mary?" 
Baravelli: [laughing] "At's-a no fish!" 
Professor Wagstaff: "She isn't? Well, she drinks like one! ...Let me see... Is it Sturgeon?" 
Baravelli: "Aw, you-a craze. A "sturgeon", he's a doctor cuts you open when-a you sick. Now I give you one more chance." 
Wagstaff: "I got it! Haddock. 
Baravelli: "At's a-funny, I got a "haddock" too." 
Wagstaff: "What do you take for a "haddock"?" 
Baravelli: "Sometimes I take an aspirin..." 

A deli as a speakeasy? Well, sorta since you are verboten from entering their semi-hidden premises on Howard. I had no idea and was immediately reprimanded to stay outside where my order would be taken. Somebody tell me the password! Is it "Swordfish"? Y'see, the place is only open for about three hours around lunchtime and just during the work week. The menu hangs on a clipboard on the window, while office workers, slackers and other assorted types are either chatting with each other or staring at their mobile devices out on the sidewalk, all waiting for their orders. 

I was forewarned the order could take a half-hour, so it was a good thing it was kind of a slow Friday at work. Their menu rotates daily, so don't count on a sandwich you read about on the site being available to order. For the most part, the sandwiches are $9, and I went for the "Mikey Likes It", which was a pastrami cheesesteak on a toasted French roll with pickles, peppers and their "board sauce" - which I was guessing is a sweeter variation of Russian dressing (see photo). I don't really know, but it was one of the most satisfying sandwiches I've had since my last visit to Ike's. 

I also went for the $4 cup of the Smoky Split Pea Soup, which was rich, hearty and chock full of fresh vegetables (see photo). Even by the time I found a place to sit to eat, it was tongue-burning hot. I was also happy to see a mini Ziploc bag of peppers and a hunk of "board" pickle (see photo). I would definitely try to arrange to come back on another slow Friday, but I see on their Facebook page that they're moving a bit further south to Cleveland Street to a real storefront. Hopefully that means they'll keep longer hours ands even provide seating. That's all good news, though I think a food truck could be ideal if they're trying to keep their overhead costs down. 

FOOD - 4 stars...one of the better sammies in town...but only if you know the password...for about three hours a day 
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...you stand outside 
SERVICE - 3 stars...it comes out in a brown paper bag in about fifteen days 
TOTAL - 4 stars...the complicated process doesn't deter me from wanting another one
author: Ed U.

description: Went here after a couple of years. My favorite sandwich place in SF. Had the Boca - delicious. A bit pricey but the quality of the meat is amazing. The bread is great. The hot sauce is very spicy but really good.
author: Sai M.

description: Don't be discouraged if you see a line! It moves quick! Only suggestion to improve is the staff's knowledge of menu ingredients. I wish they knew if the falafels were vegan so I sub it for the chicken in my salad.
author: C.K. H.

description:
I was craving a fat sandwich after my run one afternoon and decided to give Deli Board a try. I was not disappointed at all. The sandwiches are huge and they never skimp on the meat. I had the Skully
(turkey breast, kosher salami, muenster cheese, american cheese, jalapenos, mayo, Board sauce, cole slaw, dutch crunch)--very recommended! Great flavors and a kick to it from the jalapeños and sauce. They were very fast too, I was there for less than 5 mins. Can't wait to try more!
author: Shannon W.

description: I haven't been here in 2-3 years but coming back I noticed the huge price hike. Sad to say I won't be back...our meal for 2 sandwiches + drinks turned out to be $40 (without including tip). Unless you're okay with spending $20 for lunch- I'd personally rather grab a sandwich somewhere else...
author: Belle X.

description:
This place bills itself as a Midwestern style deli, and I can't speak to the authenticity of that, having successfully avoided any prolonged periods of stay in the Midwest.

I can, however, vouch for the fact that their sandwiches truly stand apart from other delis and sandwich spots here in the city. Even compared to places I love, like Ikes's, this place has a unique flavor from the bread and meats, to the coleslaw fillings. And yes, the sandwiches are well proportioned. I read a couple of reviews that mention that the sandwiches can be eaten for two meals but if you have a hearty appetite such as my own (I'm big boned), one sandwich is just about right.

I recommend the Samantha, which is essentially a Philly cheesesteak. The Boca also appears to be a staple there.

Lastly, the reason I can't give it five stars, is the price. Everything is just couple dollars more than it should be. That being said of course, I will be back because I'm a dumb San Franciscan.
author: Baron C.

description: Impressive sandwich!  Had the Mina. Bread was not a huge, hard loaf in which your mouth can never fit over upon taking bites. This is a competitive advantage for this sandwich, esp. for women.  Light on their own custom "Board sauce", which is mayo based. Fresh and flavorful pastrami and roast beef. It's warm and bread has a nice freshly baked, chewy element to it. It doesn't have the veggies, such as chopped lettuce, in which The Submarine Center still holds on to top sandwich shop in the Bay Area, although it comes pretty darn close!
author: Ella H.

description:
Solid spot for a filling, heavy sandwich.. The line gets long around lunchtime during the work week but it goes pretty quick.

I ordered the  falafel one (forgot the name). Why did i get a vegetarian sandwich at a place known for their meats.... beats me.... but it was surprisingly good for a meatless sandwich. They give very generous with their portions and throw in their house made cole slaw, pickles, and jalapenos. 

For a sandwich at $14, it's definitely on the pricier side, hence the missing star, but if you need a meat craving satisfied, this is your place to go to.
author: Angela K.

description:
Tasty and fresh ingredients but way overpriced.  Nothing to write home about.  

I forgot to mention the free pickle?  Free pickles here with your $20 sandwich.
author: Big D.

description:
Visited a friend near by so we decided to grab some sandwiches from Deli Board. I had no idea what he ordered but they were absolutely delicious! The meat was delicious and nowhere near dry.

I'll definitely be back for more!
author: Mabel Y.

description: You definitely can't go wrong with any of their Romanian pastrami sandwiches. Its a very hearty sandwich and fills the tummy for sure paired with a Mexican Coke. Also, their pickles are good. I've only been here on the weekends and parking seems to be ok the surrounding neighborhood is so so. If they expand outside of SF that would be nice and I'm sure they would do well since the sandwich game has stepped up over the past several years.
author: Carguy S.

description:
SoMa used to be a district of industrial business and this area is truly transforming.   The Deli Board is a hidden location in SoMa district and across from a public park (basketball court and playground).  We even notice by standers and passerby comments - "Wonder what is this place?" as they don't have a typical business sign beside a spray painted "1058" in the center of the building front. 

Parking -
The location does not offer much parking during the weekday, but you will probably have better luck during weekends. No parking meters!

Carzle - brisket, romanian pastrami, provolone, cherry peppers, pickles, cole slaw, Board sauce, garlic french roll.
The garlic French roll is lightly toasted and packed with brisket, pastrami, and cherry peppers.  The provolone melted nicely as the board sauce gave it a little kick each bite.  The cole slaw and pickles add a little crunch.

 
Zeke - turkey breast, avocado, bacon, cream cheese, pickled onion, sprouts, mayo, french roll.
The French roll tied the turkey breast to the center, while the bacon, cream cheese and avocado where squeezed tightly that my wife said she didn't taste much of the avocado.   The sprouts and mayo float on top and didn't overpower the overall sandwich as sprouts tend to give off its own green taste.

Both sandwiches came with homemade pickles in a Ziploc bag as we took the order To-Go.

Overall, the sandwiches were good but for the price of each sandwich, you better save up to keep on enjoying each bite.
author: Mike T.

description:
** This review is for the catering**

Outstanding service. I placed a mid sized catering order for some custom items that weren't on the menu slightly 24 hours before the event. While describing to Adam what I needed I had my finger crossed the entire time hoping they could accommodate. Without hesitation he took my order and handle the transaction with ease. There was 1 minor hiccup, but they corrected quickly without anyone noticing. 

Thank you guys for the outstanding work and professionalism.
author: Samuel C.

description: We had the Paulette (chicken salad with  bacon and fixings) and it was one of the best sandwiches I have ever had!
author: Linda C.

description:
Whoa Whoa Whoa! Hold on Ike's, you have a contender! Ever since my friend introduced my to Deli Board, I've been a huge fan. Love their sandwiches! They do not skimp you out of meat. In fact, they are very generous in the amount of meats and toppings in their sandwiches. My goal is to try each one down the menu list. 

Tip: their spicy mustard goes great with any sandwich.
author: Richard T.

description: Probably the most amazing sandwich in SF...but $16 for a sandwich is just uncalled for. If you're going to charge $16 for a sandwich, at least offer water cups or some type of side. Unless your sandwich can make me fly I'd rather not cough up $20 (tax+tip) for a sandy. :)
author: Paul A.

description:
Wow what a sandwich and I mean life-changing I was simply amazing how good this sandwich was. A buddy and I split halves on each sandwiches so to have a different taste of selections. 

All in all just tried to sandwich it's worth the $20 bill

Must try for any one in the area avoid lunch hours it gets crazy packed
author: Angel S.

description:
I scoffed when I saw that sandwiches were averaging $12. I was fuming that I had to wait over 10 minutes for my sandwich. But..when I took that first bite, I was in sandwich kingdom. 

The bread was hot and crispy on the outside. Inside the bread were my chosen ingredients generously piled in. The turkey was super fresh and probably three times the amount you'd find in a typical deli. 

The pickle on the side was better than icing on the cake!

Go ahead! Treat yourself! It is the worth the wait!
author: Mimi T.

description:
Deli Board is awesome! The sandwiches are amazing. The bread they use is not too soft that it falls apart, and it's not too hard that it tears your mouth to pieces. It's just right. They're generous with their fillings, and it's always fresh and delicious. The people are super friendly, and there's usually a line out the door during lunch time, which is a sign of loyal customers.

The downside is that there's usually a line out the door during lunch time. The price you pay for good food, I guess.
author: Kenneth C.

description:
Went to eat here and not expecting much out of it. I was trying to visit all the 1000 plus review spots on my trip to SF. This place has lots of hipsters eating here. They seem to be always busy and the food comes out quick. My friend ordered us the "Boca" a half corned beef half pastrami sandwich. The soft bread is wonderful to the meat. It has some pickles and a sauce inside as well. The meat is cut down into tiny chunks where it melts in your mouth. The meat to bread ratio is perfect. This is one of the best sandwiches I have ever eaten. It cost $15 bucks but well worth it. I'll pay this again any day for the masterpiece. Yes, I enjoyed this sandwich more than Ike's!

They also have mustard and four hot sauces that you can put on. 


Recommendation: BOCA sandwich
author: Andy N.

description: Literally a perfect sandwich. I didn't know they were served hot, so the cheese is all melty. I had the Leroy Brown. Amazing. I love the use of American cheese. If you're in the area you have to try this. I heard the line can be out the door, so I went early (11am). It was a small line and service was super quick. There isn't much seating. Also having Dr. Browns soda is a nice touch. In my opinion, it's better than Ike's.
author: Knolan H.

description: AMAZING food. Been coming here for about four years but am just getting around to Yelp now. We end up here at least once a month but have been through many months of weekly visits. I appreciate the options for those who don't eat the classics, like pastrami and corned beef, and the rotating daily specials to try out new combos. It's hard not to order a BK or Jezerski when given the chance, but we've been delving into the Deli Board salad world lately and especially enjoy the Board Cobb. Yes, it's definitely pricier than other options, but I'd say worth it. The sandwiches are so big I usually end up eating half for lunch and returning to the rest later in the day. And it always tastes SO GOOD.
author: Rose J.

description: We know deli and this was awesome deli! First, there were lots of specialty sandwiches you could choose from or a 'create your own' option. Sandwiches for the meat eaters and non, with great bread and special sauce (which you could either get on the side or none at all). We waited in line for about three minutes to place an order at the counter, then grabbed the last 2-top in the small dining space, about 8-10 tables inside and two tables outside. Food was delivered to our table in less than 10 minutes. And, bottled water was free since we ate in the restaurant as opposed to taking sandwiches to go. The corned beef, pastrami, ham, and brisket were tender and flavorful and there were lots of cheese and other sandwich toppings from which you could choose. And the accompanying pickles (served in zip lock bags) were terrific like they were pulled out of an old fashioned pickle barrel. Prices were a bit high for a sandwich but portion sizes were AMPLE-we could only eat half and took the rest home. Highly recommend and if there is no seating, there is a park across the street a block or two away.
author: Alicia W.

description: The godlike sandwiches are worth every penny. Try the Fatty Matty. It's better to eat one of these alone because you honestly shouldn't be talking and eating. You should be experiencing nirvana.
author: Dee D.

description: If there is a better sandwich place in this entire world, nay, galaxy, I don't know if I could handle it. I just finished the Mezman and literally cannot come up with enough good things to say about it, so I won't even try here. It's not every day I'm looking for the best sandwich ever, but whenever I am I now know where to go.
author: Justin S.

description:
Just such a good place for lunch. Small place, but it's expected for close to downtown SF. 
Ordered the Hermine Sandwich. The meat was exquisite. Piled pretty high too. The bread was nicely toasted and very soft. The Haba Haba sauce they have on the side is good. Not too spicy, but gives the sandwich that nice little kick. I wish they cut the pickles on the side more. Was kinda messy biting into a whole chunk of pickle. But that's a minor detail.
author: Timothy J.

description:
Holy cow, I was lucky enough to dine with the gods of sandwich making. Normally when I order a sandwich it usually comes out in a huge, piling heap of messiness. It's a struggle I like to avoid when in public. But these pieces of art are carefully constructed in a way that packs flavor and juiciness without messiness. I'm still dreaming of this sandwich today, bless the mila. 

+ its extremely filling, well worth the price
author: Janna L.

description: Ok, definitely one of the few best sandwiches I've eaten but expect to pay above average price for not a really large sandwich.  The meat is done to perfection and the proportions just right in the sandwich.  A must visit if you are on jury duty but also a hard choice if you had only one meal and between this place or Turtle Tower, which are both within walking distance, I would go to turtle tower as it's half the price for delicious pho.  The $15 per day that you get paid for jury duty would not even cover your one sandwich here but it's still oooh la la delicious and worth the $$$.
author: Anna C.

description:
I've only been here once when I was in the city but the quality of the sandwich I had was definitely on point! One of the best in fact, so much so I will make it a point to stop by again soon.
We came right as the place opened and by the time we were seated the place was already filling up. The lady running the front was very smiley and kind and the sandwiches came out quickly. I can't wait to go back and try some more!
author: Heather J.

description:
My darling, thoughtful boyfriend had a Zeke delivered to me at school today after my lunch plans fell through. It has turkey, avocado, cream cheese, bacon, sprouts, and pickled onions, all served on a sweet french roll.  At $10.85, this is the same price point as Ike's. I like both DB and Ike's, so I'm not going to declare my preference for one over the other. I did like this sandwich. The portions of each ingredient were very generous. A ton of turkey, maybe half a tub of cream cheese, an entire avocado, and four slices of bacon were in my sandwich...at least that's how it tasted. 

I actually had a bite of the boca last night. I think it was better than the Zeke, but definitely not as healthy.
author: Jenn C.

description:
So happy I finally got to try Deli Board after having it on my bookmarked list for almost two years!

This place truly does make a killer sandwich, because it doesn't fit in your mouth! (TWSS...?). The meats are always stacked high and all the ingredients taste fresh and well made. I got the Zeke and the Boca and both were full of flavor. Although I admit, I skimped on the mayo in the Zeke and I think it could have been a little more moist, but the flavor was totally there. Yum!

I was a little off put by this place since seriously I didn't even see a sign that said "Deli Board" but I figured this is probably the only super popular sandwich place around the area and thankfully ended up being right. If you go during an odd hour like I did, no line!

Totally worth the two year wait!
author: Lorrie M.

description: One of the best sandwiches i've ever had, the Boca.  The picture i took didn't really come out well, but i feel that i didn't get as much meat as other pictures I see on yelp, but still a lot. I'm not sure if the bread is made fresh here but it sure tasted like it.  My sandwich came out nice and warm.  I like how thin they slice their meat, it makes taking a bite effortless. Def. wanna try some other sandos when i get the chance, worth the price of admission.  Yo balls to the walls or not at alls, go big.
author: Spencer W.

description:
This place offers a great selection of very tasty sandwiches.  The only thing is it is SUPER far away from my office, and in a bit of a sketchy location. 

While the sandwhiches are great, I doubt I'll be back, since they are SUPER overpriced ($11-13 for a sandwich?).
author: Rachael S.

description: This place is legit, and you need to give them your money - trust me. Best corned beef sandwich in town. Best quality of meat I've tasted, amazing layering, delicious slaw, great pickles, fast service, I could go on but honestly if you're looking for a phenomenal sandwich just come here!
author: Noam S.

description: Well, if you're going to be in this neighborhood you have to eat here. The "Mick" sandwich is basically a slice of heaven on bread.
author: Sarah S.

description:
This place gets my nipples hard.

Not a chain.

Way grubbin sammie - Boca!!!

It was free (but won't always be).

I'll be back, these sams are the shiz.

Ya feel me?
author: Johnny L.

description:
Ever since my phone autocorrected my last name to 'nemesis' in an email to UCLA's nursing school, I have been loathe to take the easy way.

Why not take a few more minutes to get a quality good rather than a cheap fix? The aroma of a just made Blue Bottle drip definitely trumps the leftover hazelnut coffee in some random cafe's carafe. A cone of Humphrey Slocombe or a year old ice cream from your corner liquor store? This isn't to sound preachy, I myself have taken far worse shortcuts than bitter coffee or even an unintended diabolical last name.

When the Deli Board popped up I was intrigued, especially when the maintenance man in the building where I work asked me if I knew about it. He told me his theory that they're running drugs out of the storefront, but that's okay because the sandwiches are so amazing, the people very nice, etc, and even with his arthritis he doesn't mind standing in the cold outside.

The Boca is undoubtedly one of the most amazingly sinful sandwiches I have ever tasted. Get this: pastrami, corned beef, brisket and muenster cheese.  If I'm going to have a coronary, this is the way to go down. The meat and cheese marry and create a delicious offspring that is greater than the sum of its parts.    

The Boca is by far my favorite, but the Mikey Likes It and Rueben's Cousin are also delicious and might be good choices if you don't feel like eating three different kinds of meat at once. Complimentary pickles are awesome, and sometimes when I just want a snack I think about walking up to the Board to see if I can score any.

They deliver around the area on bikes, but part of the fun is standing on a nondescript stretch of Soma salivating over the good smells emanating from the storefront. Besides, if you take the easy way, there's no telling what will happen.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Today was my third day of jury duty at the Hall of Justice so I look nowhere else but Yelp to hop me find a good lunch spot. 

So I'm clearly in the minority here but I have to say I wasn't super impressed. I got the Boca and sure it was good, but it didn't impress me all that much and clearly isn't the best sandwich shop in the City. Due to the overwhelming positive comments on here I was expecting more, especially since the sandwich and a can of Diet Coke cost me $17.93!!

Tomorrow I'll try AK Subs and see how it stacks up. Happy lunching!
author: Doug V.

description: This is the best sandwich shop in San Francisco...you have to just go and try it, that's all I can really say because anything else would not do it proper justice!
author: Amanda G.

description:
*expensive sandwiches that are totally worth it*
#chickensalad
#greathotsauce

This place was flat out, unexpectedly amazing. I'm used to a quick cheap hoagie or sandwich and to that point, was shocked to see that most sandwiches were 11 or 12 bucks. Reluctant at first, as soon as i sat down, I saw that it was worth it. 

Nothing crazy or fancy to note about this place their food speaks for themselves and they have a plethora of fun combinations that leave me wanting to go back. The chicken salad sandwich was seriously incredible. First, it came out warm (who knew), and with some other sliced meat. But the flavor was all there. Top it off with a great kosher deli pickle and it was totally worth it. 

Great ghost pepper hot sauce too. I thought ghost peppers were deadly, but this was a pleasant addition to my sandwich.
author: Kevin T.

description:
If you like sandwiches, this is the spot! 

Hubert- super good!
Turkey with roast beef, bacon on Dutch crunch

Hermine- super good!
Pastrami, brisket, corned beef on Dutch crunch

RLMB- super good!
Roast beef and bacon on Dutch crunch

The sandwiches are pretty filling and you could prob share one if you don't have a big appetite. 

Also if you like pickles, all sandos come with a bag of 2 thick cuts of pickle
author: Jane M.

description: Got zeke n it was deliciousness. Highly recommend it.
author: Kilim C.

description:
Dutch Crunch and Sweet French Bread!
That's what makes Deli Board special!
Well, that and the fact that they pack their sandwiches full of delicious cuts of meat!

Located in the SOMA section of SF, Deli Board is a small sandwich shop that's only open for a few hours a day. Pretty much a lunch only joint.

Their menu features many tasty sounding sandwiches, all of which you can tweak to your liking. My buddy and I came here for an early lunch on a Friday morning. We got here right when they opened so we were the only people in the shop. We ordered;

Boca- Corned beef, pastrami, brisket, muenster cheese, Board sauce, brown mustard & pickles. Then I added jalapenos, slaw & bacon. Served on Dutch Crunch

Gold-n-Berg-n-stein- Corned beef, pastrami, kosher salami, muenster cheese, house slaw, house 1000 island on sweet French bread. We also added pesto.

Both sandwiches were packed full of meat. Both sandwiches featured amazing bread that was perfectly toasted on the outside and warm and fluffy in the middle.  Both sandwiches were overall amazing. 

Prices here are reasonable and the service was fast and friendly. 

If I lived in SF I'd put the Deli board on my sandwich shop rotation.
author: Craig R.

description:
On the corner of hooker and hipster lays some of the best sandwiches I've had west of the Mississippi. What make them so great. Hmm could it be the layers and layers of thinly carved deli meat, the mystery sauce, or the perfectly toasted yet super soft rolls?? 

All I know is that I just shelled out $11 for a sandwich without batting an eyelid (and would gladly return in a heartbeat). If you're like me and think that paying $11 for a sandwich is akin to highway robbery, I tell you it is worth it!! The sandwiches are huge and delicious and some of the best I've had..
author: Ritu K.

description:
Whoah. Feels weird to not be in camp Deli Board is bomb. I'm feeling more of a 3.5 but I'll round it up to a four since they do have quality sandwiches.

I ordered the Stephanie which was pretty good. The most salient point about the sandwich was that it was actually warm?! Not that I haven't had a warm sandwich before, but the warmth and the melted cheese and crispy bacon all oozed together really well creating quite the good sandwich. The dutch crunch was superb--if there's one thing I love about Deli Board, it's definitely the quality of the bread.

I think my biggest turn off is definitely the wait time. I guess I wouldn't mind the wait time if the food was the most mind blowing thing that I've ever had, but it wasn't. I waited probably about half an hour for my sandwich? I know that stores that are mad popular can't be worried about wait time when they have so many customers, but if I'm waiting for a sandwich that was good (maybe) at best, I'm really not quite sure that's worth my time.

tldr; decent sandwiches, long long long wait. don't bother if you're not a hardcore sandwich fan
author: Jasmine X.

description: Seriously good melt in your mouth sandos! I highly recommend the Boca. If you like spicy, I'd recommend the Carzle. All their sandwiches look amazing though. Such a treat to eat here!
author: Jennifer G.

description: Great simple lunch spot. Not the typical sand which/salad menu. Salad dressing and pickles were homemade as well.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
Got there a little after 11am and there was no line. 
The Boca was great. Not as much meat or as big or impressive as the RLM (which i tried as well.) but very good just the same. 

The RLM was impressive. the salami gave it a small peppery hint to the sandwich. i think a little horseradish would be awesome. It reminded me of a french dip of sorts.

Make sure you add your fixin's. Also they do not take phone orders only for catering.
author: Craig I.

description: Nom nom nom. Amazing sandwich!  Had the Carzle because of all of the good reviews here.  So tasty!  Spicy, toasty hot.  Great amount of meat and right proportion of fixings.  Impressed that it wasn't a messy, gloopy mess.  Held together really well right to the last bite.  Was completely and utterly satisfied! Quick service at 1pm on a Saturday.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I'd been looking for a time when I could come here for years, and we finally had the occasion during a conference at the Moscone Center. However, we were both disappointed with our sandwiches and salad. The sandwiches were overly large and difficult to eat, but not very tasty. The salad we tried, Kinda Fatty, was very heavy but didn't come together at all. The dry falafel sat separately from the tuna salad and odd bits of cheese. We didn't try anything with pastrami or brisket, which maybe would be better.
author: Lisa K.

description: Best sandwich  spot I ever had.this spot is crazy the Philly cheese steak on the special is the best I ever had I come all the way from the east bay to come out here for this spot
author: Johnny B.

description:
This has to be the best sandwhich I have ever eaten in my entire life! The meat is cooked perfect and the bread is perfect as well. It's not a bread over load in my mouth is nice and thin. 

Also the service is even better. I forgot to grab and water and instead of waiting back in line and paying she gave me a free bottled water!
author: Blake G.

description: After his first bite of the Samantha, my hubby said "FIVE stars!"  He never gives out 5 stars.  The Samantha was brisket sandwich heaven.  All the ingredients were in perfect harmony with each other and a whole sandwich was big enough for the two of us to split.  We would have had to spend an arm and a leg if we had both gotten sandwiches because they start around $14.  That's madness for a girl from AZ, but according to the insanely long line out the door, price doesn't matter in SF as long as you know you're getting quality.  Try to come just before or just after lunchtime, otherwise, it could take 30 minutes just to order due to the huge demand.
author: Alyse H.

description: I was working in the city the other day and stopped to have lunch here. The place is really small but the food makes up for it. Everything on the menu looks good.... I Had the turkey, avocado sandwich, Zeek they call it. It was about 1pm, and it was packed, line all the way to the outside. Well worth it if you have the time.
author: Erik H.

description: The variety of sandwiches in the San Francisco food scene is amazing for a sandwich lover like me, from the overflowing Ike's sandwich to the touted Roli Roti porchetta. Deli Board is the hidden gem of sandwich spots, deep down in Soma where only those in-the-know frequent for one of the best sandwiches in the city. It's an Ike's-style sandwich, on the heavier side with meat, sauce, and cheese, but somehow it's lighter on the palate, with a better formed sandwich that doesn't leave you feeling weighed down. Their Dutch Crunch is honestly the best that I've had, sourced from The Rye Project just around the corner. Although on the expensive side, their sandwiches boast a hefty amount of meat, to the extent that I end up taking half out. My favorite sandwich is the Fay, made with roasted turkey, your choice of cheese, Board sauce, and avocado. It's packed tightly so your fillings aren't oozing out the side, but you get some of each ingredient in every bite. The garlic Dutch Crunch has the perfect crunch and zing of garlic that brings the whole sandwich together. The size is much more manageable than the behemoths from Ike's and nothing is too sweet or too salty. Deli Board is my go-to for an indulgent sandwich that keeps the tummy happy throughout the day!
author: Ashley T.

description:
I'm giving this place 2 stars because the price is outrageous. 

The food is great. 

I've gotten lunch at Deliboard probably 40 times in the last 2 years. But after their last price hike, you can't get a sandwich and a can of soda for less than $15... which is outrageous. 

Tony Baloney's is 2 blocks away at 7th and Howard, makes killer sandwiches, and is literally half the price of Deliboard. 

Sorry Deliboard, no more outrageously expensive sandwiches for me.
author: Chris P.

description: happens to find this place while looking on the web. when there today the 1st time for lunch. nice little set up pretty neat and clean. service wise was good and prompt. actually they bring u the order when is ready. reason for only 3 star 1st time trying there sandwich and it was ok. order the RUBY Claire.. had to change from french roll to dutch crunch and that was even better. just the dutch crunch itself made the meat and dressing all stand out pretty good,but not excellent yet. there is alot more room for improving. will for sure be back to try all other sandwich. is really too bad that they don't make the $$$$$ and the VHAT.. I would very much like to try these 2 sandwich.This is a good place to get lunch.price rise is pretty fair.. recommended for people that want to grab lunch fast.
author: Tommy M.

description: Off the hook nothing more need be said Leroy Brown it was really really good the  hot sauces is spicy as fuck
author: johnny W.

description:
So, here is the deal.  This place is just about the stupidest place that I have ever had a sandwich in my life.  There is absolutely no reason to pay the ridicules cost for a sandwich that this place charges and the energy could not be in more bland and boring...  I grew up in San Francisco and there was a time where the expectation of a good sandwich shop was more like Lucca or Molinari or Roxie's or but NOT Subways!  Go to Tony Baloney's down the street if you want a killer sandwich at a fair price with interesting decor.

Customer service was cool but you know, when you charge these prices you are making a statement and I get it and no thanks, like I said--- I grew up here and this sort of pricing segregation is not something that is cool, it clouds my karma.
author: ein bier bitte k.

description: Delicious Cleveland-style sandwiches.  I haven't had a bad selection yet.  Get there before 11:45 to have less of a wait.
author: Mark T.

description:
Deli Board 101

Lesson 1: Look at their menu beforehand at www.deliboardsf.com.
Lesson 2: Check 'The Board' for daily specials.
Lesson 3: Realize their regular menu is under the 'Delivery' tab.
Lesson 4: Know that they do deliver.
Lesson 5: Remember they don't have a storefront.
Lesson 6: Call ahead if you don't want to wait.
Lesson 7: Plan accordingly to their limited operating days and hours.

Just keep these things in mind! Because...I did 1 & 2, didn't realize 3, knew but didn't think much about 4, didn't know about 5 so didn't do 6, but luckily accomplished 7. This resulted in a long walk during lunch, no time to look at the regular menu posted on the window and waiting at the sidewalk. 

Finally got back to the office to enjoy the Deuce. The combination of pesto and hummus was interesting but surprisingly good, and the dutch crunch was soft and thick. The amount of turkey was generous but needed an extra kick. Overall I really enjoyed the Deuce, but I wasn't blown away.

Will be back for more!
author: Marti L.

description:
Maybe it was just me, but I had to drink about 10 cups of water after eating Deli Board's infamous Boca sandwich. It left my mouth really dry and wanting something to quench my thirst. 

Boca ($11): It was full of juicy meat and cheese. After eating half of the sandwich, the other half ended up being salty. I might not get this sandwich again as it was all meat and made my mouth dry. 
http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Ft-oYkF-xxM1V1RdBsmaKw/l.jpg

I will come back to try another sandwich with the garlic dutch crunch.
author: Erica T.

description: So good. I'm not usually crazy about sandwiches, but the ones here are out of this world. The salads are amazing too. Love the ambiance and the owner/staff are always super friendly.
author: E A.

description: Love Deli Board so much! Amazing sandwiches that are so packed with good stuff I don't even know where to begin. The taste is a little bit Cleveland, a little bit Jewish deli, and all of it is delicious. Great record selection that the staff has playing in the background. The hours are not the best, so if you can't make it there during lunch, you are out of luck. But c'mon! Play hooky and go out of your way for some of the best sandwiches in SF!
author: Jake A.

description:
The jury is out.

Out for lunch.

Blocks from the courthouse, a Deli Board sando could easily make your otherwise dreary day.

It will assault your wallet, but you won't press charges. Eat the whole thing and you'll likely be pressing at the seams of your jeans.

For someone who can otherwise do without red meat, especially in a sandwich, I couldn't resist the Boca. Three kinds of meat, sauce, cheese, hot toasty bread. Three of the four I'd normally avoid. It was an all or nothing kind of day.

Chock full of SOMA tech folks and a line down the block, it's easy to find even if you don't spot a sign right away. 

At eleven bucks for a sandwich, it ain't cheap, but it ain't exactly theft.
When your eyes roll back and your taste buds are doing backflips, you, too, will know it was well spent.
author: Alissa A.

description: The sandwiches here are awesome but being a limo driver I really hate the fact that they do not accept phone orders or online orders. It's very difficult for me to park my limousine go in order and go back out to the car and wait without getting a ticket I would have ordered many more sandwiches from this place to take to the park if I could call ahead to get them. They know how to make a sandwich but not necessarily how to run a business..
author: Jeremy R.

description: Sandwiches are da bomb.  Best got sandwiches in the city.  Salads decent too.  However I don't recommend the soups.  Come early or you'll wait a while to order especially on work days.  Corned beef is recommended.
author: Zebra F.

description:
OVERRATED.

$16.00 for a club sando and a coke, SIXTEEN BUCKS WITHOUT SIDES, WTF?

And no tomatoes....

Too dry, don't know why this place is so popular.
author: M P.

description:
I love Deli Board and recently used their catering service for a catered lunch in my office.  Even though you can't order the items exactly as you see them on the menu (because they don't travel well and the sandwiches will get mushy), they had a great option where one can order the sandwich and meat together and then you can order trays filled with different toppings such as cheeses, veggies, sauces, etc.  The cost was a bit on the pricey side, but considering these are great quality sandwiches, it's worth the extra $$$.  

They seem to be very accommodating with the ordering process and will help you with any questions you may have.  Just make sure you order at least 2 day before the order is to be delivered to guarantee they can schedule you in.
author: Ken G.

description: This joint is off the hook. Went here on a break from jury duty at the courthouse a couple weeks back. Searched "sandwich" on Yelp and 4.5 stars with 100's of positive reviews seemed enticing. I live across the city but would make the trek across town just to savor another Zeke, one of the best, if not the best, sandwiches I've had in 6 years here in SF. Their mustard is amazing and hot sauce is on point. Can't wait to go back.
author: Niall D.

description:
One of the best sandwich places in San Francisco. Other top contenders are Ike's and The Sentinel, but I feel like the Deli Board has a lot of combos and they don't skimp out on the meat and the fillings. About 50% of the people get their sandwiches to go, so it seems like you can find a seat to eat there if you'd like. I went once at 12 pm and another time at 12:30 and found a table both times. I like their wood decor and it is clean, which is always a good thing.

The first time I went, I got the Mezman, which has pastrami, deviled egg salad, muenster cheese, jalapenos, pickles, and board sauce. I think it came on garlic dutch crunch. I loved the bread, it was soft, fluffy, and so delicious. I loved the deviled egg salad and the way the cheese was melted into the meat. I did find that the pastrami was too salty for my taste and I could only eat half the sandwich before I wrapped up the other half to take home.  I guess pastrami is not really for me. In small doses, yes, but the sandwich just had too much for my liking (I know, most people complain that sandwich shops skimp out on the meat)

I decided to give this another shot, because I think I just ordered something that wasn't right for me before. I got the Zeke which was completely up my alley and delicious. It had lots of turkey, bacon, cream cheese, pickled onions, sprouts, and mayo. I wasn't too much of a fan of the cream cheese, but I'll get it next time without. The whole thing was delicious and I ate the whole entire thing. 

The sandwiches are a bit on the pricey side, around $10 - 11, but they are worth it - the portions are big, the quality of the ingredients is great and very fresh, and they don't skimp out on any of the fillings. If you take half of it home, it reheats pretty well in the toaster oven. Remember to try the mustard they have, it's spicy and a little bit sweet and complements the sandwiches really well. 

It's fairly close to the courthouse, so if you're there for jury duty, make sure you come here for lunch - it will be the highlight of your day and the only saving grace to having to go to jury duty!
author: Christina L.

description: I came here for lunch from jury duty and ordered a kosher salami sandwich.  To their credit, the Dutch crunch bread is great and it was crunchy on the outside, but warm in the middle.  The pickle was a perfect dill and there was a ton of salami on the sandwich.  But, it's hard to justify $15 for this sandwich.  The salami was a bit oily, and $15 for a sandwich is high even is sf.  Especially given that it's at 6th and Folsom (not the nicest block.). Additionally, they don't have tap water so you are forced to buy bottled water which I find obnoxious.  The sandwich spot on pierce is probably the closest compare in SF, but the sandwich spot is better and closer to $10 / sandwich.
author: Jeff M.

description: Tried to order 8 sandwiches with 24 hours in advance - got an email from the owner that I couldn't "grasp" that he can't do that....with 24 hours notice....at $14 a sandwich....I can't grasp that this guy is such a dick
author: Wendy W.

description: Who drives from Napa to San Francisco to get a sandwich at Deli Board spontaneously?  This girl.  Best life decision I ever made.  Make sure you bring a friend with you so you can both order different sandwiches and try each one.  I work in the hospitality industry and am a firm believer that it is not only about the product, its about the whole experience.  Deli Board blew all of my expectations out of the water.  Yes, the sandwiches were AMAZING, but the staff and I believe it was the owner, were genuine, kind, friendly, funny and enthusiastic.  They WANTED TO be there, they WANTED you to have a good experience, they WANTED you to have an incredibly scrumptious sandwich.  I'm serious, the vibe there made the sandwich taste even better than it already way.  Thank you to the Deli Board family for feeding our bellies, satisfying our craving and showing us that a sandwich can turn into an experience!
author: Chelsea A.

description: This place really is as good as people say it is. -JS
author: Jeremy S.

description: Wow! Sandwiches are so good! Worth the cost for sure try this spot! Hands down best sandwich I have ever had!
author: Aaron M.

description: All I can say is "YUM!"  You must eat here. Sandwich may sound weird. Get it. Doesn't matter. Delicious.
author: Caitlin B.

description:
The drive here was horrible. SF traffic is just horrible. But these sandwiches made my day.

There were lots of people. I'm assuming that it's always like this. But it's a good sign because you know people are willing to wait long periods of time just for a sandwich! 

I got the Fatty Matty and my bf got the BBB. Both were sooooo good. I even ate leftovers a couple hours later and it was STILL good. I would come here again in the future for sure. ALSO, the nice woman who rang us up gave us a free water bottle!

If you're sitting in your car with your friend or significant other, and don't know where to go for lunch, DROP EVERYTHING AND COME HERE.
author: Alice H.

description: Like narcotics, these sandwiches can put you in a temporal state of pure bliss leaving nothing else you could possibly do that day even remotely as satisfying, but like all substances that effect brain chemistry, abuse can lead to destructive habits and ruin. This is why Deli Board closes for dinner and on Sundays, to preserve the longevity of its customer base. This is also why the best sandwich, the BK, is only served on Saturdays. You would be hocking your television in the street for sandwiches in time otherwise... As a sandwich aficionado, you will be hard pressed to find a shop anywhere in the region with as much flavor, texture, or quality as this unassuming den of gastronomic exuberance. Toasted dutch crunch garlic bread buns? Double-sided bacon? Juicy cheese-infused pastrami? Hand-crafted hot sauces? Ha! Good luck...
author: Rich W.

description:
Out of all the choices today I had the Bradley. My first time so I was hesitant to make a decision but man o' man what a meal. It all comes down to the bread and the sauce. The softest bread you can imagine piled high with meat and cheese and a delicious sauce. The first bite made my eyes roll back, so yum I believe they call that a food-gasim.

Only open for 5 hours a day, this was a total hot spot with people waiting outside. It was a quiet day compared to other days I heard someone say but it didn't take but 10 minutes and our food was served piping hot.  You know your doing good business when you can sell enough sandwiches in half the time that the other shops sell all day.

I plan on getting the special brisket next time since I tried a small bite of my friends. You can't go wrong with anything though because they definitely take time and care when preparing this little hand-held meal.  You have to go!!
author: Jessica M.

description:
Second time eating a sandwich from here and was a little disappointed. Had a Rubin and it was $15 for a sandwich that wasn't that big and very salty.  Wife had a Boca and she also said it was salty. 

2 stars due to price and taste. If sandwich was half that price, it would deserve maybe 3.5 stars.  Definitely had much better.
author: Sidney L.

description:
I had to give 2 stars only because of the price. The sandwich itself was pretty good. Soft bread, good tasting meat, and fresh veggies. However $20 for a sandwich and cup of soup is pretty ridiculous. I do not think I will return to this place as I can get great deli sandwiches for half the price at many other places in the city, and these are nothing to write home about.

I will pay for quality, however for a deli sandwich $14 is crazy. At the end of the day its cold cut meat and bread. Sorry people, not worth the price any way you slice it. Service was good!
author: Ed S.

description: Fantastic food and service.  Also love the vibe of the place.  We got the Boca (bread and meat were both on point!), and will be trying more stuff next time.  Booyah.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Like most negative reviews on Yelp some ot the ones here are just so stupid. 

Here is the deal. This place makes solid sandwiches. Really solid. And Mo, Adam and the other staff have never been anything but pleasant. If you don't like the prices move out of San Franciso. We live in an expensive city. Deal with it. If you go there and have something to complain about you might just generally be a sour-puss  and your rant probably says more about you than it does about this great sandwich shop. 

You like sandwiches? Go here.
author: Boo R.

description: I had the Fay sandwich - turkey, avocado, swiss cheese, cherry peppers, cole slaw, Board sauce, mayo, garlic dutch crunch. Everything about that screams yum and it indeed was delicious. The sandwiches are toasted so it melts in your mouth. I loved the sandwich but the price is a little steep. Deli Board is definitely the place to go when you want a really good sandwich and are willing to splurge a little.
author: Evonne T.

description:
If I had to eat another catered sandwich from Specialties while held hostage in another all-day meeting I swear I was gonna go postal.  How dare they put non-foodies in charge of ordering lunch for twenty-plus inmates.  As they say, if you want something done right, do it yourself and this was my moment to shine.  Looked on-line and figured out what sounded like a delicious line-up of lunchables then placed an order via email.  

Responsive?  I think Justin might've responded before I even hit send.  Not really, but it was lightening quick.  And that's how it went down.  We ordered a boatload of sammies, some salads, some sides, some cookies, and some Mexican cokes.  Freakin' delicious, all of it.  Justin told me my order was perfect and suggested that the cole slaw would be great on one of those pastrami sandwiches.  That, plus their special sauce was... oh God, mmmmnomnommmm.  Pastrami sandwich with coleslaw and sauce and mustard, brisket sandwich with coleslaw and sauce and mustard.  I was so happy I almost didn't mind being in that meeting.  Almost.

They ask for a 30 minute delivery window and Justin was there with the delivery right smack in the middle (the perfect time), and laid out the spread like a mural.  Everyone stopped yapping at me for a while as they savored their lunch, finally getting some good in the middle of a slog of a day.  Chances of me ordering again from Deli Board are upwards of 100%.  Chances of someone else on my team ordering from previously-unknown-to-them Deli Board in the future run about the same.  One of the best sandwiches I've had and I really appreciated that they didn't even ask for a credit card until the food was sitting right in front of me.
author: Tracey A.

description: Call it artisanal if you will. The quality, craft, and taste of their sandwiches are out of this world. $17 for a sandwich including tip is unheard of. Especially for a place that is in a cheaper neighborhood of San Francisco and is essentially a grab-and-go place (although it does have a good amount of seating). With that being said, the sandwiches here are delicious. I got the carzle sandwich with romanian pastrami, brisket, provolone, cherry peppers, pickles, cole slaw, and Board sauce on a garlic french roll. It's definitely one of the best sandwiches I've had in my life. You can taste the quality of every ingredient and the flavors go so well together. If you like a bold sandwich full of flavor, I definitely recommend the carzle sandwich. But I don't think you can go wrong with any of the sandwiches here. My co-worker got the $$$ and raved about how good it was. The cashier also asks you if you want pickles on the side. Get them! They are perfectly salty and crunchy and a great addition to have as a sidekick to your sandwich. I wish I could give this place 5-stars. I really do. But with the amount of food (beware, the sandwiches are a lot smaller than they look in the Yelp photos) and the price point for a sandwich is enough drawback for me to give them only 3 stars.
author: Hana K.

description:
One word: Wow. 

The gods have been kind to us and they show their appreciation by giving us the opportunity to eat at Deli Board, which is literally a small slice of heaven on Earth. 

$$$ ~ 5 stars ~ $13: Yes, the name of the sandwich is just "$$$" because that's exactly what it is, MONEY. This sandwich literally eats like a burger. It's packed with generous servings of brisket, corned beef and kosher salami. The muenster cheese provides awesome goodness while the sharp cheddar adds another layer of flavor. With each bite, the slaw and cherry peppers provide great crunch and heat. The Board Sauce is amazing - zesty, tangy and bold. All served on a crunchy yet flaky French roll. Words like nirvana, divine and supernatural came to mind while I was scarfing down the $$$. Have you ever seen Anthony Bourdain slip into a state of bliss when eating something on either No Reservations or Parts Unknown. You know when he takes a bite, closes his eyes, chews slowly as the background music transitions into soothing harp chords? That's exactly what happened to me. This sandwich is a boner-fied winner. Excuse the raunchy language, but do enjoy my awesome close-up shot. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=CRJOMP83KghYChR_TOsVQw&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A

Sandy built a custom sandwich with kosher salami, muenster and a few other things that was pretty much $$$ minus the brisket and corned beef. She said it wasn't that good so I tried it. Yeah, she was right. The kosher salami doesn't carry the sandwich well by itself. It provides good substance but lacks flavor. After she told me what was in her sandwich, I wondered why she didn't just get the $$$. She can be an odd one sometimes. http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=MG8qhJBG5f5TvFchwLpsdQ&userid=CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A

Other sandwiches on their menu caught me eye as well. Many of them looked the same with a couple minor twists. Like their Hermine sandwich. Instead of kosher salami, it has Romanian pastrami with brisket and corned beef. Their Grog sandwich sounds bomb too - brisket, bacon, cherry peppers, American cheeses, 1000 island, Board sauce and cole slaw on a garlic french roll. They also offer several selections of bread. I wanted to get the $$$ on dutch crunch but decided to stay true to their own creation and take it as is. They have wheat, french roll, dutch crunch and variations of the last two - garlic french and garlic dutch. If you're not in the mood for a sandwich, they also have salads. But let's be serious... Who in their right mind would come to this place for a salad???

I sincerely mean every single word - I CAN'T WAIT TO GO BACK TO DELI BOARD.
author: Bruce C.

description: By far the BEST sandwiches in all of SF!!!!  To the friendliest customer service right when you walk in the door ( MO & CARLY) how they remember everyone's name and heir order every time.  To the huge portions you get with every sub and the pickles are bomb!!!
author: Michael W.

description:
I'm new to the city, but experienced with a sandwich, especially a Rueben. Walked into this place feeling comforted by the Jewish vibes. Service was friendly and charming. But the Rueben (spelled Rubin here) was slightly above average. Disappointing for such a fine-looking establishment. 

I don't doubt, however, that the other sandwiches lack deliciousness. I'll have to go back to try the roast beef or brisket. 

Ike's still wins out, but not writing this place off just yet.
author: Max R.

description:
Delightfully delicious!  Massive and creative sandos that will break your belt, but hey tasty food is worth it.  Oh and now there are hot dogs in sandwiches and I highly suggest you eat one or three.

Oh... and when Adam makes the Cinci-Style Chili you better order a quart to take home!!!
author: Kyra W.

description:
Wow this place has amazing Sandwiches. It is a challenge to eat all of it at once, since they are so rich, but you cannot stop either, since they are very good. 5 Star without a doubt. 

Do schedule some waiting time, as this place seems to be very popular.
author: Carsten H.

description: Originally from the East Coast, good sandwiches are not that easy to come by in SF but this place is great.  Its a bit pricey ($15/sandwich) but its worth it.  I will definitely be back.
author: Tim H.

description:
Their original location was trippy:
you placed your order with a person standing outside of this building and then waited.  no kitchen.  no seats.  no nothing.

Sufficed to say, I was not a fan the first time around.

I'd plan on returning but then they moved and all this new found attention

(thanks to an article in the Chronicle) 
http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/blog/2012/01/19/deli-board-brings-cleveland-to-soma-and-harris-is-revisited-in-todays-newspaper/

kinda scared me off.

But I recently got over it, and I gotta say,
this new location may actually make their food tastier:
why?  you can sit down (if it's not too crowded) and enjoy the sandwich while it's still hot.

Now, I don't know what their signature sandwich is, but the Boca is pretty bomb.
The combination of corned beef, pastrami, brisket can be a bit much and some flavors can get lost if done improperly, but they know their sandwiches and it turned out to be a really tasty combo.

Are the sandwiches worth the $11?
Sure they are - well, every once in awhile anyways.
Besides, I'm real curious about some of their other sando combos.
author: Dan B.

description:
The Boca- #73 on the 2013 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

They don't take your order over the phone, so make sure you go in person even if you're planning to take your sandwich to go. This time around I just ordered The Boca (Corned Beef, Pastrami, Brisket, Muenster Cheese, Board Sauce, Brown Mustard, Pickles, $11, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/deli-board-san-francisco?select=h4tnZ0OcWNaGv_glZf9Hxw#PQuv6gxE13KGbCdxUZbMdQ) to share since I can't finish an entire sandwich here by myself. For a normal girl's appetite, you'll likely be full after 1/2 or 3/4 of the sandwich, but guys can probably finish off the whole thing, but just feel really full afterwards. I thought The Boca was just ok, but I made the mistake of ordering in on Dutch Crunch, which I thought overshawdowed the meats in the sandwich. It's originally served on a French Roll, which I would recommend staying with! However, the corned beef, pastrami, and brisket were all really tender, but a little salty. In any case, Deli Board still has awesome sandwiches, and I will be back for The Munsoned! Street parking in front is available, but spots are limited.
author: Amy D.

description: Ordered the Chloe w Dutch crunch instead of a French roll and added Pepperchini mix. The sandwich is REALLY good, woulda been perfect with a little more sauce... I added some stadium mustard to it. It comes with pickles on the side, yum. I did order a bag of chips and water bottle with it, and it came to like $19 ... Definitely WAY more money than I like to spend on lunch, but I'm on jury duty and they had great reviews so I had to check it out. It is a great spot though! They had a line the whole hour I've been here.
author: danielle a.

description:
Everyones bucket list should go something like this:

Sky Diving
Find True Love
See Europe
and Eat at Deli Board

Review Done.
author: Ben Z.

description: My new go to sandwich place. Zeke, turkey sandwich melts in your mouth. Well worth the 13 bucks. Recommend splitting the sandwich with your friend and try out there salads or soups.
author: John C.

description:
Man, that was a good sandwich.  I got the Lawrence - chicken salad with bacon, jalapeños and cheese on French bread.  I wasn't sure exactly what to expect, but I ate both halves of the sandwich when I was only hungry enough for one.  I. Couldn't.  Stop.  Myself.  

Go here.  You will be glad you did.
author: John H.

description:
We were so excited to come here for lunch and sadly didn't think it was all that the other yelpers made it out to be.

We shared the Samurai salad and the Cohen sandwich. The sandwich was by far the better of the two, yummy meats, decent bread, a nice spread all as a hot sandwich. The salad was pretty basic. For a salad with romaine lettuce, generally the greens have to be pretty fresh and green for us to get excited. Here they were yellow, on the crisp side but also heavily green to other stuff ratio. The dressing also was quite light and when one of us went back into the store to ask for extra dressing was admonished by the owner that we could have more dressing this time but that they usually charge $1 for it.

Overall a decent meal but not the best we've had and nowhere near Sentinel.
author: Amy D.

description:
The sandwich is pretty awesome. I had the A. Stud, the pastrami sandwich with avocado and jalapeño peppers. There was a lot - a lot of pastrami. Loaded with sugar, salt and fat, so definitely loaded with awesomeness. 

My only complaint is that the line goes out the door and the wait just to order is extremely long. I only work 3 blocks away and it took me an hour door to door.
author: Alton Y.

description: I have been coming here for years. They are by far the best sandwich in the city. Unfortunately they've gotten greedy and the prices have just become insane. $17 for a sandwich which in my opinion has also gotten smaller. I am not a price conscience shopper but this is even too much for me. I now consider it a luxury to go here once or twice a month (and I work a half block away).
author: Travis B.

description:
It doesn't help some asshole French fuck ashed his cigarette right onto the sleeve of my favorite jacket and then had the audacity to blame it on me for not watching where I was walking. REALLY? AM I SUPPOSED TO BE LOOKING FOR PEOPLE ASHING THEIR CIGARETTE EVERY TIME I CASUALLY WALK DOWN THE STREET. REALLY?! WHY AREN'T YOU WATCHING WHERE YOU PUT YOUR CIGARETTE?! I WAS ONLY RIGHT NEXT TO YOU. SHOULDN'T YOU BE THE ONE MORE SPATIALLY AWARE?  /rant

Anyways, I came here with a friend on his lunch break on a super sunny Thursday. This place was packed. I hated all their vegetarian options. Seriously they were terrible. I got a falafel sandwich. The bread was awesome. Everything else was not. I fucking love sandwiches too. Service is really nice. I heard them mess up a bunch of orders and they apologized tenfold to the customers. The food comes out crazyyyy slow. Its pretty easy to find a seat despite how packed it is because most people just order to-go. Probably because by the time their order is ready their lunch break is already over HEYOOOO.
author: Tiffany V.

description: Deli Board has changed its menu since I first tried their sandwiches over a year ago. Their sandwiches are still really good and even though it's a bit pricey for a regular size sandwich, the flavors, meat, bread, and bread-to-meat ratio are perfect. I wish they opened Sundays or even later than their regular weekday times since it's hard for me to get out there for lunch on a weekday, but when I do have a chance on a Saturday, I'll brave the lines for their "$$$" sandwich.
author: Rick T.

description: Over priced and no service for 6 or more sandwiches. just silly excuses for not making a sandwich. Will not take e mail orders. Will make you wait for single orders to be done first.
author: Ed F.
