I was craving for sandwiches so asked her if she wanted to go to the Sandwich Spot but she asked "have you been to Deli Board yet?" I immediately remembered I have not and then we were on our way to Deli Board. 

We went to their new location on Folsom. They were previously located elsewhere and had a whole different system. But now they have an actually location with tables and chairs. 

I ordered the Boca. Unfortunately they were out of brisket today but I said it was ok to have the sandwich without it. Jenny K made her own.

Our wait for our sandwich didn't seem to take long. While we were eating, the workers went up to all their dine-in patrons to check in on us and asked us how we were enjoying our sandwiches. Then the owner guy (I think he was the owner) came out and also checked in with us as well as the other patrons. He commented on Jenny K's sandwich and how it was dripping sauce. 

I had such a great dining experience and would most definately come back in the future for more sandwiches! :D
author: Eugenia G.

description: Still delicious, but the prices are ridiculous.  $14-15 for a hot sub sandwich?!?!  More a relfection of the absurdity of what's going on financially in SoMa these days (years).  The sandwich I had the first time (and the last time, today) was called the Munson'd, I think.  Super tasty, but too expensive to enjoy again.
author: Rob P.

description: The sandwiches were fine and big, but if I'm going to pay upwards of $17 for basically a chicken club, with tip, it better sing to me. It didn't. Overpriced sandwiches in rapidly gentrifying hoods make me sad.
author: Amy M.

description: Deli board makes great food.  The sandwiches are delightful, they taste fresh, the bread is soft, and the flavor is great.  The salads have fresh ingredients, and are a great portion.  The downside? A sandwich or salad will cost you $16.00 and 30 minutes of your time, just to get the food.
author: Dick S.

description:
Wow, amazing sandwiches.

I was staying in the unsexy SOMA for a conference, but someone recommended this gem to me. So glad I made the journey. The signage is very understated, and I would have probably missed it if it weren't for the tons of people inside with rapturous looks on their faces.

I ordered the Zeke, featuring turkey breast, bacon, avocado and a whole bunch of deliciousness. It was like getting punched in the mouth with flavour.

I ordered my sandwich to go, and took it down to City Beer Store to enjoy it while sipping on a delicious cold beer. Great way to spend a lazy weekend afternoon.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I live across the street from this place.  I finally tried it after I drunkenly spilled coffee all over my shirt this morning, and went home midday to change it.

I think sandwiches are kinda stupid but this place is totally worth going to.  It took like 15 minutes to make my Bateman, and it is kinda awkward standing around on the street waiting for it. But it was really flavorful, served at a good temperature, and not too messy. 

If you call to far in advance they won't make your sando until you get there because it affects the quality of it.  I guess that makes sense.  I don't really care because now they are open on Saturdays and accept cards.

***

I have tried like 10 different sandos now, and I have never been disappointed.  They make their own pickles!  And everyone there is super nice.
author: Derek B.

description:
I have to say, Deli Board lunch deliveries used to be a company event, usually on a weekly basis. For months, we would all look forward to that one lunch day where we would all put in our orders and eagerly get through the day until lunch when our hot sandwiches would arrive. Then one day, we called and was told Deli Board would not deliver anymore, only cater (24 hour notice with at least 10 sandwiches).

People were actually sad. Then my boss emails everyone this link today:
http://sanfrancisco.grubstreet.com/2011/09/check_out_the_new_deli_board_n.html#

Deli Board got too cool for us. After nearly a whole year of our lunch meetings as an excuse to all call into Deli Board, it looks like this relationship has really come to an end. Will miss it, but probably not enough to make a trek to the storefront.
author: Angela S.

description: If you're looking for a KILLER sandwich with fresh ingredients, look no further. Every sandwich I've had from Deli Board has been excellent, tons of meat with farm fresh veggies. Only thing is the price, each sandwich is going to run you ~$13 after taxes which in my opinion is pretty steep, but if you're looking for a quality sandwich it's certainly worth it.
author: Geoff G.

description: A tad bit expensive but really great selection of sandwiches and a very nice staff with a good ambiance.
author: Alastair K.

description:
Dear Deli Board owner,

There is only one reason I could possibly fault your fine establishment.  Where's the rye?  Seriously?  It's the best corned beef this side of L.A., by a long shot, but I can't order a corned beef on rye?  

You've even covered the small touches, such as Stadium Mustard, but would Corky and Lenny's or Slyman's dare debase their fare by serving it on Dutch crunch?  

Thank you very much for showing SF what a real sandwich looks like.  I'll be a repeat customer for the years to come.  I'll be the guy who brings my own bread.

Sincerely,
Anonymous C.
author: Anonymous C.

description: Got to the door of Deli Board as it was opening today. David had to pay off WS bet. Got the Pastrami 'A Star' and now finishing it up at ome. Great menu, Fabulous record collection behind counter. Get the pickles on the side. 6 stars on Folsom. Thanks Alex.
author: Charles S.

description:
Dare I say it? Could it be the best sandwich in SF? I know I know. I'm making a huge claim by saying that but it could be true. They now have a full blow sit down spot and I love it. I think I may go every weekend. Besides the sandwiches being fucking delicious the lovely workers there have such pleasant and friendly demeanors. 

They also have Funyuns! Hell the fuck yeah.
author: David C.

description: I don't get what's the hype. My work usually buy sandwiches from here or Tony Baloney's for our company lunches. I feel like the meat is overloaded, so maybe that's why it's so expensive for a sandwich.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Al the sandwiches my boyfriend got were spectacular, and i always had half or some bites of his, and i always enjoyed it. But one day i decided that i would order one for myself. And I wasn't lucky. I don't even remember the name of the sandwich, but i ordered a chicken sandwich, but it tasted like tuna! Not that i don't like tuna sandwiches, but i was in the mood for chicken! ha ha
Anyway, i got disappointed with the sandwich, but the mushroom soup and pickles were awesome.

Is a great place to go.
author: Danielle S.

description: I believe that they are the best sandwich spot for any meat lover. Their price tells you about the quality of the meat that goes into that sandwich. The moment I digest that sandwich I feel like going back for more. They are known for the pastrami and my favorite is the Corned beef. I also like the Tuna on Dutch Crunch. I like the quality of the clover sprouts, pickles and all other fixxings that go into my sammich. I highly recommend this place to anyone that likes a hot meat loaded sandwich.
author: Charles B.

description:
My sister just got married at the University Club (yeah, I reviewed that too!), and while we were getting ready for the big day, we decided to have some sandwiches catered to the Club by the Deli Board.

Originally, we were going to go with Le Regency Deli - but they're closed Saturdays (lame!). So I hunted around and, thanks to my fellow Yelpers, found the Deli Board.

We ordered the Build-Your-Own board with roast beef, turkey breast, and black forest ham (with provolone & cheddar cheeses). All I have to say is YUM YUM YUM!! In my experience, catered sandwiches usually are mediocre. These sandwiches... These sandwiches created a feeling in me that I can only describe as what I imagine Andy Dick feels like when he buys coke. It was just THAT. GOOD. My brother-in-law snuck into the room to eat, too. He made a sandwich, bit into it, and I'm pretty sure his eyes were gonna bug out of his head; he looked at me and said, "Holy crap, this is the best sandwich ever!". 

And he's pretty right. The meats were all super fresh and tasty, and the roast beef was perfectly cooked (medium to medium-rare, thank you - just as roast beef should be!). The bread was still warm when they brought it to us, and the condiments & fixins were just amazing. All in all, it was a great way to start a busy, busy day.

As if amazing food wasn't enough, the staff who helped us were just unbelievably courteous and friendly. Adam, who handles all the catering orders, was SUPER friendly and really great with handling our order. The person who delivered our food (I think his name was Jim...) was also really friendly and helped us sort out of the food on the table before he left. All the folks I spoke with over the phone were great, too. The prices were also really affordable - fresh meats, cheeses, and breads for 10 people for $80, which included both the taxes and delivery fee! And trust me, that definitely fed more than 10 people!

I've definitely been recommending the Deli Board to folks I know who need catering in the city. It's well worth it!
author: Jennifer V.

description:
This has to be the greatest sandwich and salad I have ever eaten. The homemade hot sauces were out of the world, and the prices were more than reasonable. 
The hours are a little crazy so make sure you get in and experience one of SF's greatest sandwich shops.
author: Mike P.

description:
OOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO Damn can these people make a mean sandwich.

Mikey - pastrami, white american cheese & those ridiculously delicious crunchy pickles. 

How can anyone not love this joint?

   note to Adam: I'd be willing to trade my infamous hummus and babaghanoush skills for your pastrami secrets.  
  Together, we can solve the midEast crises through mutual love of food  :)
author: Athena S.

description: If you like sandwiches and life. This place has it all. The meat is so well cooked and the keep rotating the menu, so there is more to love all the time. The counter service is great and they are all easy on the eyes, especially the one with glasses ;). Go and make your tummy happy and the happiness comes with a side of pickles.
author: peter v.

description:
I'm going to miss them taking my order on the sidewalk and then running back inside the building.  I absolutely love the place.  Bad for my diet but delicious.  The sandwiches are very very hearty and it will make even the bulkiest man full.  They also tend to mix things up and have amazing specials everyday.  Also, I'm not a fan of pickles but somehow they serve yummy pickles here that go perfect with any sandwich.  I will always be a fan here.  

The service, the food, everything is amazing.  

Advice: there will always be a wait (because it's just THAAAT good).  Try to check the website for specials and call in ahead of time for pick up.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
Recently tried the Gold-n-Berg-n-stein and wow, was i blown away! most definitely one of the best sandwiches in the city. So it's corned beef, pastrami, salami, meunster, 1000 island sauce, pickles, and french roll. Simple? Not really, but the flavors go together so well it's making me drool now, 9-10 days later. I will have to make a stop here more often... 

BTW the ambiance is nice. Just 8 tables, a record player and nice, friendly service from the employees.

Tips: It'll start getting busy around 1145. Come in early and/or give yourself 20 minutes... it'll be well worth it. Parking is MOSTLY metered unless your lucky enough to park across the street in the 4 un-metered spaces. Bring some quarters.
author: Vittorio L.

description:
You walk up and there's a person waiting for you in front of a door. That's it. No tables, no seating... just a brick wall and someone with a clipboard.

That's a beautiful start in my book.

So I've been to a few sandwich places in the Bay and this has topped them all. While Ike's was good, I still thought it was overrated. This place was hyped up on Yelp and it definitely lived up to it.

My buddy and I ordered the Boca and the Uncle Sam. Both were delicious. The mats were flavorful and thinly sliced. The sauces were not overpowering and there was just enough cheese on both (especially the Uncle Sam) to give it a bit of creaminess.

But what makes it... the bread. The bread is ridiculous. The french roll was chewy and the perfect compliment to the Boca. And that dutch crunch... my GOD.

One of the best sandwiches I've ever been to. One of the many reasons I sometimes wish I lived in the Bay.

Cheers!
author: Andrew B.

description:
Pros:
Great, filling sandwiches
Friendly service
Rotating specials to supplement menu

Cons:
A bit expensive
Limited seating
Most of the sandwiches taste the same

Up to you:
It's all about the meat (straying from that might make for a questionable meal)
author: Alex G.

description:
Deli Board is goood. I've had their sammachs and their salads and they are HUGE. The chicken salad lasted me 2 lunches. RIDIC!

Free delivery is very awesome and I like the changing blog menu on their website.
author: Amy S.

description:
Great place for a sandwich. Since they've moved to their new location, Deli Board has gotten even better. To a certain extent, there's a level of thrill associated with wandering a scuzzy neighborhood and ordering a sandwich from what looks to be the inside of someone's apartment behind a metal gated doorway. But that was earlier this year and now they have a store front on Folsom and a small dining area. It's not a terribly long walk from SOMA, and I bet if you avoid the peak lunch hours, you could make it back in an hour. 

I split the Boca and Zeke today and both were amazing. The Boca was a mound of pastrami corned beef and brisket and almost nothing else tucked inside the confines of a sweet french roll. Who needs the frills of a regular sandwich when you can let the meat speak for itself? The Zeke was turkey bacon and avocado with cream cheese, again on sweet french roll. The cream cheese more than makes up for the dryness of the turkey during the toasting process. Of the two, I definitely prefer the Boca. Even better, each sandwich comes with a side of pickles!

I also remember seeing a bike messenger stuff a dozen sandwiches in his messenger bag for a delivery. So if you need a quick lunch and you crave a sandwich, look into that. 

Knocked one star down because the sandwiches are about $10 each. A taaaaad expensive.
author: Dennis L.

description:
Tried out a Roast Beef sandwich today on Dutch Crunch with Provolone, Mayo, Mustard, Shum Sauce, Pepperoncini, and Sprouts.  

I don't remember much about the sandwich because it didn't last long, but from what I do remember, it was delicious!  Toasted to perfection; the cheese melted nicely.  

Every sandwich, soup, and edible I've devoured here has been pure bliss.

I can't stop dreaming of their sandwiches...
author: John M.

description:
Walked about 7 blocks just to check this place out since I'm taking advantage of my temp work assignment in the city. This is my favorite place thus far in the area.

Thanks to YELP...another successful lunch place discovery. Man the combo sandwiches are the BOMB! I had the BOCA. It was super flavorful.

Only down side is its $11+ for a specialty sandwich....so just a bit pricey to justify coming here multiple times a week for lunch & you may have to wait quite some time for your sandwich to be made during the lunch rush. But hey it's SF....lunch is usually $10+.

I'll definitely be back..once in awhile....

TO SUM IT UP: YUMMY BUT PRICEY!
author: Cathy D.

description:
This place had some some pretty tasty sandwiches. I had the Zeke sandwich, which was pretty tasty. The fresh bread is pretty good! The prices are a bit pricy, in my opinion, but the portions are large. I think it would be better if they had a half sandwich option, for a cheaper price, especially for those who are visiting just as my friends and I were. The atmosphere was decent. It's a relatively small place, but there are plenty of little tables. The customer services was great! I gave this place 4 stars for two reasons:
1. the prices are a bit high
2. they put too much mayo/cream cheese on their sandwiches, which distracts from the flavor of what else is in the sandwich.
I wasn't a fan of their homemade pickles, but my friends loved them. Overall, the place was good.
author: Mandi C.

description: Overrated, overpriced, and unprofessional! I ordered the Zeke (hot) sandwich, chips, and a Mexican coke, and included a 15% tip and paid nearly $17 dollars for this lunch.   The female worker seemed to know half of the patrons, hugging them and saying it was nice to see them as they left.  Maybe it was Friends and Family Day. The male staff seemed to be taking a break with a friend of his who ordered a sandwich, and I heard him offer his buddy a free bag of chips. Later I heard the female worker talking with the male staff about how they had recently received a bad yelp review, and they were bad mouthing the anonymous customer who left it. I saved half of my sandwich for later and unlike other saved sandwiches in the last, it tasted dry and nasty and I ended up throwing it away.
author: Laq Y.

description:
I am a creature of habit at places I like.  But upon recommendation of the Chairman of the Board.  I took up the "Teddy O"

Speechless.

The Romanian Pastrami is crazy in the Teddy O.  Word is DB is the only place that receives it in these parts.  I don't know what it cost me, but it was worth every dollar.

If you are in to pastrami, corned beef or brisket, try the Boca first and you'll love it for sure.  Then go back for the Teddy O.

I don't even look at the rest of the menu anymore!
author: AJ B.

description:
I had the Cohen, and it was honestly one of the best sandwiches I've ever had. I'm sure every sandwich there is amazing though.

One word: Orgasmic!
author: Cassandra S.

description: Sandwich was really good! Staff was friendly and welcoming. My only complaint was it's too expensive I would say instead of $14 it should be no more than $11. If the price was adjusted I would be at least a weekly regular.
author: Nyla S.

description:
Another one of my fav sandwich places!

For the price you pay, you get quite a humoungous sandwich! half of one was a serving for myself, i saved the other half for dinner! The quality of fresh ingredients put together in one sandwich is amazing. I like how they have a diff menu daily, i dunno i guess i think its a unique thing among restaurants. I remember I had a sandwich by the name of the Wallowitz, oh and was it a glorious wallowitz! It contained roast beef, turkey breast, some amazing garlic sauce, pepperocini's in a soft fresh french roll, there may have been more ingredients.. but it was a while ago that i had this sandwich. Their pickles are great too!

I will have to take my fiance here sometime for sure. He's definitely a lover of meat and the large portions are bound to make him super full lol. I'd like to go again to try out other sandwiches as well as the soups/ salads they have to offer.
author: Rehana K.

description:
Why have I not been here before? This place is fantastic. The music is great, the people super friendly, the service was speedy and efficient, and the food's terrific - what's not to like?

Tip: check their website for their daily specials. They cater for 10 or more orders w/ 24 hour advance notice. If we move the office up to San Francisco, these folks are going to get a lot of our business.

Highly recommended.
author: Mark W.

description:
This is my absolute favorite place to eat lunch hands down -- better than ike's -- better than anywhere. I love everything on the menu, the soups, the sandos, and the salads are HUGE and delicious. I especially love the pastrami, brisket, and roast beef sandwiches. I adore the staff like family and I eat there everyday.

From Justin's delivery service to Adam's culinary versatility: there is a genuine passion and care put into this food that you just don't see at larger establishments. 

I have a pretty diverse palette, but the deliboard keeps me satisfied. I love that the menu changes monthly, and that each day there are 3 new specials.

As for the service, I've never had a bad experience. The staff is extremely friendly, flexible, and sexy. You just have to understand that it gets busy during the lunch rush and customers who're rude or have their heads up their keyster won't receive the pampered treatment they feel so entitled to. 

Anyone familiar with the SF sandwich game knows that the relationship between residential tenants and delis can be a little testy, sometimes it can lead to the demise of a beloved business; thus it is very important that you follow the rules. 

the rules are very simple:

DO NOT ENTER THE KITCHEN. If you complain that the staff is rude, chances are you never even considered reading the two GIANT signs that say "STOP HERE, you will be helped" and "NOTICE: Employees Only!" before you waltzed into the kitchen. 

Maybe you should've noticed the other 15 people politely waiting outside, maybe you could head back to to where ever it is you came, though  last I checked burger king doesn't allow their customers in the kitchen, either. 

DO NOT ORDER +9 SANDOS. If you need catering, use the catering menu, order 24 hours in advance, but do not try to game the deliboard by submitting multiple orders. You're not the first to try. It won't work.

As for people complaining about bike delivery needing a 35 minute window: when was the last time you ordered a pizza with a specific receiving time? Chinese food? Comcast? Hell, when did you ever have a sandwich personally delivered to you? Spoiled yelpers.

Don't know what to do for lunch? Grab your friends, go to the deliboard, pickup a menu, wait outside, go to a park, and enjoy the best picnic you've ever had.
author: Dylan S.

description: Super Hight Quality Meat.  Their sauces are awesome too, so don't forget to try those while you are there.  Also, if there is a sandwich you really like remember the name, they rotate menu but they can make it again usually.
author: Steve D.

description:
Deliciously toasty bread. Softest, tastiest meats you'll ever put in your mouth. Will be back for seconds of the munsoned (brisket w/ american cheese) and the mish (corned beef bacon and onions kicked up w/ jalapenos). Side of Snooki-worthy pickles were refreshingly large, fresh and crunchy.

Extra credit: half of a mish leftover was still tasty and not soggy after a few hours in the fridge.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Was not blow away by the sandwich here, I think it's more hype than anything else. I was told that this place had great sandwiches, I'll take peoples opinions a little less at face value next time.

I could probably put together a sandwich for less money and still have enough fixings for another the next day!

Why don't you make a sandwich with just bread called "the sheep". Cause that's all that eat there.
author: Danny S.

description:
I love deli board. I love everything about them. I love the brisket, I love the pastrami, I love when you put them together. The 'munsoned' and the 'Boca' have changed my life.

Straight up, this place is the best sandwich shop I have ever been to. It has never ceased to amaze me. Whatever I try, I love it.

My next favorite part is the super sketchy atmosphere. I love that shit!. The lovely ladies taking your orders and the hole in the wall looks make this place not only delicious, but a fun little adventure.

I have had deli board exactly 14 times if you are wondering. I can't contain myself right now because I want it, and they are closed. Call in early if you are smart, other wise you might have a 45 minute wait.
author: dr. L.

description: Damn what a great sandwich and a killer menu to boot. Everything on the menu looks like something I'd try.
author: J G.

description:
OMG!  Seriously Yelpers, you have to try Deli Board if you've never been.  If you want a serious taste-buds' orgasm, TRY IT!  The sound of the brown wrapper crinkling as you unwrap the sandwich reminds me of our minature dachshund's ears perking up when you unwrap a Kraft's single cheese a mile away. Then you bite into any of their scrumptious sandwiches and then you're like, DAMN!  The bread is unbelievably fresh and the meat is one of the highest qualities of meat you'll find in a sandwich here in San Francisco, maybe the Bay Area.  I had the BOCA, BUFFALO WINGS AND CHICKEN POT PIE soup on 01/19/2012 and the MIKEY and (OMG) TOMATO & POLENTA soup today, 01/20/2012.  Hella Yummy!

Forget losing weight again this year, I'm at least going to hit up this place twice a week for a month and then settle down to once a week.  I'm that crazy about this Deli.  And yes, they literally put the DELI in DELIcious. Nice job Deli Board Team.  Yal are my new best lunch friends.  

P.S. Visit their website at www. deliboardsf.com to view their daily specials.  They literally update the site everyday and I'm loving that.  Can you tell I'm a fan of this place?
author: Frank C.

description:
Piping hot, melty sandwiches jam-packed with meaty goodness!  I'm so happy to see this place doing so well.  I used to work with the owner, and I remember when he quit his bank job to make good food.  And his food is GOOD!  I'm so happy to not only see this place taking off, but doing so well that he's opening another shop soon.

I can't believe how good these sandwiches are!  Top-notch bread, great flavor combos, and generous portions.  The staff is super cool, too.  The girls at the counter are nice and fun.

This is a SOMA gem!
author: Jeff M.

description:
Way too hipster for me. 

But I mean that somewhat lovingly, as the servers were so happy and pretty friendly. 

I got the maeday (grilled squash & zucchini, goat cheese spread, sprouts, pepperoncini blend, organic greens, pickled red onion, Board sauce, dutch crunch) and found it was lacking substance... meat would've helped, but I do love vegetarian sandwiches and think this could've used avocado or more vegetables or something. 

Overpriced, otherwise I'd be willing to give it another shot.
author: Richa A.

description: The sandwiches are solid, nothing amazing so I have yet to come back. And the outdoor seating area could be improved.
author: Cindy T.

description:
I love Deli Board. This is the sister-store to 1058 Hoagie. When the latter opened, I wondered at the wisdom of being so close to Deli Board, but it seems to be working out. 

The sandwiches here are heated, which I prefer. As with Deli Board, the staff seem to genuinely enjoy their jobs and there is always good music playing on their record player. The owner knows what he's doing: pretty young gals serving up good food quickly and efficiently. 

The only possible knock I could give against the place is that it gets really packed during lunchtime. But that's really just another sign that this is a good lunch choice. Oh, and I loathe the usual gaggle of greasyhaired/tattooed/skinnyjeaned/overscarved/etc. hipster-types, but that's San Francisco in 2013; what can you do? Eat a sandwich and try to forget....
author: Bill G.

description:
I'll start by saying I would have rated Deli Board 5 stars it had Rye Bread.  I expect you to have Sweet Tea if you have a Southern restaurant, and that you have Pastrami on Rye if you run a Jewish/New York-style deli.  when I asked for Rye bread, I was told they only have it for their specials.  I already had a taste in my mouth for it, so darn!

As for the sandwich we got, it included pastrami, turkey, cheese and Dutch Crunch bread.  It was fantastic, and the lentil soup was quite good, could have used more salt. (Would have been better with some ham bits cooked into it but I'm guessing the soup is supposed to be a vegan option.)

Service was great.

Atmosphere is cute and clean.

Prices are consummate with the great food, but if they were lower, I would come here a LOT.

On my scale*, Deli Board gets a 3

*Scale:
1: Would not go back alone and would protest if a friend suggested we go.
2: Would not go back alone, but would not protest if a friend suggested we go.
3: Would go back happily and willingly without being prompted by someone else.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Love it.  I've spent way too much here...  :)

At $11 a sando it's on the higher side, but I'll be darned if it's not worth every penny...  The best stuff is usually on their 'board list' which changes daily...  They are getting into soups and making sauces and it's ALLL GOOOOOD...  If you're going off the menu the Boca is solid, everything is solid... Follow your gut...  Your fat, meat filled gut. 

Also bonus points to Mo' ! ! !   She's great and remembers names with ridiculous accuracy.
author: Will W.

description:
Best sandwiches in SF I've had thus far.

Cleveland! Represent!
author: Tony P.

description:
Wow. Killer sandwich. And for a place with a tagline about meat, they still have plenty of awesome veggie options.  The pickles are great and so is the Mexican coke. 

I appreciate the attention to detail they take in making their sandwiches-- they are even wrapped with care.  You can call ahead to order and everyone is friendly and helpful.
author: Sharon G.

description: It's way overpriced, but I don't care because it's just that good... All about that Cohen.
author: Alex H.

description:
Get the Boca sandwhich- totally blew me away.

Normally I'm not a sandwhich gal, but decided to try this place out on a rainy Sunday afternoon.  There wasn't much of a line outside (which literally consist of a girl standing outside the door, taking your order.)  I'm curious as to how big/clean the establishment is on the inside.

The sandwhich is VERY meaty- I don't think I had any vegetables (besides the side of pickles that comes in a plastic bag.)  I do, however, love meat, so it worked out perfectly.

I prefer these sandwhiches over Ikes- nothing too crazy going on inside (no mozarella sticks, fried artichokes, etc.)  The meat is flavorful, perfectly cooked, and slicked so thin that it melts in your mouth.  YUM...
author: Clarissa P.

description:
This is such a DELI-ghtful sandwich spot.  My bf was having cravings so he picked me up during a lunch break (I'm in the FIDI) and came here in the SOMA to grab a bite.

We ordered the Boca and Zeke and thought that both were yummy sandwiches but the Boca was better than the Zeke.  Be warned... you need a BIG mouth to be able to take a bite out of this sandwich without missing one side of the bun.  The meat is cooked very well and the slices are thin but you get layers and layers in quantity.  I love it!  The Boca comes with sliced pickles and their own special sauce.  The Zeke has cream cheese, avocado and bacon.  The bread is fresh and every bite is full of great flavor.  Your taste buds will be buzzing with happiness! 

the only down side of this sandwich spot that i could think of is i wish they had more drink selections.  you're eating such a great sandwich but you will be thirsty!  having more drink options would be great!

also, you should arrive early for lunch because there will be a line.  the good news is that it goes quick and they have great service.
author: Sandy L.

description:
Wow! I really love this place!

I have only been here twice but both times I left wishing I had a bigger stomach just so I could eat another meal here, immediately!  

All of their sandwiches are served toasted and warm with mouthwatering, ooey gooey, melted cheese.  I have had the Munsoned (brisket, american cheese, pepperocinis) and the Zeke (turkey, avocado, bacon) so far.  The Munsoned is featured in this years San Francisco 7x7 list, which is what first lead me here.  

Unfortunately, this place is closed on Sundays and it can get  crowded at times, but these sandwiches are definitely worth the wait!
author: Chrissy M.

description:
Outstanding.  First time I went here was with a large group mid-week for lunch.  We grabbed one of the tables after ordering and when the owner overheard it was one of the girls' birthdays, he brought out a giant bowl of pasta salad on the house.  

The sandwiches were spot on packed with meat, melted cheese and the perfect kick of spice on french bread.  Easily the best sandwich I've had in SF.  Naps are required to combat the inevitable food coma but it's worth a lethargic afternoon.
author: Rich L.

description:
Super delicious but super pricey sandwiches for lunch.

The Munsoned is incredible as is the chicken salad.  It is tough to throw down $11 for a sandwich that comes solo.  Well, each sandwich does come with a pickle on the side.

However, despite the price, I was in heaven while eating my sandwich and was raving about the taste rather than complaining about the cost.
author: Chad S.

description:
And, And, And......they deliver to whereever you ask them to.  I ordered 2 sandwiches with extra pickles to the ballpark....10 mins and they showed up calling to find out where I was.  Excellent.  EXCELLENT I tell you! 

BOCA for the win again!
author: Vincent K.

description: Just ridiculously good sandwiches. I haven't had one that wasn't amazing. And the hot sauces are fun too. This is the only place I repeat for lunch.
author: Amjad S.

description:
Could be the best corn beef and pastrami sandwich I ever had.  

I highly recommend the Rueben's cousin which substitutes board sauce for thousand island and a sweet French roll for rye.  Simply delicious substitutions I must say.  Rumor has it that the board sauce is a mayonnaise based sauce with brown mustard and spices which provides a great condiment , this and the brown habanero sauce are the perfect compliments for any sandwich.  The bread is lightly toasted which gives it a nice crunch and brings texture to the sandwich.  Both the corn beef and the pastrami are surprisingly lean and are thin sliced resulting in a slightly sweet and salty assault on the palate. The homemade pickles are excellent although I did find the turkey to be a little dry.

It is a fairly small restaurant which tends to get very busy so it gets loud in the board. The staff is friendly and the wait is reasonable for the sandwich.  Prices are a little steep, with a sub and a drink averaging between twelve to fifteen dollars.  When considering the quality of the product, the price is not too unreasonable.

Overall, I would consider this the best sub shop I have been to in san fransisco.  
You really need to try this place. 
The Deli board is definitely one of my fish pix.
author: Fish E.

description:
Came in here quite by accident while waiting for a quick car repair down the street, thinking it was a cafe.  Something told me to stay and order a sandwich.  After ordering I went to the restroom and noticed the newspaper article about the place framed on the wall of the john.  I suddenly realized that my friend in Cleveland had sent me the same article and that, being a Midwest transplant who appreciates good meat, I had been intending to come here for a while!

I introduced myself to the owner, Adam, who is a Cleveland native.  Every employee I encountered was super friendly, nice and helpful.  I love that the music playing in the place is provided by their good selection of vinyl records behind the counter.

I ordered the Roman (a special) which was an Italian style hot sandwich.  WOW was it great!!  And they served it with two big hunks of dill pickle.  The only slight drawback was the prices ($12 for my sandwich) but considering the quality ingredients it is worth the occasional splurge.  If you don't want to order a sandwich or salad, they also sell their meat by the pound!

Adam mentioned to me that while Deli Board is a Jewish-style deli, he's opening a new location down the street that's more of an Italian-style deli with cold sandwiches.  Can't wait for that!!  I will definitely be back and will be excited to try the new location when it opens.
author: Jon B.

description:
Deli board is great for those who love salty meaty sandwiches with no veggies.  Its a good sandwich place, but in the last 6 months has exploded well beyond its abilities to produce a solid sandwich.  Instead of adding more staff, they seem to just to think we'll wait.  While the prices used to be reasonable, they have ballooned beyond affordability for a daily lunch.  I often call in a sandwich 30 minutes ahead of time and walk around the corner to pick it up, only to find they haven't started making it.  Only after an additional 15 min waiting outside and paying way too much, I finally get my delicious meatwich.  Sorry, but this brought you down from a once solid 4 star sandwich review. 

If you do come here, know that there's no place to eat inside so walk down Moss to Folsom st and eat it at Victoria Manalo Draves Park. I guess its the SoMa version of taking Ike's to Dolores [the sandwich wont be as good as Ikes, but its still great to picnic with deli board in a park without hipsters]
author: Dan W.

description:
Oh. Heck. Yea! Talk about total ownage of all other "sando" places to have ever existed. If you're a meat-head like myself, no not the type at the gym who is always grunting and working out with their shirt off), but rather someone who appreciates the delciousness that is corned beef, pastrami, and brisket, you must, I re-iterate, must come eat here.

I had the "Boca" this afternoon and I'll undoubtedly be thinking of it all week while I'm eating a sad substitute of a sandwich at my office's cafe. All the meats are thinly cut and as such lend themselves perfectly for a bath in melted muenster and "Board" sauce. It's as if they took the best of a aspect of a Philly cheesesteak and elevated it to level unknown to a regular sandwich...I guess that's why they called sandos.

Anyhow, the meat to bread ratio was perfect, not at all overly stuffed, but by no means skimpy, and the bread was slightly crisp on the outside and super tender on the inside perfect soaking up delicious meat and sauce juices.

Overall, a perfect sandwich with no wasted space with lettuce fillers. Definitely plan to try a least a 1/2 dozen or so of the other sandwiches on the board.
author: David H.

description:
I've gotten sandwiches here a few times since moving to the area about 9 months ago but, for some reason, I've been extra obsessed with them lately and have been stopping by at least 3 times a week. I'm almost certain that there is something addictive in the meats they use. I mean, how else do you explain my need to buy 2 sandwiches at a time when I only eat half of a sandwich and keep the rest in the fridge for when the sando craving hits an hour after they close and then again at midnight?? You're probably thinking, "eww, reheated leftover sandwiches?! what an addict." I know, it sounds weird but even microwaved sandos are delicious!

I've tried Boca (when in doubt, start with this one), Zeke, Fatty Matty, and Saracevic (has just the right kick if you want something spicy) and loved them all. You really can't go wrong with any of their sandwiches. At about $10 each, they seem kind of pricy for sandwiches but that hasn't stopped me yet!

Insider Tip: they have opened a sister store called 1058 Hoagies (http://1058hoagie.deliboardsf.com/) to satisfy your cold sandwich needs. Be sure to check it out!
author: Amaryllia L.

description:
Long lines and waits, short stubby sandwiches.  But for $11-13 dollars I better be getting a footlong, and enough meat for two meals...

I will admit the bread is amazing and the hot pastrami is excellent. Unfortunately, it comes smothered in their "house" sauce, which just tastes like crappy salad dressing.  

How about you hand me a sandwich without your special house sauce, and I'll hand you 4 bucks less?!?!
author: R C.

description:
This is the best place in the world.
Great Sandwich, friendly efficient help, nice guy in charge.
Everything the previous guy sez and more.
author: Richard L. D.

description: Boca Baby!,thats all i have to say.what makes deli board so good is their meats.good quality you can taste,but most important to me is the way they slice it.house made corned beef and brisket is shaved real thin.the breads are toasted and compliment the meats instead of distracting.house made pickles are a nice touch to the fine sandwich.i would rate deli board 6 stars,but im subtracting one star for not giving me a caramel apple lollypop.
author: Soupnazi B.

description:
OMG!  today I had the reuben's cousin (admittedly the only sandwich I've ever gotten) with jalapeno and all i could think of was "insane in the membrane!"

seriously, this is a great sando, and they are so nice there.  i'll drive across town to get one, and I DEFINITELY CRAVE IT.  Admittedly it's annoying that they don't take phone orders, but the wait is worth it, believe me.
author: chris m.

description: Wow! Now I know why 4.5 stars. This was an amazing place for a sandwich my wife got a tuna sandwich and she said it was the best sandwich she has ever had.  I got the gold-n-stein and could not believe how good it was.  Just wishing it wasn't so far away.  I did like it better than Ike's way more meat and overall better sandwich.
author: Brad S.

description:
Premium deluxe specialty hot sandwiches! I love their house made pickles, but lately they've been jipping me! Used to give us tons of pickles...now it's like 2 slices per sandwich.

Place gets really packed during lunch. Not much room for dining in, but that's ok because we usually order to-go anyway. They have daily specials for sandwiches and soups and other random goodies. I have yet to try their soup, but the sandwich itself is already a meal for days.

I usually get sandwiches with turkey or chicken or the zeke, which has bacon, sprouts, cheese and avocado in it I believe. I don't know, but topped with their hot sauce this sandwich is pretty good.

On the down side though, these bad boys will surely put you in a food coma! Productivity levels at work after lunch at deli board = -40%.
author: Stine H.

description:
my favorite sandwiches!  so good...the Ron BLOWS MY MIND.  If you get a cold sandwich, you get the bonus of having half leftover for dinner (hot sandwiches are made to be completely scarfed)!

delivery is FAST, too!
author: Charlene E.

description: Love the place. My favourite place to go for lunch. Sandwiches are awesome (my favourite is the rivkah) and salads big, filling and healthy (the samurai is my favourite).
author: Christophe C.

description: I really like their Mezman sandwhich, which inside consist of romanian pastrami, which I've never had before. Andalso deviled egg salad, muenster cheese, and their own special board sauce.
author: Krystal S.

description:
This has to be the best sandwich I have ever had.  Pricing is right in line for quality food in San Francisco.  

The staff is great and they always are changing the menu.  It does not matter what you get it's all excellent 

I hope they'd open a location in the East Bay soon !
author: Brodie S.

description:
I've been meaning to check out Deli Board and even bookmarked it sometime in 2010 but never got the chance to because it was so hard to catch them during their business hours. I always had work or had other obligations to tend. They are only open 4 hours a day, 5 times a week. 11am-3pm M-F. 

A couple weeks ago, Jimmy picked me up for lunch and gave me several options to choose from. Seeing Deli Board on the list, I quickly pointed the name and confirmed, "DELI BOARD! We are going to deli board!" 

Well Deli Board ain't no shop, that I will tell you. I think they make their sandwiches inside a home/apartment. You stand outside an apartment complex and posted on the wall is their menu. Every once in a while, someone will come down to take orders, runs back up and runs back down to tell you the price of your order, they run back up with your credit card or cash and runs back down with your change or credit card receipt. 

10-15 minutes later, they run back down with your sandwich(es) and a side of pickles to eat with. Delicious! Their pickles are yummy and I think my mouth is watering right now as I'm typing this.... hold on, let me wipe my mouth. 

Got the pastrami sandwich w/ lettuce, pickles, avocado, jalapenos, grilled onions, sprouts and pepperjack. Hold the mayo and mustard. All on a sweet french roll. Nothing fancy but it sure tasted darn fancy! 

Can't say when I'll be back but I will definitely go back!
author: Jenny K.

description: I got the clifton with mozzarella and dutch crunch. And let's just say they aren't shy with the meat. It's a carnivores dream. I would add the pickled onions on the side. It helps cut through some of the heaviness from all the meat. It's a good sandwich but there are just so many good sandwich places in the city. The servers are super friendly. Note, if u get the shum sauce make sure you got some gum or don't plan on kissing anyone.
author: Eve C.

description:
Ridiculous. 

If you haven't been to this place yet then you haven't experienced the best sandwich shop in the city. Their pastrami sandwich mades me home sick every time I eat it and I try and get over there to get "home sick" as much as humanly possible.
author: Jamie C.

description:
After reading about this place in Serious Eats I suggested to the company office manager that we have it brought in for one of our weekly Wednesday lunches before I ever even sunk my teeth into one of these meaty yet tender sandwiches. I forgot about it until I saw the internal email go out to everyone that I selected today's lunch of salads and sandwiches from Deli Board. All of a sudden my food selection skills were on the line!

The food looked amazing upon arrival. We got three "boards" for a wide selection of sandwiches for the office: Board #1, Board #2 and Bubbees Board (these included ham, turkey, roast beef, corned beef, pastrami, brisket, egg salad, tuna salad, and chicken salad sandwiches), plus veggie and caprese sandwiches. There was also a box of pickles and peppers, all sauce was on the side-- which everyone appreciated-- a box of cookies and two kinds of salads with the housemade dressings.

How did my reputation fare this lunch selection? I feel like maybe I just got one stepper closer to being one of the cool kids.

The meat sandwiches have thin shaved meat which melts in your mouth (with a little board sauce and those pickles!), the vegetarians loved the caprese-esque sandwiches and the salads were also a huge hit. The fusion dressing was the perfect amount of tang and sweet and several people noted that it was really good. Would I go back? Absolutely. Would the office order from them again? I sure hope so!
author: Alanna R.

description:
The only reason it's not 5 stars is that they aren't open on SUNDAYS! argh!

There's no better quality meat in the city.  We're from New York city where REAL pastrami (navel) is produced at the like's of Carnegie and Katz. Albeit the way the meats are cut here vs. the east coast are in no way similar, but the taste is worth not having to fly to New York.

Expensive, but worth it!  Try it and you'll fight with me to get them to open on Sunday!
author: San F.

description:
Been wanting to go here for a while. Damn it i am so glad i did and not haha...Their BOCA is so damn good i cant even speak after my first bite and im not a pickle fan but there shit is on hit nah i meean.

I dont want to sound mushy and all but this is a very cute place arrived there before they opened and already i see two older couple waiting for the door to open like myself.  Older meaning they are in the 60s atleast and i can tell this is what they do often nice to see.

I really cant descrie the taste all i can say is its amaxing their mustard and habanero sausce all great stuff.  I just hate the fact that i have to cross the bridge for this sando and i know i will do it plenty mo times.

Sando worthy of WESTCOAST THUGLIFE for sure.
author: William T.

description:
My face just exploded eating their Rueben's Cousin. I have not tasted better sauerkraut in my life. I guarantee you they have some old guy named Klaus in lederhosen chained out back stirring up his secret family recepe, knee-deep in cabbage. The sandwich was the size of my forearm and the corned beef was sliced and diced perfectly into little pieces. And despite the fact that it's pouring rain today, my sandwich was still hot and dry. Definitely worth the wait and the price.

Seriously, I'm sitting here picking every possible stray clump of sauerkraut out of the sammie wrapper and my keyboard to eat. What's wrong with me?
author: Michael E.

description:
Damn you Deli Board! Why are you so far away from my house? 

Some cousins visited me from Chicago/LA and were staying in Soma. Through Yelp I came across Deli Board and the three of us walked over on a Saturday afternoon for some sandwiches. As Jewish men, we were immediately drawn in by the smell of warm pastrami and corned beef. I went with a GoldbergNStein and subbed brisket for salami. Ike's aside, a better sandwich in SF I've yet to have. The meat + slaw + 1000 island + cheese all came together to create a special lunch experience. If I was to design my ideal sandwich, I honestly think this would be it.

We had one small hiccup on coming here. I gave them the name "Jon" when I ordered and when the sandwich-artist brought out my meal, an imposter posed as "Jon" and took off with my lunch. This took a few minutes to figure out, bu they were immediately apologetic, quickly made a replacement, and threw in a few bags of chips and drinks on the house. We took our lunch to the park across the street. Plenty of picnic tables and grass to spread out.

Can't wait for a return visit!
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Proof that hipsters are just as zombified as tea partiers, blindly going wherever everyone goes, stamping a place with 5-star reviews, just because they're supposed to. 

I walk by here all the time to see hordes of people in line at lunch time, but the other day I was in the hood around 3:30, there was no line, and I thought I'd see what all the fuss was about. Ordered a "Goldie" sandwich from the special board: "turkey breast, bacon, cheddar, cherry peppers, mayo, board sauce on a French roll." $10 plus tax. 

What i got was a medium-sized sandwich with a big pile of dry deli turkey, a little bacon, no cheese (they forgot the cheese!) and a bunch of ridiculously hot peppers. Sauce and mayo negligible. The sandwich was like Death Valley it was so hot and dry -- dry turkey on dry bread. Accompanying it were two small pickle ends. Ends! 

Supposedly there's a whole Cult of Pastrami happening here, and I've never been a big pastrami fan, so maybe I'm missing the point. But jeez, Ted's Market up on Howard and 11th makes giant delicious sandwiches for like $4.50. "Best place in the world"?! Middling-to-poor turkey sandwiches! For $10!! SKIMPY ON THE PICKLES!! If that's heaven I'll choose hell.
author: Ben G.

description:
Yes, only 4 stars. That fifth star is reserved for places that either make my head spin or offer something on par with a happy ending.

That said, I must tell you that THIS PLACE ROCKS!

I went on a Saturday afternoon with a couple friends from Australia. Yes, we had to wait in line (out the door, on the sidewalk), and yes the wait was kind of long-ish. However, everyone in line was pleasant, respectful, and obviously fixated on making a decision as to what lovely sandwich they were going to stuff into their faces.

Once we placed our order with the cute and friendly staff behind the counter, it took about 15 minutes to get our sandwiches, and let me tell you, it was worth the wait.

I had a Gold-n-Berg-Stein ($11), which is a corned beef, pastrami & kosher salami sandwich with Muenster cheese, the house slaw, 1000 island dressing, served on  grilled sweet french bread. The mix of salty and sweet, creamy and crunchy, veggie and meat was truly something to behold. This is a big sandwich, filled to almost overflowing, and constructed in a way that, if you are careful, it is possible to take a bite without everything squirting out the back end. Believe me, this is no small feat.

I will, no doubt, return to Deli Board in order to work my way through the menu since it all sounds so good. I recommend that if you haven't tried their sandwiches yet, don't bother; the line is long enough already, and I get cranky if I have to wait too long.
author: Rev. F.

description: I was a little shocked that items on the basic sandwich menu were $10, but when my egg salad came out on the Dutch Crunch roll, it was a little slice of heaven.
author: Michael G.

description:
I work nearby and have tried every lunch option in the area.  These are the most expensive sandwhiches in the neighborhood, by one to three dollars, depending on what you get.  The biggest sticker shock was the  egg salad sandwhich.  Usually the cheapest thing at a deli, you'll pay double for it here.

And they seem to be selling "Cleveland" as something cool.  Uh, no.  I'm from Cleveland and there is nothing cool about it. 

But these are very good sandwhiches.  I loved my turkey and cheese and my friend who is a very picky eater got the pastrami and commented after each bite about how good it was.  And she raved about the pickles.  In subsequent visits, I have fallen in love with their brisket.  So good.

The people who work there are nice and spin vinyl (real LP's) between orders.  

They get busy, so if you are pressed for time, go early or late.  We were there right at noon and got our food about 30 minutes after we arrived, including the time we spent waiting in line to place our order.

The other customers were friendlier than average, which made the whole experience nicer.

The few soups I have tried have been good, but I don't like eating out of a plastic container.  I feel like I am eating leftovers out of the fridge and hate the waste of using a plastic container once and then discarding it.  I get that they don't want to wash dishes, but serving the soup in a bowl would make a world of difference.
author: Bay G.

description:
Excellent little hole-in-the-wall--literally! Toasted, melted cheese goodness on whole wheat. I love that they're small, and just serve orders out the door--it's perfect to take back to work, but glad to hear they're growing. 

Get the Skinny Reuben's Cousin on whole wheat. Not sure how skinny it really is, but it sure is tasty. 

Oh, and they take credit cards too.
author: N B.

description:
Finally, a very delicious vegetarian sandwich!! The VERA - grilled eggplant and squash cream cheese white american cheese pickled red onion pickles jalapeños Board sauce on dutch crunch.   
And, delivery is key during a storm.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Let me first be very clear. This is not a quick and cheap sandwich joint a la (the spectacularly good) Ted's. This is a high-end sandwicherie.

I had the Cohen and it was simply divine. Generous portions of perfectly cooked corned beef and brisket, a smaller portion of high-taste-impact vegetables (I loved the peppers), delicious sauce, all on a warm french roll that seriously tasted as though it had just come out of the oven.

I wasn't actually super impressed with the pickle (it was too thick to really absorb all the pickling spices, in my opinion), but it was a nice touch.

Service was very, very friendly and the food came out faster than I expected, given how busy it seemed.

It cost $13. Yeah, I know that's a lot, but this was seriously one of the best sandwiches I've had in San Francisco.
author: Luke W.

description:
I just move back to SF recently and this was my first new ventures. I found it by searching for nearby restaurants on the 7x7 Big Eat 2012 List.

Description of the Munsoned:
Shavings of smoked brisket, white American cheese, pepperoncini, Thousand Island, and brown mustard on their signature sweet French roll (a refreshing sweet, spongy change in a city that loves its rustic, Acme bread and toasts everything)

Yessss. And it was amazing. Fresh meat and bread that melts in your mouth. The sweetness of the bread and pepperoncins create an interesting contrast to the savory meat. I wish I had substituted the cheese for something better as I dislike American cheese. The cheese tries to make it feel like a cheap Philly cheese-steak, but gladly the other ingredients made up for it. A single sandwich should serve two. The sandwich reminded me of something from Ike's. It's been a while, but I believe I had a much better experience here.

The customer service is great too. Helpful, social, you know, the traits that people in SF are known for.

Their menu changes daily. Check it out at http://www.deliboardsf.com/the-board/. It all sounds delicious to me.

Eating here felt as if the City had graciously welcomed me back.
author: Rahil P.

description:
Sandwiches like drugs, man.

In the middle of SOMA's seediest hood, there is this secret little spot where you can get the good stuff.  But you gotta know where to go, and who to talk to.

I got the inside scoop from their sando dealer, an unassuming girl with a notepad and a wad of dollars.  I handed over the cash and waited outside while she disappeared into an unmarked building.  After 10 minutes or so, she came back with a wink and a discreet paper bag and we got the hell outta there.

Back in the safety of our office, we found that our Deli Board dealer did, infact, give us the good stuff.  We got a maeday, fatty matty, and boca.  All were super high quality and really blew our minds.  We also received a few little pickle thingy-dingies, sealed up nice in clear plastic ziplock baggies.

Well, great.  Now I'm addicted.  Good thing they make house calls.
author: Mari C.

description:
My coworkers and I ordered out of this place today. Here are the multiple reasons why I'm giving this "establishment" a horrible review. 

First off, I work in the entertainment industry, which is very fast paced and we don't have time to fiddle with pre ordering 24 hours in advance for a quick lunch. We we busy, therefore it was a slightly larger order, for 11 people to be exact. We weren't asking for anything to be different, i.e. either subtracting ingredients and adding others. 

So my first complaint is that as soon as we picked up the phone today at 11:30 this morning, they said we could not place an order over the phone of this extent. Granted we had gone through all of the offices and specifically told them to look at Deli Board's menu. Because of this and because it's a hassle to go back and tell people that they didn't want to take our order, we decided to put most of them over the phone, and once there place the rest. MInd you. both girls that work outside the establishment taking orders were very polite and worked with everyone patiently waiting outside in a slightly sketchy side of SOMA. What really ticked me off is when one of the guys from the kitchen came specifically towards me and told me that because i had ordered more sandwiches once I made it over to the location, that it would take longer and that it was my fault that the sandwiches would not taste as great and to next time order 24 hours in advance because they care about the quality of the food. I politely nodded and inside thought, that was completely uncalled for. Why was I, who gave them a $100 dollar order being nagged for giving them this much business?? Un freaking believeable! 

Another 10 minutes went by (this is by now 40 minutes from when the order was originally placed) and one of the girls told me that my order would soon come out. It did, with three guys and bags out the door- which mind you I had no idea that all three bags were the order that I had placed, therefore I asked if that was all of my order. One of them had the nerve to say, and I quote " well, you placed the order!" - OMG! Are you kidding me? Do you want the business or not? Do you want me to go back and tell my 200 + crew to never go through your establishment that is only opened from 11am til 3pm and say what a pain you were to deal with? Your sarcasm and your bad customer service makes me want to throw your sandwiches out the door and ask for my money back. How rude. Plain and simple they don't deserve your business and in downtown SF, if you don't deal with people properly, you'll just be another shop from the past. 

So once I made it back to the office, I opened mine and granted for being a warm hummus sandwhich, the flavors were not worth even half of that experience. The sauce on the sandwhich was nothing more than what quiznos can do for a vegetarian. Perhaps their meat menu is what everyone else is craving, but this is nothing overboard. For all of you foodies, I prefer Brainwash a few blocks away for much better service, actual tables to sit on while you eat and a place that will treat you like a customer, not like you're a pain in their neck. 

So again, if you work downtown and have a group of people larger than 9, this place won't bend over for you, or your money and if I were you, try Ike's place before even thinking that this is a biased review.
author: Carolina S.

description:
Everyone has heard the saying "A way to a man's heart is through his stomach" and let me tell ya, Adam has this theory down to a science. 

Case in point #1:
This morning I asked around to see who wanted to place an order for delivery from Deli Board and when I came over to the IT pod they had never heard of Adam, or his delicious sandwiches, but when I started to talk about his meats made with love in-house such as his pastrami and corned beef, the eyes of one of the men glazed over and he began to salivate and lick his lips continuously. I didn't even have to finish, they all three in unison said YES! 

Case in point #2: 
After feasting on aforementioned deliciousness, a few of the guys that ordered gave various forms of feedback such as high fives, double thumbs up, some fuck yeahs and maybe a hug. When have men ever given this much feedback?! 

Case in point #3: 
We ordered a total of 9 sandwiches. 8 of them were for men. 


Cased closed. Verdict: Deli Board is le sex. For men and for women. Mostly for men.

Key things to know about Deli Board:

- The don't have a store. Delivery only.
- They cater (and do it well). 
- Their pickles are made in house and are yummy.
- Their sandwiches are even yummier. 
- They take credit card and cash.
author: Jen D.

description:
My sandwich was excellent.  5 stars for the food.  

Know that you are NOT allowed inside this place.  I ended up stumbling upon it and didn't realize it was take-out/delivery only.  Poked my head inside and the chick taking orders basically hit me with a GTFO.  

She then ended up rushing the other guy ordering behind me who the entire time was just looking at her like is this girl serious.  

I'll definitely order from here as I really enjoyed the sandwich.  Hopefully the same girl delivers and I can make her  "WAIT OUTSIDE AND CLEAR THE DOORWAY!"
author: Matt S.

description:
Now thats a sandwich. It wasn't the best sandwich I've had in life, but Deli Board is a top-tier deli. 

I wanted two sandwiches to take to the Giants game, so I called ahead and ordered the Rosen, Rosen and the Boca. The Boca was great. But honestly, the Rosen, Rosen ($9, turkey/salami) was even better. The staff was very friendly, and multiple people asked me if I had been helped within 1 minute of my arrival.

I also dig that they gave us bagged pickles with each sandwich. Huge.

I'll definitely be back.

Update: Had the d.nice as well. It was better than the others. Simply fantastic sandwich!
author: Evan G.

description: One of the best sandwiches I've had.  In line with the SF food prices it's about $12 for a sandwich or salad.  The employees/owner seem nice and make damn good sandwiches.  I'll definitely be going back to try other kinds. It does get very busy though and is only open from 11:00 am - 4:00 pm 6 days a week.  It's worth it though!
author: Dan C.

description:
First time here, I tried the Zeke. Bomb soft french bread and delicious thin deli-sliced meat (& lots of it!). Though simple, it was spectacular and super satisfying. About $10 for a sandwich. I've also seen some people order salads here and it looks great too. But now that I've had the sandwich, I probably won't be order anything else.

I reheated my second half of the sandwich the next day - to my surprise, still delicious as ever! Bread was still just as soft as when I ordered it!
author: Cookie M.

description: Best sandwiches in town!  I personally like any of the sandwiches that have cole slaw inside but you can't go wrong with any selection.
author: Tammy S.

description:
I admit, I havent gone yet.... But Im on this show, and its what they bring me... got the RACH: Pastrami and Muenster on Dutch Crunch... It was one beautiful... I was admittedly quite hungry, but I think it goes on my top 10 sandwiches list... 

I'll try to give them another shot soon, and let you know if it holds up, but I am pretty stoked with my first impression!
author: Will S.

description: Tasty sandwiches but $12 is a bit pricey.  I'd come back more often if the price drop to about $9-10 each.  For now, I'll stop by and get a sando when Citizen Band is out of the shrimp & grits.
author: Veritas V.

description:
the pickles are huge and amazing. i have never tasted such mouthwatering, juicy, sour, crisp evolved cucumbers

customer service is excellent and as fast as it can possibly be...but i never have any luck getting through to them when i try to call in between 11 and 12:30. their phone line, or the workers, are just way too busy!

the sandwiches are soft, warm, saucy, and densely packed with simple ingredients. the meat is thinly sliced, buttery soft, perfectly salty, and packed into the sandwich like no tomorrow. and get a dutch crunch roll! i also highly recommend the vegetarian maeday which consists of grilled eggplant and zucchini, goat cheese cheddar cheese, pepperoncinis, sprouts, basil, pickled red onion, and vinaigrette. the perfect partner...to the delicious pickle.
author: Jessica C.

description: When the meat-to-bread ratio is over 2:1 on a sandwich, you know it's gonna be something outrageous! Can't recall what I had but it was damn good and the fact that they delivered was a bonus!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
The sandwich was great, smaller than in Cleveland but great tastes. It's Cleveland food  with SF price. 
Salad was fresh and it he chicken salad wasn't all fancied- just basic, good chicken!!  And you can buy Cleveland Stadium Mustard at the counter!
author: Akiko I.

description: "MAY DAY, MAY DAY, MAY DAY!!!!!! I've just eaten 1,000 calories in one delicious, fresh, tantalizing sandwhich and I can't get up.....bring me another one"
author: Kristy M.

description: This place lived up to its hype. Unfortunately I was in a food coma for the rest of the day. I cant wait to go back to this place and try more of their sandwiches as they all look so good.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
If someone could earn a PhD in Sandwichology, I believe Adam over at Deli Board could do it. The guy knows his meats and if you get him going, you get the sense he considers pastrami, corned beef and turkey his children.

But wait, have you tried the soups? Another entire revelation, and perfect for these colder times. 

Important note:  there is absolutely no place to sit; you quite literally order from the street. If you message me, I might be bribed into giving away a location or two where you can chow down nearby.
author: Nish N.

description: I know a good deli sandwich when I see one...and these are freaking fantastic. I've only been here a few times (so far) but this is hands down my new fav sandwich spot. Portions are hearty but not to the point where it's too much, quality products, creative meat combos, amazing sauces and a great little vibe. Super busy for a weekday lunch but otherwise a pretty low key spot. Highly recommended.
author: Megan N.

description: I tried the $$$ (money) sandwich.  It was very good.  At least as good as Ike's.  With a little luck you can find parking nearby.  The Boca wasn't on their sandwich board but just ask for it.  Gotta try it next time.  Thanks for the foodie tips, fellow Yelpers.
author: Ed D.

description: I work off of Howard and was getting sick of the same old places. Definitely was not in the mood for a sandwich but when I came across this place on Yelp, I figured it may be worth a try. BEST DECISION EVER! I got the Sha Sha and added avocado. While the walk here was a little shady, it was entirely worth it. Probably will end up here once a week now.
author: Megan B.

description: Great sandwiches, love the service here and the ingredients used. I just wish it was closer to my office!
author: James H.

description: One of the great place to get sandwich!  All sandwich comes with delicious cut pickles. The Boca sandwich is the bomb! Definite worth going again!
author: Christopher G.

description: Ate the Stephanie - a tuna melt with bacon, sprouts and pickles on french bread.  All ingredients are served warm.  Simply the best tuna melt i've ever eaten - full stop.  the place is lovely - bare bones but friendly - turntable and good sound system.  Sandwiches about $12 or so each.  Highly recommended.
author: David E.

description:
Amazing sandwiches, very friendly counter-staff, and occasionally you'll even see Adam make it out from the kitchen. Great place...hopefully they can expand hours to the evenings soon. Good music too.

My only regret is I miss the clandestine nature of the old location on Howard - I swear it was run out of the owner's apartment :-) But the broader menu makes up for it.
author: Brian K.

description:
I'll keep it simple.

This is has THEE BEST PASTRAMI in San Francisco. If you love Pastrami, you must try this place. If you like big, hearty fulfilling sandwiches in general, Deli Board will not disappoint.

It does consist of either ordering for delivery or waiting outside a building/apartment if you order here, but it is worth every cent. I once waited 20 minutes for my sandwich in the scorching hot sun on one of those rare sunny days that the city gets from time to time, and it was worth every minute of my lunchtime. This place is LEGIT.
author: Megan D.

description:
Deli Board is awesome for a take out, tasty sandwich. They give you lots of meat and flavor in each bite! 

I do recommend calling in your order and picking it up because it is a catering, to-go, deli. You cannot sit down and eat. If your near the SF downtown area, they do deliver though!

The wait is long during peak hours, but the wait is worth it. Here are my top sammys:

Zeke - The cream cheese is so delicious
Gold-n-Berg-n-stei - Their pastrami is warm and juicy
HiC - The jalapenos adds a nice kick

They also change up their specials and soups and those are also a must try.

The only downside is that the pickles, are sometimes just cucumbers (very lightly pickled) and i like my pickles.. well.. pickled. But a pickle is not worth docking points because their sandwiches trumps most others!
author: Chris C.

description: The sandwiches here aren't cheap, but they're amazing!  The staff is always friendly and have great energy. The food comes out pretty fast too. I also like that they vary the soup everyday. This can be a downside if you find a soup you really like though!
author: Christopher K.

description:
First of all excellent sandwich. Easily big enough for two if you don't want to eat all your calories in a single meal.  They are really that big.   

So, there seems to be a bit of controversy in various reviews about how to order one of these yummy sammies.  One thing to understand is Deli Board is literally a hole in the wall, its a door you do not enter.  It is not a restaurant or cafe.  It has more in common with a food truck than cafe, except it has a permanent location. There is no inside at all.   I talked to the owner once about this and he said that Deli Board as it is is a bit of a phenomenon that he did not intend.  He was trying to open a catering and delivery sandwich shop and one day people started showing up at the door to order.  So he started to feed them.  And now it is what it is.  

I've never had to wait longer than a minute to be waited on.  But it does take some time to have the order filled.  The only time I ever got any attitude was the first time I went and clueless-ly  started to walk in, ignoring several signs.  As far as waiting on the sidewalk the patrons almost always seem to be extra friendly.  I've always had a conversation started there with someone I've never met, like the self proclaimed Pastrami King of San Francisco.  Hell, its worth going just for that.
author: Michael D.

description:
This has become a regular weekend stop for me, considering I live literally right around the corner.
The sandwiches I've gotten so far have been delicious- especially the falafel. I love that they come with little bags of deli pickels too- it's a unique touch. The menu is very detailed, with tons of interesting sandwiches to choose from and an obvious mixture of Midwestern meat meets East Coast deli. You can't beat either so why not mix them?

Only downside: Pricey.
author: Hannah B.

description:
Soooo very delicious!  The way they slice their meat, and its savory appeal is just so incredibly yummy, I can overlook the spotty service.  
Their pastrami is literally to die for and their salads are humongous.
Plus, I love the slogan: "Where the meat hits the bun", priceless.
author: Jonsey B.

description:
Friday, 1:00PM.

Mundane front. There's not even a place to sit. Who cares? The proprietors obviously put their effort into making legit sandwiches.

Lauren took our order. She's from OH. How did I know she was a true Cleveland fan? LeBron's departure is still painful.

Quickie: 
++Great customer service
++Fast turnaround for food 

Grabbed the sandwiches and went to a nearby park to nom nom nom. One sandwich wasn't enough, so went back for another. Adam, the chef, came out to greet this PHATTY who ate two large subs for one meal.

And then...?
Deli Board makes a serious case for the Bay's top sammy place. And they deliver too? It's over y'all!

**********
Stuffed my face in:

1. Veggie Burger
     +Moist patty, firm sides, stacked with fresh avocado
     +Not bland 
2. Falafel Sammy
     +Yogurt sauce softens the fried exterior, tomatoes and juicy interior 
     of chic peas fills each bite
3. Gold-n-Berg-n-stein
     ++Thinly sliced pastrami, stacked to a thick medium, full of flavor
     ++Corn beef AND kosher salami with muenster - each takes its turn 
     prevailing
4. Sausage soup
     +Tomato roasted corn and Italian sausage = hearty goodness
     +Lauren hooked it up with a sample of this soup
5. Pickles
     ++Succulent house-made pickles, full of crunch n' crisp
author: Chuck N.

description:
Something magical happened to these sandwiches. I got to experience the deliciousness that Deli Board has to offer during a recent lunch meeting in the office, catered by Deli Board. Their version of Caprese [the Mila] sandwich was spectacular and the grilled vegetable sandwich [the Leia] with some other worldly spread -  was it cream cheese? Oh yes, it was. Either way, it was exactly what I was hoping for. No one makes em like that anymore.

That's not even the best part. The bread. I used to be something of a bread connoisseur before the advent of the Atkins diet. While I'm not a practicing Atkins dieter, it did help me take inventory on my abundant consumption of carbs and I have since slacked a bit in my hunt for delicious bread. I digress. This sandwich bread is perfect in every way. Soft, fresh hoagie rolls. Whether you go white or wheat. Pretty much everyone who got a bite of these is now planning a group pilgrimage over to the brick and mortar for more. Among the others tried and received rave reviews from the meat eaters were the brisket - this disappeared first, the corned beef and pastrami and turkey. I'm pretty sure some of us ate our weight in sandwiches that day. 

Even their pickles are crisp, fresh, and delicious. Perhaps I'm starved for a decent sandwich in this neighborhood [doubtful because while this neighborhood is starved for variety in lunch options, there are sandwiches aplenty] but I'm definitely on board with Deli Board.
author: Angela N.

description:
I live approximately 500ft from Deli Board and find it hard to eat anywhere else in SF.  The gravity's just too great, the food too heart breakingly good.

They are The Word when it comes to a Deli.  Adam, so far as I can tell, is one of the last true great innovators in sandwiches, and he deserves a scientific award for his contribution to the field.  Regular PhD of the art, and a totally rad dude to boot.

Oh, and all the lovely ladies who take care of ya'.  Almost as good as a little East Coast Diner, but way sassier.  Makes a rainy day in SoMa worthwhile.


The line out the door?  Yeah, deal with it, fool.  There's a reason for the line.  Kids ain't dumb.  So hop in line and get ready for overdrive.


And ask Adam for some of the ultra spice he keeps in the back.  Phenomenal.



-Cd
author: Cody D.

description:
Not for the faint of heart. Massive, epic, delicious, awesome. They have a new spot which is pretty bare bones but a nice step up from the sidewalk at 7th and Howard.

My only complaint about the sandwiches are that they seem to be lacking some balance. These things are more like a boxer who just gets gets into a punching battle instead of the boxer who gracefully bobs and weaves to avoid being knocked out by a hay-maker. I think some veggies or vinegar would go a long way to making these the best sandos in the city, but even without the balance I generally look for, they are damn close.
author: Josh B.

description:
It's time to line up, Deli Board is serving better Matzoh ball soup than your  Bubbie.   The sandwiches rule and leaving me wanting more.    Dutch crunch bread, brisket, cheese and peppers......8.7 

The location is interesting, however, I will be dreaming about these for sometime.   This is a winner.   If you are hungry and need a great meal, visit Deli Board.
author: Susan J.

description:
Awesome Sandwiches!

This is a far cry from traditional West Coast deli fare. The sandwiches burst with flavor, and are very satisfying. The staff is friendly and helpful, the interior tastefully and creatively decorated.

Highly recommend. 

P.S. Buy a bottle of 'Stadium Mustard' previously available only in Cleveland
author: Ethan K.

description: It was a decent sandwich. The meat or bread was nothing to rave about. The sandwich had a good amount of meat, but the sandwich wasn't that big. I got the Boca by the way. What was a turn off was the price. A single sandwich on the small side cost $15. for. a. sandwich. My son got an egg salad sandwich and my wife got a cobb salad. I automatically chose the smallest tip option which was 15%. We did not eat there. The bill came out to $40+. Jeez luis. Oh and the crowd? Just another reminder of why I don't live in the city anymore.
author: Gavin M.

description: Do yourself a favor and go here!!  Ahhhhh-Mazing sandwiches!!!  We tried The Zeke and The Mezman!  Both Oh. So. Good.
author: Edie P.
